title: Top 7 Benefits Of Using Cloud CRM To Your Business | MYNPEC
text:
CRM is a trendy term in today‚Äôs business world. Everybody knows that they can benefit from it, but many aren‚Äôt aware of which solution would be best for their company‚Äôs needs.

CRM is one of the excellent tools that can help you establish closer connections with your customers, provide professional customer service, and sell more. Whether ten or 100+ employees, CRMs are an essential aspect of any business‚Äô success.

Image Source: Adobe Stock

So, if you‚Äôre among the 72% of companies who are investing in modern technology such as CRM and see it as a way to grow your business, then let us help you guide you through these unknown waters without getting lost on the path towards finding what CRM fits you perfectly.

What is a Cloud CRM System?

CRM software has been the standard for decades. It‚Äôs time to take advantage of new technology and use cloud-based CRM platforms, accessed from any device with an online network connection.

With instant access to real-time insights, you‚Äôll have less work on your hands than before because you can automate critical processes like qualifying leads or closing deals for increased customer retention rates.

Cloud vendors are striving to meet the demands of an ever-changing business world. According to Flexera‚Äôs report , the number one strategic initiative for 2020 is ‚Äúmigrating more workloads‚Äù into cloud services (second only behind optimizing existing use), which 61% of companies plan on doing in the year 2020 alone.

Image Source: Flexera

What are the reasons to use a cloud-based CRM system?

Cloud-based CRM is an excellent way for companies of all sizes to grow their businesses. Here are seven reasons or benefits of cloud-based CRM on why you should consider it.

1. Work From Anywhere or Anytime

A cloud-based CRM is a system that can be accessed on any device, around the clock. This capability makes it easier than ever for teams across different departments to get the information they need in any device like a smartphone, a tablet, a laptop, or a desktop and ultimately improve business process efficiency by allowing staff members from anywhere in an organization access to their respective databases at all hours of day or night.

The cloud-based CRM provides seamless mobile access to the centralized database that you can use for making sales calls, amending proposals, or finding prospects‚Äô phone numbers.

2. Hassle-free Installation

Image Source: Freepik

In the world of CRM, you‚Äôve heard the phrase ‚Äúa long process‚Äù and complex installations. That was true in past years, but now it‚Äôs not! With cloud-based systems and quick installation times, getting your company on board with an efficient customer relationship management strategy is easy as pie.

All you ever need is a steady internet connection for Cloud-based CRM installation. Once signed in, plenty of software and capabilities are available to make the most out of it.

You can very well easily access it from anywhere or anytime with an internet connection and never have to worry about setting up hardware or paying for maintenance on servers since that all gets taken care of by a cloud-based CRM provider .

3. Flexible

Image Source: Adobe Stock

CRM is a vast and comprehensive system that can help your business communicate more efficiently. A cloud-based CRM offers the ability to tailor it specifically for you while also giving businesses of all sizes multiple options when the small companies need something new or improved in their platform ‚Äî like adding extra features on-demand without having any downtime whatsoever.

A cloud-based CRM is a perfect fit for any business. Not only does it offer instant updates to satisfy new needs, but employees can also do what they need when with this system as long as it has 24√ó7 access.

4. Cost-effectiveness

It‚Äôs easy to analyze why many people would be hesitant about investing in a CRM system. The upfront cost can seem overwhelming, and there are so many options out on the market today that it is hard for small businesses like startups without much resources at their disposal to choose one wisely.

However, cloud-based solutions (which offer pay-as-you-go subscriptions) become less of an issue because these types operate with minimal initial investments, making them more affordable than ever before.

5. Effortless Integration

The multitude of software and hardware that make up a CRM can often be cumbersome, especially in businesses where information exchange between different applications is prevalent.

A cloud-based CRM software provides flexible options for companies who need more help with their sales process than traditional stand-alone products.

This compatibility, specifically in its ability to integrate across multiple platforms and devices like Gmail and Office 365 products, including Excel, Word, and PowerPoint.

This makes the Cloud an even better choice for your business. This enables you to carry out tasks seamlessly from the start through the finish without any difficulties.

6. Enhanced Security

Cloud solutions are more cost-effective and much safer than traditional data center solutions. Companies that offer cloud-based CRM software take security concerns seriously with advanced automated backup policies and robust recovery plans to ensure the safety of your information no matter what happens in case there‚Äôs an attack on their system.

You can improve upon these already impressive levels by using two-step authentication or stronger passwords and being completely GDPR compliant using cloud-based CRM software.

7. Great Reliability

What happens if the power goes out? In this situation, you would have no access to your customer data or information. That means all of that hard work is going up in smoke.

Not only could there be a significant halt with productivity but even worse ‚Äî some essential details about their products and services might disappear forever due to an offline CRM system model, which has been known as on-premise software.

With a cloud-based CRM system, you can get your customer data through the cloud, restore it onto a computer or smartphone and go back to work without worrying about losing any vital information.

That kind of reliability is not just convenient but necessary in this day and age where cyberattacks are constant threats that we must always be aware of.

Ending Note

A cloud-based customer relationship management system will help you provide excellent service by centralizing your customer database and automating key processes.

You‚Äôll be able to access real-time updates, which give an end-user a comprehensive view of their interactions with customers all from one system.

Cloud-based CRMs provide several benefits that make them attractive for many businesses. They‚Äôre easy to install, offer seamless online access with low setup costs and no special equipment required; they also happen cost-effectively as well as securely! The most popular integration options are available right out the box, so adding additional features such as chat or email marketing is simple too.

NPEC offers a flexible and cost-effective cloud solution that can be tailored to meet the specific needs of your business.

We‚Äôll work with you every step along this journey with our team on board! Are you interested in setting up cloud-based CRM software for your company? now to get started on setting this new CRM trend into motion together!

Frequently Asked Questions

1.What do advanced cloud-based CRM platforms have?

A cloud-based CRM software is a powerful tool for companies that want to provide excellent customer service.

With an online interface, the advanced cloud-based CRM makes it easy and quick to centralize your database, automate critical processes giving you instant online access to real-time insights into how well each interaction went as well as provide a comprehensive view on every level of contact, including leads generated through social media channels like Facebook ads or Twitter promotions which can be converted directly back into a customer base at any time.

2.What‚Äôs the Difference Between On-Premise and Cloud CRM?

The significant difference between cloud and on-premise CRM software is where information, software deployment strategies are kept.

In the on-premise software, it‚Äôs all done locally at your company site with an installation of servers to store data and CRM programs.

Instead, Cloud CRM services will have access via internet connection only so their info can be remotely stored within these remote databases or accessed whenever needed across any device ‚Äî whether the computerized desktop system (PC) or laptop.

title: Make Better Use of Suite CRM with Kanban Boards
text:
Your organisation may utilise CRM for day to day sales activities, and the visualisation of the sales pipeline is of great benefit to the sales team. The question then becomes, how do you get the most out of the CRM software, and is there a way to improve its visualisation benefits to further increase its value to your team?

Take SuiteCRM, a popular open source CRM solution which is used all over the world. It provides all the benefits of conventional CRM software, but its views do not provide ample context for the sales pipeline stages that could prompt actual action.

Take the example of a module, say leads. A list view is good for letting you know how many leads are being pursued, but in a quick glance it is not easy to determine how many new leads have been generated, and how many in comparison have been progressed.

Kanban Boards

This is where the idea of Kanban boards comes in. Imagine a board with lanes, such that each lane represents a unique lead stage such as new, assigned, and in process. Now imagine a sticky note with a task written on it that you put in the lane representing the stage the task is in. That‚Äôs the idea of Kanban. With a Kanban board it is not only easy to see where everything is, but easy to shift it around so it is organized for maximum positive outcome. When looking at your sales in Kanban view, it is easy to see where the heavy load is. If any of the stages has more cards than others, you know that you risk dropping sales because work could be stalled. With this insight available instantly, you can spread the tasks for a smoother operation of your sales.

Kanban gives a bird‚Äôs eye view of your sales pipeline. According to AllBusiness.com, ‚ÄùKanban Can Help Take the Stress Out of Sales‚Äù. Trello, which is based entirely on this concept, was acquired in 2017 for $425 million.

When you use Kanban boards instead of the default list view, you get more done in less time.

How Kanban boards improve CRM

If you want to improve sales operations, and increase productivity of your team, Kanban in CRM is the way to go. With a bird‚Äôs eye view of the whole process, including which item is in which stage, and how many items are in each stage, it is far easier to make sure that sales are not stalled at any stage.

In addition, Kanban for CRM makes it easy to shift the items around. With a simple drag and drop, you can qualify a lead, progress a sale along the pipeline, and even mark a sale as complete or incomplete.

RT Dynamic Boards

RT Dynamic Boards is a Kanban plugin for Suite that enables the Kanban view for your modules so that you can reap the benefits of Kanban inside SuiteCRM.

But Dynamic Boards doesn‚Äôt limit itself to simplifying the sales progress along the pipeline. On the Kanban cards, you are provided with shortcuts to calls, emails, and notes, so all actions for the card are within a few clicks. Each card also shows other relevant information for the item, so for instance a lead has the source displayed in colour coordinated tags. This saves you the hassle of switching back and forth from list view to detail view for each and every item.

Why Dynamic Boards?

When you use Kanban boards instead of the default list view, you get more done in less time. By simply providing you more options on the main view, and by enabling simple drag and drop changes for assigning opportunities or qualifying a lead, whereby you can move a record in the pipeline much more quickly than you could without Kanban, Dynamic boards allows your business to give more time to focus on each lead without being bogged down by the procedural issues of updating fields in CRM.

Get RT Dynamic Boards for SuiteCRM

If you are using SuiteCRM in your business, simply get the RT Dynamic Boards plugin here, or contact support@rolustech.com if you want to know more.

title: ‚ÄòToo much sugar‚Äô is surely a thing‚Ä¶
text:
Photo by Mikhail Nilov from Pexels

Sugar is a simple carbohydrate that your body uses for energy and is also considered the source of all health evils. But how much of it is harmful is the real question. According to many health organizations and medical experts, the amount of sugar intake has been the biggest public health concern.

Signs that tell you that you are eating too much sugar

Increased hunger and weight gain:

Consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages has been linked to weight gain. Also consuming sugar makes you want to eat more sugar.

Irritability:

Eating too much sugar can be the reason if you‚Äôre feeling moody or irritable.

Low energy and fatigue:

Sugar is something that can be easily absorbed and digested and that might be the reason you are feeling fatigued. It is also a very quick energy source but no matter how much you eat, after 30 minutes you are going to be hungry again and will feel low.

Cravings for sweets:

The feel-good effect of sugar on your brain might be the reason you are craving sweets all the time.

High blood pressure:

Scientists say that high levels of glucose can damage the lining of your blood vessels which makes it easier for lipids like cholesterol to stick to the walls of blood vessels. This hardens the blood vessels causing your blood pressure to shoot.

Acne and wrinkles:

Research shows that advanced glycation end products (AGEs), which are products of excess sugar, encourage skin aging.

Sleep issues:

The sleep cycles and quality of sleep are regulated by the light and the temperature of the room, as well as glycemic control. So a diet with high sugar can cause long-term sleep issues.

Joint pain:

Consuming too much sugar might lead to systemic inflammation, which might ultimately lead to joint pain.

Why is sugar present in almost all foods?

The reasons why sugar is present in almost all foods are given below:

Adding sugar to foods makes them more appealing

Sugar is added because of its preservative abilities

It serves as a bulking agent in ice creams and baked goods

It balances the acidity level of foods containing vinegar and tomatoes

It fuels fermentation

It gives baked goods flavor, texture, and color

Nutrition labels and sugar

The threshold for the products being high or low in sugar is given below:

High: more than 22.5 total sugar/100g of serving

Low: 5g or less total sugar/100g of serving

Why are added sugars a problem?

As it provides extra calories and provides very little nutritional value. Eating too much sugar might lead to multiple health problems.

Weight gain: Added sugar adds to the problem of weight gain as it is extremely calorie-dense. Poor nutrition: If you are choosing sugar-laden foods instead of nutritious foods then you might miss out on important nutrients, vitamins, and minerals. Tooth decay: Sugar promotes tooth decay as the bacteria multiplies and grows. You are more likely to get cavities if you drink or eat more foods with added sugar.

Some of the different names of added sugar

Cane syrup Malt Maple syrup Molasses Honey

Conclusion:

Sugars, though are considered a source of energy, can have negative effects if their consumption exceeds a certain point. So it‚Äôs really important to look out for the sugar content in your meals and diet. If the amount is too high, it is paramount you control its intake.

title: ProtoType One
text:
ProType One Design Concept

I‚Äôm on this endeavour to help people with type one diabetes run successful marathons and even help them complete the Ironman triathlon.

How is that possible? It‚Äôs a Loonshot worth nurturing I believe and I‚Äôve learned insights that one couldn‚Äôt find in a textbook yet.

It is because, on this journey I decided it‚Äôs time to reach out to pioneering experts like Havlik Marcell, the CEO of Diabtrend.

Diabtrend is an AI based diabetes diary application. Why is that a BIG Deal?

Let me give you some context.

To this day, I keep a record of my blood glucose measurements in a physical notebook designed for the purpose to track my blood glucose and insulin dosages.

The notebook is not so precise, it is rather based on habitual timings with measurements slots for three regularly occurring meals like ‚Äúvalues before and after breakfast‚Äù

The doctors recommendation is to check before and within 90 minutes after the meals. But what if you have snacks in between meals? And what if you excercise?

A picture of my oldschool diabetes diary

There is always two kinds of data one can collect: qualitative and quantitative data. Diabtrend is setting a standard for medical best practice by allowing you to collect both.

The app uses a training period of two days to set trends for your glucose levels and learns more and more overtime when you use their gamified point collecting system that helps in the blood glucose prediction system they have.

In addition to this there is food and voice recognition built in to the app.

I was amazed when I first saw this technology!

That‚Äôs when I realised, perhaps it‚Äôs time to show them my first prototype.

I‚Äôm focused on pairing caloric output to the changes in blood glucose.

The aim is to be able to predict the change in plasma glucose based on the caloric performance of the athlete.

For this I developed an experimental formula and I was hoping to get some feedback from the team behind Diabtrend.

What I learned was that maybe it‚Äôs time for me to start thinking about self learning algorithms and great news : My equation could serve as a basis for one!

Marcell introduced me to a computer language I haven‚Äôt heard before. It‚Äôs called Julia.

Then he recommended I check out this TED talk with Alan Edelman, the co-inventor of the programing language.

Edelman says:

‚ÄúA good programing language design is applied psychology‚Ä¶

It not only allows computer units to talk to computers, but it allows humans to talk to humans about their intent on the computer.‚Äù

Moreover, there are four objectives he specifies:

It creates community

enables talk between humans and machines

creates software collaboration

Benefits everyone from high performance

And thanks to the world wide web I get to part of the community of seekers who think about self learning algorithms, but there is a challenge.

For security reasons the continuous glucose monitoring sensors use an encoded data transfer method that doesn‚Äôt allow third parties to use the data.

It‚Äôs a good thing that strangers can‚Äôt hack my blood glucose readings, but the thing is‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt experiment with it either.

This brings us to the topic of designing experiments and one of my favourite Nobel Laureates, William D. Philips.

In year of 2019 in Lindau he said in an interview view with Adam Smith :

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs clear that there is a French approach to doing science that is different from an American approach to doing science, at least among the French scientists that I know.

Now, of course, people say these days ‚ÄúThe World is Flat‚Äù meaning that that things tend to even out across the world and perhaps the differences are not as great as they once were.

But I appreciate those differences very much, because the way I see the difference, what we might call the classic exaggerated version of the difference between the French approach and the American approach is that the French would think of a problem first.

They would calculate everything that they could about that problem, figure out exactly what should happen, and then go into the lab and see that that they had calculated whereas the Americans would think of a problem and say, wonder if I could do that in the lab, then go into a lab and see what happens.‚Äù

For now it seems I‚Äôll have to choose the French route and continue the progress that way until I become certified to develop my solutions.

It‚Äôs an interesting journey and I‚Äôm happy to be up for the ride.

Thank you for reading!

title: Innovations in Continuous Glucose Monitoring for diabetics
text:
Continuous Glucose Monitoring Device. For a long time to diabetics, fingerprick tests were a regular affair when it came to monitoring their blood sugar levels. However, a recent generation of devices called Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) have risen to give accurate blood sugar readings in almost real time.

Some of these gadgets can be connected to a smartphone or smartwatch and display readings remotely. Most CGM devices are equipped with audible alarms that set off when the blood sugar level spikes or drops too suddenly.

For use with smart devices ‚Äî Dexcom G6

The Dexcom G6 is one CGM more popular with those who love smart technology. By sending automatic updates (every 5 minutes) to a connected smartphone (both iPhones and Android), tablet or computer, it excels at smooth close monitoring. Particularly for those times when glucose levels may drop dangerously low, causing one to lose consciousness.

Known to be highly accurate, the gadget monitors interstitial fluid to gauge the level of blood sugar level. The sensor is wearable on the belly or arm.

Great value ‚Äî Abbott FreeStyle Libre

A really simple device, the Abbott FreeStyle Libre serves its CGM functions well, making for easy reading and great value. One drawback is that it needs the phone to be scanned over the device itself to get a reading. The good thing is that there is no limit to the number of scans allowed.

Additionally, it is designed to be placed on the back of the arm only. If constantly scanning the device is not a problem for you then this gadget will likely prove to be a worthy choice.

Long term use ‚Äî Senseonics Eversense

The Senseonics Eversense requires a physician to insert the device underneath your skin and activate it. You cannot replace or activate it on your own. Do take note of this important peculiarity.

However, it only needs to be replaced every 90 days, making it ideal for long term use. Combined with its low-maintenance, the Eversense model is good for those who just need a basic CGM and do not mind it being inserted under the skin.

This article was produced solely for the purpose of healthcare and medical knowledge. Not all innovations are available or approved for clinical use. AsiaMD may receive financial or non-financial sponsorship from the companies or institutions involved in these innovations. However, AsiaMD does not endorse any specific product or service in the article, in addition to the Terms and Conditions for the use of our AsiaMD.com website.

title: Diabetes Vaccine: Immunotherapy (PIpepTolDC) shot for Type 1 Diabetes
text:
Research Spotlight

When speaking about vaccination, usually the end goal is to prevent the disease from happening. But have you ever thought of vaccination as a treatment for an auto-immune disease?

Well, the PepTolDC immunotherapy vaccine (a treatment that uses a person‚Äôs immune system) is designed just to fit that!

With more than 1.25 billion people worldwide affected by diabetes and 246 million children under the age of 20 affected, this immunotherapy vaccine seeks to not only help patients with type 1 diabetes but also to prevent type 1 diabetes, or T1D before it even starts.

Phase I trials (taking place at the City of Hope Medical Center ‚Äî California) are investigating the side effects of the PIpepTolDC vaccine in treating patients with type 1 diabetes who use insulin and don‚Äôt have any other diabetes-related health complications.

Given that Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease, the PIpepTolDC vaccine helps the immune system to stop attacking the beta cells of the pancreas, which may help the beta cells recover and make enough insulin to control blood sugar levels.

The idea of solving the core problem of auto-immune disease is a dream coming true! Better yet, it may have implications for other auto-immune diseases as well.

How does this treatment work?

To understand how this treatment works, it is critical to understand Type I Diabetes first.

Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease. This means that the human immune system, which usually protects against foreign invaders like bacteria and viruses, attacks the body‚Äôs insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas marking an autoimmune response. Over time, the beta cells are destroyed by the immune system.

As you can imagine, the standard treatment for people with type I diabetes would be insulin intake. But this can be expensive, chaotic, and often ineffective at maintaining a normal lifestyle.

Here‚Äôs the good part: PIpepTolDC vaccine works like an allergy shot. The vaccine is made using one‚Äôs immune cells (dendritic cells) and a beta-cell protein. It appears to put an end to the body‚Äôs attack on the insulin-producing beta cells of the pancreas. The vaccine aims as well to reactivate immune tolerance mechanisms that are poised to begin repairing beta-cell damage and restoring their ability to secrete sufficient levels of insulin in response to blood glucose levels.

This would be a very important advance in T1D treatment and may even help to reduce future type 1 diabetes-related complications!

How can I get involved?

While this study is still in the first phase of human trials, it has the great promise to have a life-changing impact on people with diabetes and autoimmune disorders across the world. Participants are likely to be paid in addition to having access to the most up-to-date potential treatments and contributing to essential research. Studies like this one can redefine diabetes treatment in the future. If you‚Äôre one of the 1.6 million people living with type-1 diabetes in the US, this exciting treatment and potential cure could be available to you.

The trial is currently recruiting around 7 volunteers, all of whom must have been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes based on the American Diabetes Association (ADA) criteria. Participants also are required to have the historical presence of at least one type-1 diabetes-associated autoantibody and must meet over 30 other criteria as well. It may be confusing at first to understand whether you qualify for this research study. Luckily, MyDiabetesResearch can help you understand which research studies you qualify for! The search tool can even show you the best-fit research studies based on your preferences and medical profile!

If you‚Äôd like to learn more about some of the groundbreaking research that is driving us closer to a world free of insulin injections and pumps, feel free to sign up for our email list here or visit our website, www.joindiabetesresearch.com, for more information.

title: Diabetic Retinopathy : A complete review
text:
Image credits : Canva

What is Diabetic Retinopathy, and how does it affect you?

Diabetic retinopathy is caused by damage to the blood vessels in the retinal tissues ( retina). Uncontrolled blood sugar is a risk factor. Diabetic retinopathy may cause no symptoms or just minor vision abnormalities at first. However, it has the potential to cause blindness.

Anyone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes can develop the illness. The longer you have diabetes and the less tightly you control your blood sugar, the more likely you are to have this eye problem.

What signs and symptoms of diabetic retinopathy are there?

There are no symptoms of diabetic retinopathy in the early stages; however, as the condition progresses, you may develop:

Spots or dark strings may appear in your vision.

Vision is blurry.

The vision that shifts.

There are dark or empty spots in your vision.

Loss of vision

What types of diabetic retinopathy exist?

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)-

The most common form of the disease referred to as ‚ÄòNonproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy,‚Äô is the early stage of DR in which there is no abnormal growth of blood vessels (proliferation).

NPDR causes the walls of your retinal blood vessels to weaken. This causes ‚Äòmicroaneurysms‚Äô to protrude from the walls of the smaller blood vessels, sometimes causing fluid and blood leakage into the retina.

It also causes dilation of larger retinal vessels, causing them to dilate beyond their normal diameter. NPDR progresses from mild to severe as more blood vessels become blocked. This can also cause swelling in the retina‚Äôs micro nerve fibers, causing the macula (the central-most region of the retina) to swell.

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) -

As the severity of diabetic retinopathy worsens, it can progress to this advanced stage known as proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The earlier damaged blood vessels have closed off by this stage, stimulating the growth of new, abnormal blood vessels within the retina, which are most likely to leak blood and fluid into the clear, jelly-like substance that fills the central area of your eye (vitreous).

This abnormal growth of blood vessels within the retina stimulates the growth of scar tissue, which may eventually lead to the retina‚Äôs detachment from the back of the eye. There is also a chance that the new blood vessels will obstruct the normal flow of eye fluid, resulting in increased pressure in the eyeball. This can also cause damage to the optic nerve, the central nerve that connects your eye to your brain, leading to glaucoma.

What other complications might diabetic retinopathy bring about?

Diabetic retinopathy, if left untreated, can lead to a variety of other serious eye problems, including:

1)Diabetic macular edema (DME) ‚Äî DME is a type of macular edema caused by diabetes. DME occurs when blood vessels in the retina bleed fluid into the macula, resulting in blurred vision.

2) Glaucoma with neovascularization -

Diabetic retinopathy can cause aberrant blood vessels to grow out of the retina, obstructing the drainage of fluid from the eye. This leads to a specific type of glaucoma (a group of eye diseases that can cause vision loss and blindness).

3) Retinal detachment

Retinal detachment is a condition in which the retina becomes detached from the rest of the body. Scars in the back of your eye might develop as a result of diabetic retinopathy. Tractional retinal detachment occurs when scars pull your retina out from the back of your eye.

Who is more likely to get diabetic retinopathy?

Diabetic retinopathy can affect anyone with any kind of diabetes, including type 1 and type 2 diabetes, as well as persons who are pregnant.

The longer you have diabetes, the greater your risk of diabetic retinopathy. Diabetic retinopathy affects more than half of all diabetics over time. However, by regulating your blood sugar levels, you can reduce your risk of developing diabetic retinopathy.

Women who have diabetes and get pregnant, or who acquire gestational diabetes, are at significant risk of developing diabetic retinopathy.

If you have diabetes and are pregnant, you should get a thorough dilated eye exam as soon as possible. Consult your doctor if you require an additional eye examination during your pregnancy.

What factors contribute to diabetic retinopathy?

Diabetes can cause cataracts, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy, which is defined as damage to the retinal vessels of the eye. If not treated, these damaged vessels can cause poor blood flow (ischemia), inflammation, and, eventually, contractual blindness.

How is diabetic retinopathy diagnosed?

Diabetic retinopathy can be detected during a routine eye examination by an ophthalmologist.

Visual acuity: The ability to see is referred to as acuity

Intraocular pressure: Intraocular pressure to rule out glaucoma.

Eye muscle function: Muscle function in the eyes refers to your ability to move your eyes.

Peripheral vision: Peripheral vision is what you see when you look out the sides of your eyes.

Pupil response: This test examines your pupils‚Äô reactions to light.

Your eye doctor will then administer eye drops. Your pupils dilate (widen) as a result of the drops .

During this examination, the doctor looks for:

Blood vessels that are not normal.

You have a bleed in the center of your eye.

New blood vessel formation.

Swelling of the retina

What can I do to reduce my chances of developing DR?

Long-term blood glucose control aids in the prevention of diabetic retinopathy and reduces the risk of getting it.

Taking the following actions can reduce your risk of getting diabetic retinopathy:

Trying not to smoke.

Keeping your blood sugar under control is essential.

Regularly exercising.

Getting your eyes checked on a regular basis.

Maintaining a healthy blood pressure.

Following all prescription instructions to the letter.

What is the DR treatment?

Your eye doctor will generally only keep track of how your eyes are going in the early stages of DR. As a result, diabetic retinopathy patients may require a full dilated eye exam every 2 to 4 months.

It is critical to begin therapy as soon as possible in the later stages, especially if you notice alterations in your vision; treatment can prevent your eyesight from worsening. It‚Äôs also critical to take efforts to manage your diabetes, blood pressure, and cholesterol.

Managing Your Lifestyle: One of the most effective methods to combat any health issue, including DR, is to improve your entire lifestyle. This will keep your eye‚Äôs blood vessels healthy and efficient, which will help you control your blood pressure and blood sugar levels and prevent vision loss. Improving your dietary intake is also an important aspect of DR-resistance lifestyle management.

References-

title: Diabetes Insipidus causes & diagnosis (DI)
text:
Diabetes Insipidus (DI) is a rare disorder with a reported prevalence of 1 in 25,000 people in the general population. In this disorder, there is an imbalance of fluids in the body and the kidneys pass an abnormally large volume of urine which is colourless and odourless.

In this article, we are going to discuss in detail diabetes insipidus causes & diagnosis.

Did you know that Insipidus comes from the word ‚Äòinsipid‚Äô, meaning weak or tasteless?

In most people, the kidneys pass about 1‚Äì2 litres of urine a day but in people with DI, the kidney can pass about 3 to 19 litres of urine a day in severe cases. As a result, the person may feel extreme thirst even if he/she has something to drink.

Adults have a higher chance of developing the condition but it can occur at any age. In rare cases, diabetes insipidus diagnosis can occur during pregnancy also, known as gestational diabetes insipidus.

Now, you must keep reading the blog to know more about the condition, its diagnosis, causes, treatment and how it differs from Diabetes Mellitus. In order to understand Diabetes Insipidus, first, let us learn about the role of kidneys and normal fluid regulation in your body.

Role of kidneys and normal fluid regulation

The kidneys play a very important role in fluid balance.

Kidneys are bean-shaped organs about the size of a fist located just below the rib cage, one on each side of the spine. To produce 1‚Äì2 litres of urine, the kidneys normally filter about 120 to 150 quarts of blood composed of waste and extra liquids.

In overall body mass, fluids can make up as much as 60% and maintaining the proper amount of fluids in the body is key for overall health management. While urination removes most of the fluid from the body, breathing and sweating also help to remove fluid from your body.

A system of organs and hormone signals are used by your body to normally regulate the fluids. The kidneys play a very important role in fluid balance and regulation by removing extra fluid from the bloodstream.

The fluid levels are regulated in the body either by producing less urine when there is a need to replace fluid lost to sweating or making more urine when there is too much fluid in your body. Your brain (hypothalamus) regulates the feeling of thirst and the need to drink water.

What is Diabetes Insipidus (DI) and how is it different from Diabetes Mellitus (DM)?

Diabetes insipidus diagnosis happens when either the secretion or response to the pituitary hormone ‚Äòvasopressin‚Äù, also known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is impaired. It results in the production of very large amounts of dilute urine which is colourless and odourless often leading to dehydration and increased thirst.

In most cases of DI, there isn‚Äôt enough antidiuretic hormone (ADH) production or the kidneys are not responding properly to ADH. Excessive production of urine can result in dangerous dehydration if a person does not increase the water intake.

Another question that might come to your mind: Are Diabetes Insipidus and Diabetes Mellitus related?

The answer is Diabetes Insipidus and Diabetes Mellitus (both type 1 and type 2) are unrelated, although both conditions might have similar symptoms like frequent urination and constant thirst. Here is the difference:

In Diabetes Mellitus, high sugar levels lead to the production of large volumes of urine to help remove excess sugar from the body.

In Diabetes Insipidus, increased urination is due to disturbance in the water balance system of the body.

Of the two conditions, diabetes mellitus is more harmful and harder to manage. Let us now take a look at the different types of Diabetes Insipidus.

If you‚Äôre looking for diabetes treatment and management, you can enrol in our program where you will be under the guidance of experts. Visit Zyla.in or download the Zyla app now.

What are Diabetes Insipidus causes and types?

The brain produces an antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin which is stored in the pituitary gland after production. When the body needs to retain water, the pituitary gland releases vasopressin into the bloodstream.

But what causes DI? When there is a need to remove water from the body, the hormone is either released in very small amounts or not released at all, leading to urination more often.

Diabetes Insipidus causes include a disruption in hormone production or when any part of the regulation system breaks down. If a person has diabetes insipidus, the body can‚Äôt properly balance fluid levels.

There are 4 types of diabetes insipidus and each type of Diabetes Insipidus causes are unique. Types include:

1. Central Diabetes Insipidus

When there is some damage to a person‚Äôs hypothalamus or pituitary gland, it causes disruption in the normal production, storage and release of vasopressin leading to central diabetes insipidus. This causes the kidney to remove large amounts of fluid from the body which leads to increased urination.

There can be various reasons which can result in damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland:

Surgery in the area of the pituitary gland or hypothalamus

Infection

Any inflammation

A tumour in or near the pituitary gland

Head injury

Loss of blood supply to the pituitary gland

An inherited defect in the gene that produces vasopressin

In some cases, the cause might be unknown.

Damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland can cause Central Diabetes Insipidus.

2. Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus

In Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus, the response of the kidneys to vasopressin is affected. The kidneys are unable to properly respond to vasopressin due to a defect in the structures of the kidneys. Like central DI, nephrogenic DI is very rare.

The defect may be due to:

In inherited (genetic) nephrogenic DI, the condition results in the kidneys either completely or partially not responding to vasopressin.

In the acquired form of nephrogenic DI, the kidney‚Äôs ability to concentrate urine when water needs to be conserved is also reduced.

Acquired/secondary nephrogenic DI can have various causes, including:

Kidney cysts that may develop due to other conditions such as polycystic kidney disease

Kidney infection

High levels of calcium in the bloodstream

Some cancers

Certain medications, especially lithium or tetracycline

Low potassium levels in the body

Blockage in the urinary tract

3. Dipsogenic Diabetes Insipidus

Dipsogenic diabetes insipidus cause is a defect in the thirst mechanism and is not related to ADH (vasopressin). It occurs when the mechanism that makes you feel thirsty is damaged and you might feel thirsty even when fluid isn‚Äôt needed.

It can be caused by damage to the hypothalamus. The same reasons which might lead to central DI can lead to dipsogenic diabetes insipidus.

It can also be caused due to:

Certain medication

Mental illnesses or mental health problems

4. Gestational Diabetes Insipidus

Gestational Diabetes Insipidus occurs only during the pregnancy period and most pregnant women who develop Gestational DI have a mild case that does not lead to noticeable symptoms. It usually goes away once the mother delivers the baby, however, it can occur again if the mother becomes pregnant again.

In a few cases, it occurs due to an enzyme released by the placenta that degrades vasopressin while in other cases, pregnant women produce more prostaglandin, a hormone-like chemical that reduces the kidney sensitivity to vasopressin.

Do you require an expert‚Äôs guidance for a kidney issue? Zyla can provide that along with personalised treatment. Download the Zyla app now for 24*7 health management.

Now let us take a look at how your healthcare provider will help in Diabetes Insipidus diagnosis.

Diabetes Insipidus Diagnosis

How do you know if you have diabetes insipidus? Your healthcare provider can diagnose it based on the following:

1. Medical and family history

Your healthcare provider can diagnose diabetes insipidus by taking medical and family history, asking to review the symptoms and whether any member in the family has a history of diabetes insipidus or its symptoms.

2. Physical examination

By physical examination, the healthcare provider can diagnose diabetes insipidus by examining the skin, appearance and checking for the signs of dehydration.

3. Urinalysis

A urinalysis test is done to see whether the urine is dilute or concentrated. It also helps in distinguishing between diabetes insipidus and diabetes mellitus if there is the presence of glucose in urine.

The doctor may also ask you to collect urine in a special container over a period of 24 hours to measure the total amount of urine produced by the kidneys for diagnosis.

4. Blood test

A blood test is done to determine the sodium levels in the body which can help diagnose diabetes insipidus and in certain cases help understand the type of DI also.

5. Water deprivation test

Water or fluid deprivation test is a reliable test to help in diabetes insipidus diagnosis. The test has to be performed by a specialist under proper supervision. Your healthcare provider may perform two types of water deprivation tests -

a. Short form of deprivation test

In this test, the patient is instructed to stop drinking all liquids or fluids for a specific period of time, usually during dinner. The next morning, the patient is asked to collect the urine sample at home. A urine sample is given to the lab to measure the concentration of the urine.

b. Formal water deprivation test

This test is performed at the hospital to continuously monitor the patient to check for the signs of dehydration. It involves allowing the patient to become increasingly dehydrated while taking blood and urine samples.

Samples taken during the test are analysed to determine the concentration of urine and blood and measure the levels of electrolytes, especially sodium in the body. Close supervision is done to rule out psychogenic polydipsia, a condition that causes a person to drink large volumes of water habitually.

Under normal conditions, dehydration triggers the secretion of vasopressin leading the kidneys to conserve water and concentrate the urine while in diabetes insipidus, either insufficient vasopressin is released or the kidneys are resistant to the hormone. Testing these dysfunctions will help diagnose and define the type of diabetes insipidus.

6. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

MRIs cannot diagnose diabetes insipidus but will help in checking if there is any problem in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland of the patient. It will also help the health care provider to determine if diabetes insipidus is the possible cause of the patient‚Äôs symptoms.

Symptoms of Diabetes Insipidus

Your body‚Äôs primary responses to dehydration are thirst to increase the water intake and decrease urine output for conserving water loss in the body. This will lead urine to become concentrated and dark yellow in colour.

In adults, symptoms of Diabetes Insipidus include:

Severe thirst

Passing more than 3 litres of urine a day (polyuria)

Waking up a lot during the night to go for urination

Peeing during sleep (bed-wetting)

Pale, colourless urine with a low measured concentration of urine

Weakness

Muscle pains

Crankiness and dehydration

Bed-wetting is one of the symptoms of Diabetes Insipidus.

In infants and children, symptoms of Diabetes Insipidus include:

In infants, you need to watch out for:

Crankiness

Slow growth

Poor feeding

Weight loss

Fever

Vomiting

Infants with hereditary nephrogenic DI may not eat properly and fail to gain weight with slow growth. They may also be irritable experiencing fever, diarrhoea and vomiting causing recurrent episodes of dehydration which leads to slow growth and delayed development in infants.

Diabetes Insipidus diagnosis must be done on time and should be well-managed, as over time it can damage the bladder and kidneys leading to pain, infections and kidney failure. With proper treatment, it can be managed with very few complications and lead to a normal lifespan.

In children, signs include:

Drinking a lot of water

Peeing often, sometimes every hour

New bed-wetting or starting to wake up during the night frequently to pee

Dehydration

Low energy

Get a holistic approach on health and visit Zyla.in or download the Zyla app now.

Diabetes Insipidus complications

If Diabetes Insipidus isn‚Äôt under control or managed properly, it can make you more likely to have these Diabetes Insipidus complications:

1. Dehydration

The major complication of Diabetes Insipidus is dehydration i.e. if water loss is more than the intake. As the level of water loss increases, more symptoms of dehydration can become visible.

You might notice the below symptoms with dehydration:

Extreme thirst

Fatigue

Dizziness

Confusion

Nausea

Loss of consciousness

Dry skin

Sluggishness

Did you know? Severe dehydration can lead to seizures, permanent brain damage and even death. Seek immediate care if there are any symptoms of severe dehydration such as confusion, dizziness or sluggishness. You can prevent dehydration by increasing your water intake throughout the day.

2. Electrolyte imbalance

Electrolytes are minerals in the body with an electric charge. They are present in blood, urine, tissues and other body fluids. When the amount of water changes in your body, the level of electrolytes can become too low or too high.

In Diabetes Insipidus when you lose too much water, your electrolyte levels can go up or low which might cause:

A headache

Feeling tired all the time or fatigue

Irritability

Muscle pain

3. Disturbed sleep

Diabetes Insipidus can lead to nocturia, a condition in which you wake up at night due to frequent urination resulting in a disturbed sleep or a less restful night.

Without medical treatment, other possible complications of Diabetes Insipidus may include:

Low body temperature

Accelerated heart rate

Weight loss and frequent headaches

Low blood pressure (hypotension)

Kidney or brain damage

Diabetes Insipidus treatment

The Diabetes Insipidus treatment primarily is to prevent dehydration by drinking enough fluids. Your health care provider may refer you to a nephrologist for treating kidney problems or an endocrinologist for treating disorders of the hormones.

As Diabetes Insipidus types have different causes, similarly treatment for extreme thirst or frequent urination depends on the type of Diabetes Insipidus.

1. Central Diabetes Insipidus

To treat central DI, a synthetic or man-made hormone called desmopressin in form of injection, nasal spray or pill is given which works by replacing the vasopressin that the body naturally produces and decreases urination.

It helps in managing the symptoms of central DI, however, it does not cure the disease.

2. Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus

In nephrogenic DI, since kidneys don‚Äôt respond to ADH properly, giving desmopressin won‚Äôt help in managing the symptoms. Instead, your doctor may advise a low-salt diet to decrease urine production by the kidneys and increase water intake to prevent dehydration.

Medications for nephrogenic DI include a class of diuretics called thiazides, either given alone or in combination with aspirin or ibuprofen.

Diuretics are commonly prescribed to help patients‚Äô kidneys remove fluid from the body. Instead in nephrogenic DI, diuretics are given to reduce urine production and concentrate urine.

3. Dipsogenic Diabetes Insipidus

No effective dipsogenic Diabetes Insipidus treatment guidelines is yet found by the researchers.

It is advised to try sucking on ice chips or sour candies to keep the mouth moistened and increase the saliva flow, which may help in reducing the desire to drink water.

Taking a small dose of desmopressin at bedtime may help the patients who wake frequently at night to urinate. Your healthcare provider initially may monitor the blood sodium levels to prevent low sodium levels (hyponatremia) in the body.

4. Gestational Diabetes Insipidus

The doctors prescribe desmopressin for pregnant women with gestational diabetes insipidus as the placenta does not destroy desmopressin, unlike vasopressin. After delivery, most of the women will not need any treatment.

Most people with Diabetes Insipidus can prevent serious complications and live a normal life by following the doctor‚Äôs advice and recommendations to keep their symptoms under control.

After delivery, most of the women will not need any treatment for Gestational Diabetes Insipidus.

Lifestyle modifications and dietary changes

Lifestyle modifications play an important role in managing the symptoms of Diabetes Insipidus. The most important part is to prevent dehydration. You can carry a water bottle wherever you go or offer your child to drink water every few hours if they have DI. Your doctor will help you determine your daily fluid intake.

You can carry a medical alert card in your wallet so that others can know about your condition in case of emergency as dehydration can happen quickly and at any time.

Your doctor may advise you to have a low-salt diet and refer to a nutritionist for making a customized diet plan. Reducing caffeine and avoiding processed foods from the diet as these are high in salt can be effective steps to control water retention and consume foods with high water content such as melons.

Diabetes Insipidus is often difficult or impossible to cure as it results either from genetic problems or due to other conditions. However, symptoms can be managed effectively if Diabetes Insipidus diagnosis and treatment is done properly. While it is a lifelong condition, with ongoing treatment, the outlook can be good.

Remember to always have something to drink close by as you will be more prone to dehydration especially if the weather is too hot or when you exercise. Carry your medication with you and avoid situations where you can‚Äôt get water.

To manage your symptoms, get support from a strong healthcare team at Zyla. We work 24x7 to answer your every query in real-time with a team of experts which includes endocrinologists and nutritionists, physiotherapists and psychologists.

You can download the Zyla App and start your health journey today!

title: Deskera Review: All You need to know
text:
Introduction:

Many businesses face problems in Payroll, CRM, invoicing, and accounting in their companies. Are you one of them? Whether large or small, Deskera helps automate your every business process. It is nothing less than a blessing for any business person. It manages bases for large customers in the businesses.

It has got a wide range of facilities to provide you. Moreover, it makes you eligible to remove all your other business management software and shift all of them to Deskera.

Further, it is made for numerous industries such as construction, distribution, building, engineering, manufacturing, trading, and much more. It has its headquarter in Singapore, but, offices of Deskera are widely distributed in the world.

What is Deskera?

Founded in 2008, Deskera is an all-in-one platform for your business management. It serves you as a complete online accounting tool. It keeps safe all of your business‚Äôs accounting, invoicing, Human Resources ( HR ), Payroll, CRM, track bills, etc. It gives you the quickest overview of your entire business. Hence, saving much of your time and making things much easier for you.

Apart from stats, it gives you charts, graphs, and tables to view your business strategies even in better and understandable ways.

Features of Deskera:

It provides many features helping you manage your all business more easily on a single platform. Merged in 4 categories, it has 52 features to serve you with. Some of the features you get with Deskera are mentioned below.

¬∑ Contact Management

¬∑ Stock Management

¬∑ Work order management
