title: Why an accountant holds CTSI
text:
Why an accountant holds CTSI

When an accountant holds CTSI, it‚Äôs time for an interview. Accountants do finance reports, budgets, tax returns, and accounting records. They provide their clients with financial reports that feature present and prospective trends in their financial situation and they have the reputation of being risk-averse. So, I asked him: what is the main reason for an accountant to hold CTSI?

Joe Tang / @joecwtang is a Dutch chartered accountant, specializing in crypto. He started his career in a large and traditional accountancy office, before joining KPMG where he first heard about blockchain and how it potentially could make accounting more efficient. Flashforward to today, Joe is now the co-founder of NEO, a small accountancy firm that offers accountancy, fiscal advice, payroll accounting, and consulting. His business is going so well he‚Äôs not taking any new clients at the moment.

I asked Joe when he started venturing into the crypto space, finding he began his journey in 2017 ‚Äî at the time only wanting to see if blockchain tech could increase efficiency in accounting. In the Netherlands, companies took a hard hit during the 2008 financial crisis and it was not until 2017 that things started to turn upwards. Joe: ‚ÄúDuring this time, companies were unwilling to invest in making their accounting more efficient through innovation ‚Äî they were still recovering from the crisis.‚Äù

It was only recently that Joe began holding crypto of his own. Asking how he determines which projects to support, Joe replies, ‚ÄúWhen it comes to crypto, I never participate in meme coins or dump projects. There must be a strong product or community behind it.‚Äù If there isn‚Äôt? Joe shakes his head, then he simply isn‚Äôt interested. When he first heard about Cartesi, he thought: Linux with blockchain? Cool. ‚ÄúFor me, Linux was the trigger to dive deep into researching Cartesi, CTSI, and getting to know the community supporting the project‚Äù.

‚ÄúConnecting to Linux is potentially big: 99% of all our devices are (in)directly running on Linux. I realized what the future power of Cartesi is.‚Äù @joecwtang

From what he found, Joe is optimistic about Cartesi‚Äôs future, ‚Äúwinning Linux devs over to blockchain won‚Äôt happen overnight but I‚Äôm doing it for the long term.‚Äù Currently, Joe‚Äôs staking in a pool with Noether‚Äôs Delegated Staking to help secure the network and earn rewards on his CTSI. Having only recently launched staking on Mainnet at the time of this interview, it was great to hear him getting involved in staking CTSI with us.

He doesn‚Äôt use his CTSI for payment: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize you can pay with CTSI until I heard of Travala accepting CTSI. But I do prefer payments with fiat money because that loses value.‚Äù

In the Netherlands, lessons have been learned from the financial crisis and monetary policies are well-arranged, with built-in buffers overseeing the borrowing of money. But for Joe, it‚Äôs just another way to continue to print money. Global monetary policy, how money is being printed and inflation rates are subjects Joe thinks the government needs to take action against. Asking him for some final words to share with our community, or anyone who might be interested in venturing into crypto, Joe has this to say:

‚ÄúI never give investment advice, but I do share sometimes my experience. I say to customers who keep their money in the bank: do something with your money, anything is better than a savings account.‚Äù @joecwtang

Want to hear more from Joe? Follow him on Twitter:

If you enjoyed getting to know why different people hold CTSI, stay tuned for more in our series! We‚Äôre shining the spotlight on our community, chatting to everyone from futurists to independent business owners on what attracted them to Cartesi and why they‚Äôre holding CTSI.

title: 3 Features of ADHD-Friendly Organizational Systems
text:
What works for an ADHD brain often isn‚Äôt the same as what works for everyone else. If you have ADHD and try to follow common advice about staying organized, you might get frustrated.

Instead, below are 3 tips that I‚Äôve found to be especially helpful for ADHD. You can use these 3 features to make effective systems that help you stay on track toward your goals.

1. Visual Cues

Out of sight, out of mind. . . if I don‚Äôt see something, it‚Äôs unlikely I will think to do it. Creating an environment that visually prompts me to do things helps me follow through on commitments. Trying a new planner or an app that won‚Äôt be seen, and perhaps even avoided if it‚Äôs not easy and fun enough, isn‚Äôt likely to help me. Instead, there are many visual cues that can already naturally fit into daily life ‚Äî colorful post-its, whiteboard calendars, keys by the door. Instead of relying on ignorable tools or your mind to remember things, consider setting up the current environment with visual reminders.

This post-it reminds me to bring my lunch in the fridge to work.

2. Social Commitments

Often, it can be easier to do things for others than for ourselves. When I‚Äôve told someone else what I plan to do, I‚Äôm more likely to follow through. As the deadline looms, I feel the internal pressure to be true to my word. For example, let‚Äôs say I have a task to do. If I put it on my calendar, it may or may not happen ‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs not fun and there‚Äôs no real accountability to finish it on certain timeline. However, if I schedule a meeting with my coach, I‚Äôm much more likely to work on my stated goals before the meeting. Similarly, if I have a project at work I could preemptively schedule a meeting with my colleague for the end of the week, which will motivate me to make progress more than if I had just put my own arbitrary deadline.

I schedule social commitments in my Google calendar.

3. Natural Consequences

I like to think that I‚Äôll do things for myself that feel good, like keep an exercise routine or see friends. But when it comes down to it, my favorite thing to do is . . . nothing. Mmm. Positive rewards hardly work ‚Äî ‚ÄúGo exercise, you‚Äôll be healthy! Go exercise, it will feel good!‚Äù Instead, I‚Äôve found it more motivating to avoid pain. Pain, in this case, can be either a social consequence or a direct consequence. For example, if I notice the gas in my car is empty, I won‚Äôt procrastinate: I am going to fill it up before I go home because I don‚Äôt want to be stranded and I don‚Äôt want to be late to my next appointment. As another example, if I‚Äôm going to the coffee shop to work, I might not bring my laptop charger. That way, I‚Äôll have a natural time limit, and I‚Äôll feel motivated to use my limited battery life efficiently on the work I intend to complete. Often it‚Äôs extreme realities and actual consequences that motivate behavior change. If there‚Äôs no real consequence, then I‚Äôll follow my inspiration in the moment and the task may or may not get done.

title: Easy-to-follow move-out cleaning checklist
text:
Easy-to-follow move-out cleaning checklist

Before you start, remove all personal belongings. We recommend you pack up as much as possible before starting the clean-up. This allows you to dust off surfaces more easily, and also makes it easier to clean your old books and other effects scattered in the cabinets all together.

We recommend you pack up as much as possible before starting the clean-up. This allows you to dust off surfaces more easily, and also makes it easier to clean your old books and other effects scattered in the cabinets all together. Have the right tools ready . A comprehensive cleaning supplies list could get quite long, but includes rubber gloves, microfiber cloths, mop, bucket, sponge, vacuum and duster, along with windex, all purpose cleaner, disinfectant wipes, bleach, oven cleaner and more!

. A comprehensive cleaning supplies list could get quite long, but includes rubber gloves, microfiber cloths, mop, bucket, sponge, vacuum and duster, along with windex, all purpose cleaner, disinfectant wipes, bleach, oven cleaner and more! Vacuum and mop floors last. Save this one for last as dust and chemicals will have likely fallen while cleaning elsewhere. Remind your roommates not to walk on the floor until it is completely dry, and keep pets in another room.

Save this one for last as dust and chemicals will have likely fallen while cleaning elsewhere. Remind your roommates not to walk on the floor until it is completely dry, and keep pets in another room. If you have a house or townhouse rental, pay attention to the landscaping (don‚Äôt forget about your children‚Äôs toys, cigarette butts, patio furniture, etc.), garage (often neglected because it‚Äôs not an indoor space, but ends up getting dirty as it‚Äôs often used for storage along with mess caused by vehicles, children or pets) and laundry room (if you have a washer and dryer in your unit, you‚Äôll want to make sure any lint or detergent spills are removed).

to the landscaping (don‚Äôt forget about your children‚Äôs toys, cigarette butts, patio furniture, etc.), garage (often neglected because it‚Äôs not an indoor space, but ends up getting dirty as it‚Äôs often used for storage along with mess caused by vehicles, children or pets) and laundry room (if you have a washer and dryer in your unit, you‚Äôll want to make sure any lint or detergent spills are removed). Make a difference with smell! A place that smells good will immediately make any guest, including your landlord, feel comfortable. It also gives them the assurance that your home has been well maintained or at least given a good scrub very recently.

Get those gloves and spray bottles out and let‚Äôs get your place cleaned up! Photo by Towfiqu barbhuiya.

Things you need to do in every room:

Clear cobwebs from ceiling.

Clean closet exteriors and interiors.

Dust light fixtures, fan blades, window blinds, HVAC vents, and don‚Äôt forget the corners of rooms. Use the brush attachment on your vacuum to remove any dust lingering on your baseboards or trim, and wipe them down.

Sweep & vacuum floors, carpets, windowsills and screens, and then mop. For carpets, remove them by applying commercial carpet cleaner and letting it sit for a few minutes. Use a microfiber cloth to blot the stain away. Some common carpet stains require a specific solution for removing, so be sure to use the right product for your apartment carpet cleaning.

Use a window or glass cleaner to wash your windows. Simply spray the solution onto the window and wipe quickly with a lint-free cloth to avoid streaks (here‚Äôs a pro tip: use a newspaper if you don‚Äôt have a lint-free cloth). Make sure to dust off the handles, locks, and between the sliding tracks if your windows have them.

If you have stains on your walls, grab a microfiber cloth and wash the walls using an appropriate cleaner for the paint finish.

Remove nails, pins, and tacks from walls. Based on the size of holes in your walls, you may be asked to restore them by filling in and painting over them. This is a must do after you take out your wall-mounted TV! Use commercial putty and paint in the same color as your wall (sometimes your landlord will provide this) to restore it to its original state. Be sure to use a putty knife to properly apply the product.

Check lights and wipe light switches. Your lease may require you to replace any light bulbs that may have gone out.

And don‚Äôt forget to empty the garbage!

Kitchen Tasks:

Clean countertops, backsplashes and kitchen appliances, beneath, inside and out. Wipe down the microwave and the insides of the fridge and freezer, removing any remaining food still in there.

Move your stove. You‚Äôd be surprised to find out how much food has been rotting between your stove and cabinets! Give the stove top a good scrub and wipe. Remove burned-on food from your burners with readily available kits like Weiman Glass Cook Top Cleaning Kit. Don‚Äôt forget to clean the oven. Most modern ovens have a self-clean mode so give that a round or two.

It may seem unintuitive, but the dishwasher will also need a clean. Use a sanitizing wipe to rid your dishwasher‚Äôs door of any soap scum and hard water spots. Then follow our handy dishwasher cleaning guide to learn how to scrub the accessories and tub.

Clean the hood fan filter. This may take a while and may require some very strong chemicals since it‚Äôs been gathering grease for a while so it requires a lot of effort to clean it. If you aren‚Äôt able to purchase something for it, place it in some hot water, add dish soap, and leave it soaking overnight. The next day, it should be a lot easier to scrub off the grease.

Empty and clean the insides of cabinets. Look out for any baskets, seasoning spills. Remove any shelf liners and wipe down the shelves with a damp cloth. You can also save time by using the brush attachment on your vacuum to suck up any crumbs in a snap.

This is a clean kitchen. Try to leave your kitchen (almost) looking like this! Photo by Becca Tapert.

The most important part, bathrooms:

Scrub the toilets. Visible toilet rings are a definite no-no when it comes time to move out. Get rid of them by using an all-purpose bowl cleaner. Once you‚Äôve finished scrubbing the toilet bowl, wipe down both sides of the seat and the tank with a bleach-based cleaning spray. Be sure to open a window or turn on your bathroom fan when cleaning with bleach.

Scrub the shower and bathtub for scum and hard water spots. Get rid of buildup and mold, and don‚Äôt forget to clean under shampoo and conditioner bottles, where soap scum builds up fast. Clean the shower curtain (if applicable).

Don‚Äôt forget to give the mirror, sink, and countertops a good wipe.

Dust and wipe the bathroom fan. If you don‚Äôt have access to the circuit breaker, use a stepladder and a can of air to dust off your exhaust fan. For a more thorough clean, remove the cover and dust the interior.

If you know you don‚Äôt have enough time to thoroughly clean or are too lazy to, hire your local cleaners as many of them already offer move-out cleaning services. With all the stress of moving, this minor luxury could go a long way. We recommend, however, you call in advance during summer months as many people choose to do their moving around then.

title: The Complete Robot Vacuum Cleaners Buying Guide
text:
A robot vacuum cleaner is a great house keeper to your home as it can complete day-to-day cleaning tasks without you having to pick up a vac yourself, saving your time and energy both. Plus, if you‚Äôre short on space, thanks to its compact size, it won‚Äôt occupy much room in your home.

If you‚Äôre brand new to robot vacuum cleaners, you might be overwhelmed by the number of features and models available. Before you jump the gun and going to buy the first model you can find, ask yourself: what do I really need?

This comprehensive robot vacuum buying guide is intended to provide you with all the information you need to make a wise and informed choice.

To get started, ask yourself these questions first:

How big is your house? Do you have carpets or hardwood? Do you have any budget limits? How often do you clean your floor? Do you mind water stains after mopping the floor? Will you need the robot vacuum to clean your house while you‚Äôre away? Do you live in an apartment complex where excessive noise might disturb your neighbors? Do you want your robot cleaner to have both vacuum and mop features? Would you prefer a robot vacuum that can clean every corner of your house?

Now that you have brainstormed and prepared this initial information, it‚Äôs time to understand more about this product and the options available.

Why should you get a robot vacuum cleaner?

A robot vacuum keeps things relatively clean and saves you the hassle of hauling out the heavy canister vacuum every time bread crumbs fall on the floor. Robot vacuums are great for daily tidying ‚Äî picking up stray crumbs, hair of all types, dust bunnies and everything else that finds its way onto your floors.

Many robot vacuums can be scheduled to run as often as multiple times a day, and some app-enabled robots allow you to watch their progress as they clean. If you‚Äôre concerned about allergies, Narwal‚Äôs product is designed with HEPA Filter, which can prevent allergies.

What are the benefits of a robot vacuum cleaner over upright vacuumer?

If you‚Äôre considering bringing a robot vacuum cleaner into your home but aren‚Äôt sure whether to take the leap, here are some of the benefits of these autonomous little cleaners.

Time-saving: one of the best aspects of a robot vacuum cleaner is the fact that it cleans your home all by itself. A robot vacuum cleaner saves you valuable time and leaves you one less chore to do yourself.

one of the best aspects of a robot vacuum cleaner is the fact that it cleans your home all by itself. A robot vacuum cleaner saves you valuable time and leaves you one less chore to do yourself. Cleans while you‚Äôre out: you can program the robot to run on specific days and at specific times. You can also schedule cleaning for when you‚Äôre at work and enjoy the feeling of coming home to a clean house.

you can program the robot to run on specific days and at specific times. You can also schedule cleaning for when you‚Äôre at work and enjoy the feeling of coming home to a clean house. Better reach: thanks to their small size, robots can get under heavy furniture that you wouldn‚Äôt usually be able to clean yourself.

thanks to their small size, robots can get under heavy furniture that you wouldn‚Äôt usually be able to clean yourself. Vacuum and mopping: many of the newer robot cleaners are dual functions, with mopping capabilities as well as vacuuming. In addition, Narwal solution has an innovative self-cleaning function. The base station auto-detects mops‚Äô dirtiness and wipes out the dirt. Then, the dirt gets stored in a separate tank to be dropped.

many of the newer robot cleaners are dual functions, with mopping capabilities as well as vacuuming. In addition, Narwal solution has an innovative self-cleaning function. The base station auto-detects mops‚Äô dirtiness and wipes out the dirt. Then, the dirt gets stored in a separate tank to be dropped. Space-saving: the compact and minimalistic design means robot cleaners take up much less space in your home than a traditional vacuum cleaner. Actually, Narwal‚Äôs high-tech design makes them a spotlight in your house.

the compact and minimalistic design means robot cleaners take up much less space in your home than a traditional vacuum cleaner. Actually, Narwal‚Äôs high-tech design makes them a spotlight in your house. APP control: You can operate and control the robot vacuum through a smartphone app. At your fingertips, you can set virtual no-go zones and choose multiple scenarios and cleaning plans.

What to look for in a robot vacuum cleaner?

While using a robot vacuum is easy enough, shopping for one can be overwhelming. Here are the main aspects to look for when considering which one to buy.

Size:

The dimensions of a robot vacuum cleaner determine how well it can get into tight spots, such as under your kitchen cabinets and low-clearance furniture (couches and recliners). If it‚Äôs too tall, it won‚Äôt be able to reach into these spots, or worse, it will get in and get stuck until you physically free it. Besides, the bigger robot vacuum, the larger dustbin. Robot vacuums don‚Äôt use expandable bags like many of their stand-up brethren do, so when it comes to debris capacity, what you see is what you get.

Cleaning modules:

Most robot vacuum cleaners feature the ability to change suction and other cleaning functions to adapt to different floor surfaces, either automatically or with input from you. As for Narwal, you can adjust its suction power and the humidity of the mopping pad through the app.

Filter:

The filter captures small particles and incisible allergens efficiently.

Navigation:

The allure of robot vacuums is their promise to complete their task with minimal management from you. In order to do that, they must be able to navigate a room‚Äôs unique layout, maneuver around furniture and other obstacles, and avoid hazards such as falling downstairs and smart-avoiding obstacles.

Mapping:

Robot vacuums with mapping capabilities usually come equipped with an onboard camera or laser reflections to produce a 360-degree view of the room. This allows the robot vac to create a map of the space and locate itself within that map. When the robot maps a house for the first time, speed and accuracy are two key points. The advantage of mapping is the robot will know which areas it has already cleaned and which it hasn‚Äôt, to avoid going over the same spot unnecessarily. This feature also reminds it from where to resume cleaning if it must stop and recharge on the midway through the task.

Extra features:

The ‚ÄúChild Lock‚Äù feature can protect your child‚Äôs safety. This function was designed to help prevent children from getting hurt while improperly using the robot.

Robot cleaner daily cleaning tips

Using a robot vacuum cleaner is usually a pretty straightforward task, but you can help it perform better with these easy tips:

1. Tidy up

Even the most hi-tech sensors can‚Äôt navigate around piles of Lego or dirty laundry, so to give the vacuum the best chance of success, have a quick tidy before you leave.

2. Use the timers

Robot vacuums work best if they clean every day. Learn how to use the schedule and set it to clean when you know you‚Äôll be out of the house.

3. Place the Base station in a good location

The Base station should be placed against a wall with enough space on either side of the station and open space in front of it. The open space allows the robot to properly orient itself when it‚Äôs sent on a cleaning run and helps it find its way home.

4. Stay home for your robot vacuum‚Äôs first 3‚Äì5 runs

Many homes have hot spots ‚Äî a weird door jamb, a lumpy rug ‚Äî where you will need to rescue your vac. Do a quick run-through beforehand for robot booby traps, like ribbons and pieces of string.

Narwal robot maintaining tips

Robot vacuums will do most of the hard work while you do something else. But even smart vacuums need maintenance to keep them performing at their best. Here are some tips on how to make the most out of your robot vacuum cleaner for longer:

1. Empty the dustbinand wastewater tanks

Depending on how dirty your home is, you will want to empty your robot vacuum‚Äôs dustbin after every use. If you run your robot vacuum daily and don‚Äôt have pets, you should empty the dustbin at least once a week. In addition, the water tanks also need cleaning.

2. Clean the filter and dustbin

Cleaning the filter is important because the vacuum doesn‚Äôt clean as well when the filter is dirty. You can clean most models‚Äô filters and dustbins with water. Each week, you can clean and thoroughly dry the dustbin while letting the filter air dry. Make sure the filter and dustbin dry completely before you use them again.

3. Clean front wheel, brushes, sensors, and charging contacts

You should do this every two to four weeks. Most robot vacuums come with a cleaning tool with a brush on one end and a cutting blade on the other. Use these to cut out hairs that are wrapped around the brushes and wheel and brush away debris. You can also use a soft dry cloth to dust the sensors and charging contacts of your robot vacuum cleaner.

Follow these tips and you‚Äôll be prolonging the lifespan of your robot vacuum cleaner. If these are not enough, we have gathered other useful suggestions for you:

Shake off the filter every few sessions and replace it every few dozen sessions

Clean the bearings on the caster, and side brushes every few weeks

Replace filters and side brushes a few times per year, the mopping padsabout once a year, and the battery as needed ‚Äî probably every second year, though that depends on how often you use the robot vacuum cleaner

To Wrap it Up

Vacuuming is one of the most loathed household chores. Robot vacuums don‚Äôt have unwieldy cords or hoses to contend with, and they require little effort from you: You can run one from your couch using a smartphone app, and the higher-end models can be programmed to wake up and start cleaning without any intervention at all. Robot vacuums also easily dispose of the most common household debris ‚Äî including food crumbs, pet hair, dust ‚Äî making them ideal for routine maintenance and quick cleanings when you‚Äôre expecting a guest.

Narwal vacuum robot has a white minimalist design and operates quietly. The noise level is 45 dB when you mopping the floor and 60 dB when vacuuming. In addition, our product also offers self-cleaning, fast charging, strong suction, and APP control.

Check out here to know more about the product!

title: 4 Easy Steps To Learn Sinhala Language Online
text:
4 Easy Steps To Learn Sinhala Language Online

Sinhala is the most spoken language in Sri Lanka. If you are a tourist or a student or a language learner, these 4 steps will be very effective to learn Sinhala easier anywhere you are lived. So, here are 4 steps to learn the Sinhala language free online.

Step 1: Learn the basics of Sinhala

Not only for Sinhala, if you learning any language, but you must also know the basics of that language. If you are an advanced language learner, I suggest you study the alphabet and grammar parts of Sinhala. If you want to speak day to day using words, I recommend you to use Google Translate and practice pronunciation. I list some weblinks to go to learning basics.

Steps 2: Watch movies with Sinhala subtitles

Image from IMDB

While learning basics, you can find out more words and phrases from movies. It is a very interesting task and you can note down unknown Sinhala words and improve your Sinhala vocabulary. I link out several popular Sinhala subtitles websites to download for your favorite movie Sinhala subtitles.

Step 3: Listen to Sinhala Podcasts

Image from Sinhala Podcast (anchor.fm/owshangi-gayana-senanayaka)

This is a nice way to familiarize yourself with the Sinhala language. You can listen to Sri Lankan native accents and differences between Sinhala speakers. And also, hearing Sinhala radio conversations and watching Sinhala YouTube videos is a very effective way to improve your ear for the Sinhala language.

Step 4: Practise With Sinhala Speakers

OK, next step 4, the next effective step is practicing the Sinhala language with others. So, how can you practice alone without a Sinhala speaker??

You can learn via the Tandem app. What is Tandem app?

Image from tandem.net

Tandem is a language exchange app that millions of learners exchange their native or learned language with similar learners freely. It is a nice platform for sharing opinions with each other and learning languages by calling and chatting. There are so many Sinhala learners and partners are here. You can signup for Tandem via Android or IOS devices. And also, you can find a partner and do your language learning perfectly from there.

Pros

Free

Any Language

Cons

The signup process may go several days

Try these steps again and again. If you think these steps are very valuable, feel free to share this with others.

title: Learning a New Language is as Simple as Picking Up a New Habit
text:
I can already hear you saying it: ‚ÄúYou must be joking. It‚Äôs not that easy‚Ä¶ More like overwhelmingly tough. Maybe impossible.‚Äù

You‚Äôll point out the thousands of vocabulary words, the new logic required to understand and apply new grammar rules, the endless conjugations and declensions of so many of our world‚Äôs languages.

And some of you might even be saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a language person. That‚Äôs just a fact.‚Äù

I assure you, you‚Äôre mistaken. It‚Äôs entirely possible and it‚Äôs only as difficult as our imaginations make it out to be. At least once we adapt a bit to how to learn a language. And since you‚Äôre reading this now, you are necessarily a language person. All human beings are language people: that‚Äôs how we communicate after all! That‚Äôs how we survive.

Language is what separates human beings from other animals. If we weren‚Äôt all language people, we wouldn‚Äôt be the apex predator over all other life on Earth.

So then, how does one learn a whole new language? It‚Äôs a big question, I know.

But a language is just a set of habits‚Äã. Bare with me.

Have you ever changed a habit? Have you ever decided to eat healthier, to stop saying some word, to start brushing your teeth differently? Really, any new kind of habit will work for our purposes now.

My guess is that yes, indeed you have at some point in your life changed a habit. Moreover, I would even wager you have changed many habits throughout your life. This is how we grow!

If you are capable of changing your habits, then you are capable of learning a language.

At its core, that‚Äôs all language really is. When you say the word ‚Äúoh,‚Äù a native or proficient speaker of American English doesn‚Äôt need to think. They simply know to open the mouth, round the lips, widen and round the throat, vibrate the vocal chords and then end with an incomplete closure of the lips. In phonetics, this is because that sound is the two-part vowel (also known as a diphthong) /o ä/.

And as a new speaker of a language, those sorts of oral manipulations seem complicated. Maybe they are. But once you‚Äôre used to moving your mouth that way, it becomes second nature.

One advantage for us, though? Changing a habit is much harder than picking up a new one. So here already, we know that if a language is a new set of habits, it demands the same effort applied to create a new habit in our day-to-day lives.

Let‚Äôs dive deeper into what I mean by, ‚Äúlanguage is a set of habits.‚Äù

First, as we learned above, we have the habits of our mouths and tongues: how we move them to make a sound, how we round or stretch our lips, how we tense or relax our throat, and so on. We do this seemingly by instinct. But in fact, these are habitual patterns like any other you might‚Äôve acquired from your parents or peers in the first 15 or so years of life.

Then we have logical and grammatical patterns. These patterns are again, simple habitual actions that we acquired from the people we surrounded ourselves with when we were still maturing.

Habit change is a major feature of adaptation: the evolutionary process which allows an organism to live despite changes in its optimal environment or situation.

So now we know that a language is just one, big habit. We just adapt, right? Simple.

Well sadly, I think 2020 made it pretty clear that life is never that easy. At least with learning a new language, we can dispose of the existential fear and simply focus on the material!

Next, we need to understand a little about the brain.

‚Äã

I‚Äôm not going to bore you with learning about the various parts of the brain, nor if consciousness can be explained through quantum physics.

Nah, all we need to know is how our brains ‚Äî our minds ‚Äî react to change.

In short, when our brain is forced to change, it starts to lash out. Like a child who‚Äôs been told they (ESL students: See they, singular, gender neutral pronoun) can‚Äôt have ice cream. Our brain ‚Äî the wonderfully evolved and endlessly complex thing it is ‚Äî essentially acts like a child when it doesn‚Äôt get its way.

And the way the brain likes it? In short: never, ever change!

In cognitive psychology over the decades, we‚Äôve learned that when a human being tries to change one of their habits, their brain responds by producing unpleasant or difficult feelings. It yells at us saying, ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt right.‚Äù It tries its best to convince us of this ‚Äúfact‚Äù by providing difficult emotional feedback.

Why? Because change and adaptation require energy, and for the people of pre-technological civilizations (as well as those living in extreme poverty today), energy wasn‚Äôt always an easy thing to maintain. The more energy expended, the more food we needed, and the higher the chances we would die from the lack of it. Our brain ‚Äî and our body as a whole ‚Äî is very against any sort of energetic waste.

Without these neurological systems, the hundreds of millions of those who live in extreme poverty today would not survive.

Additionally, once we finally adapt to a new situation, the brain concretely considers this situation ‚Äúsafe.‚Äù But because change means facing the unknown, the brain instinctively labels any ‚Äústrange‚Äù situation as ‚Äúunsafe.‚Äù So it stays the same or it starts the process of adaptation. That‚Äôs the point where we deny its comfortable emotional safety but assure it that we will be OK!

That makes two reasons (among many) that we experience these difficulties in learning anything ‚Äî especially a new language.

Indeed, the brain never has grown beyond its childhood tantrums. Even if you‚Äôve managed to reign those in on the outside. On the inside, it‚Äôs always going to be bossy and forceful. But don‚Äôt think of it as puerile or spoiled. It‚Äôs just afraid.

And what‚Äôs the brain‚Äôs main job? Keeping us alive. Keeping us safe. That‚Äôs the purpose of fear.

So don‚Äôt judge your brain! It loves you! The only reason it reacts this way is to keep you breathing. Our DNA has programmed our neurology to think that the unknown means danger, and since change means facing the unknown, change equals danger.

Let‚Äôs not take that for granted, though. This mechanism is critical to our survival, even today.

And in case you were wondering, this internal resistance to change is lovingly referred to as cognitive dissonance.

The fun doesn‚Äôt stop there, though.

When we learn, the brain physically changes in structure. In my simplistic understanding of the subject: basically, the folds in our brain are where information is stored and the way that information is transferred among the various parts of the brain. When we need to access specific information often, the folds create a smooth pathway to and from the proper places in order to access and utilize it with efficiency.

So when we are learning a whole new language, the brain is forced to not only learn new facts, but also to create new pathways in order to access those things in the most energy-efficient way possible. If only our own technology were a little more like our bodies, right? Maybe we could avoid issues like the inevitable disaster of climate change and the greed-fueled wars over oil.

Digressing once again, those neural pathways which are already present and easy to use are also collectively named the default mode network. Our brain loves this network as this is where it feels safe and comfy. But that‚Äôs also what sets the scene for dissonances. So if something new comes into our awareness, the brain throws a tantrum and on and on we go!

For this reason and try as we might, in the beginning of our language journey, it‚Äôs downright impossible to speak with ease or to understand other speakers, even at normal speeds. That language either has no pathway to use, or the pathway is very, very rough. Eek! Inefficient and incomplete. Dissonance party! Cue the inability to express ourselves in the new language. And that inability goes beyond simple cognitive dissonance: it‚Äôs a physical limitation that only practice can overcome. Those pathways must physically be constructed and the only way to do that is practice.

All right then. Now we know there‚Äôs an emotional component and a physical component of why language learning can be difficult.

So back to habits.

As we learned, the sounds of a language are all just a set of routine behaviors. The grammar, the structures, the forms, the patterns, the rhythm, the writing, the spelling, the idiomatic expressions, and so on and so forth: they‚Äôre all habits.

So, how do we change a habit? Practice and believe!

Yes, that‚Äôs really all there is to it! You just need to practice regularly to create new pathways and overcome the resulting cognitive dissonance.

Remember, dissonance has a lot to do with feelings of safety. As a result, simply convincing your brain of the following things will drastically simplify the process for us:

Required beliefs for pacifying the angry, dissonant brain: 1. You are safe. 2. You aren‚Äôt wasting energy. and

‚Äã

3. You need this skill.

I know, it‚Äôs yet another list of rote learning. Most of us aren‚Äôt a fan ‚Äî even those who do consider ourselves ‚Äúlanguage people!‚Äù Making ourselves believe something is totally possible, though so don‚Äôt stress.

It‚Äôs all about repetition. The more you do it, the easier it becomes. Repetition sends the signal to your brain that this skill is necessary and as such, the mind starts chilling out a little. The tantrums calm down in intensity and frequency until one day, your brain barely has them at all!

We‚Äôve got some basics of habits, we‚Äôve got cognitive psychology, and even a little bit of neurology thrown in to spice things up. Let‚Äôs add some traditional Eastern wisdom, verified by science. This basic mindfulness practice will help ease the headache and give your brain more than a fighting chance. Again, this is really simple.

When you feel the dissonance, you must accept the associated emotions and then challenge the ideas they‚Äôre trying to reinforce.

If you try to deny the feeling of ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt right,‚Äù then you will only encourage more of the same feeling, and that may make the problem worse. So the first step is to fully acknowledge and accept the feeling for what it is: a feeling. No more, no less. And feelings alone pose no real threat to your existence.

Dive deep into those sensations (or any others). Feel to the finer details. At first, you can try labeling them in a calm, warm voice in your head: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs anxiety,‚Äù ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a headache,‚Äù ‚Äúthere‚Äôs happiness,‚Äù and so on. Pleasant or not, let that voice treat them exactly the same ‚Äî with equanimity.

Experiment with going deeper into specific sensations ‚Äî again both pleasant and unpleasant. Go from sensing its existence to being curious about the finer details of it: where is it? Is the sensation moving? Is it intense or light? Is it connected to another part of the body? Notice the texture of the sensation. A sensation detective, you should get as curious as you can without forcing anything. But remember: equanimity is key.

Yes, sometimes feelings get in the way of us achieving our goals. However, the more we learn to accept and feel our every sensation fully, the more those same feelings that get in the way become less important and eventually fade away, leaving room for more pleasant and less burdensome emotions in the future.

But that doesn‚Äôt mean you will be accepting this feeling as a way to define your reality or the facts of a given situation! On the contrary, you will simultaneously accept the feeling as simply that ‚Äî a feeling, nothing less and nothing more ‚Äî and you will challenge the belief (‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do this‚Äù) with a new one. That is: you replace the old, self-defeating belief with one that helps you. Even if that, too causes dissonance.

For example, you could use this script when you feel the brain starting to throw a dissonance tantrum:

Hello there, dissonance. Welcome. You are totally free to visit. You don‚Äôt define my reality, even though you are here to keep me safe. I appreciate you for that, but I can learn a language and I am going to continue to practice. I know that, even if I don‚Äôt believe it in my heart at this very moment, I am totally capable and I have all the necessary skills to be successful at learning this new language. I am completely safe, and I know it‚Äôs worth the time and energy engaging myself in this task.

‚ÄãNow, maybe this sort of phrasing isn‚Äôt right for you. That‚Äôs okay! Whatever works! As long as you‚Äôre accepting the feeling for what it is, and challenging the belief that stems from that feeling and making sure you‚Äôre using compassion rather than scorn when giving it attention, you‚Äôre good to go. Each time you do this, repeat the above quote (or your own version). It‚Äôs okay if you don‚Äôt truly believe it immediately. Repetition will lead to belief.

All it takes to believe something is to insist on thinking it! My French students of the English language call this la m√©thode cou√© and, according to Wikipedia, it‚Äôs called ‚Äúautosuggestion‚Äù in English.

Some of you may ask, ‚ÄúBut what if I‚Äôm just too embarrassed to speak?‚Äù My suggestion remains the same. Feel that feeling, identify it compassionately. Then ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhere is this feeling coming from? What thought or belief is bringing this emotion to the surface?‚Äù

Maybe you‚Äôll think, ‚ÄúI know how I see people who speak my language badly sometimes. It‚Äôs just natural. We associate low-level language skills with children. So I know people are going to look at me sideways and sometimes will totally misunderstand me. It could lead to a bad situation. What if I offend someone? I‚Äôll be so embarrassed!‚Äù

Anything can happen! The ceiling could come crumbling down upon you right now. Just replace those thoughts with, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident with my language skills. I‚Äôm doing my very best at the present moment, and I can only improve from here. Anyone who judges me probably doesn‚Äôt speak another language and has no place around me. Their judgements are meaningless because I know who I am and how smart I really am.‚Äù

Or something like that.

Regardless, making mistakes is imperative to learning anything. I call these formative errors.

As an aside, the key difference between the aforementioned method and what I‚Äôm describing in this post is that for us, the practice of emotional willingness via mindfulness is critical in keeping the emotions from becoming blockages in your learning and practice. Mindfulness isn‚Äôt just beneficial for learning a new language, but for pretty much everything in your life. For now, you can just look at the numerous pieces of research on the topic.

In summary: notice those feelings and then feel‚Äã them intentionally then once you‚Äôre centered enough, identify and change the thoughts and beliefs that cause them. Allow yourself time and practice with these skills, just like any other.

English: The most important thing is how you see yourself.

With these small changes in your thinking and behavior, you will make remarkable strides in your learning. At first, these changes will be subtle. But trust me, they will occur. Persist even when you don‚Äôt see any new skills developing. The brain will play cat-and-mouse with you sometimes. Don‚Äôt let it psych you out. Sometimes it takes longer for it to ‚Äúget into the mode,‚Äù of learning a language than it does for other things. But it will click one day as long as you don‚Äôt give up. When it does, you‚Äôll see the world in a whole new and exciting way.

Just one more thing: sleep is essential for the process of creating new neurological pathways and creating long-term memories. So make sure you‚Äôre getting enough sleep!

Awesome! Now you‚Äôre ready to continue your journey. Go forth and create your own confidence in your target language!

Oh and by the way: congrats! Reading this article counts as one step of the learning process you can check off your list! Look at you. Already a step forward. Boom.

title: 5 Amazing Doable Tips to do Effective and Competitive Workout for Mental Health
text:
How workout affects both your body and mind.

We already have an awareness that workout is essential for our body. But did you know it is also essential for our mental health, assisting to cope with depression, anxiety, stress, boosting our mood, and more?

Workout is not just about good-looking and muscle size. Undeniable, exercise can enhance your physique, physical appearance and even to some extent augment years of your life. Nevertheless, this doesn‚Äôt inspire most of the people to have associated.

Therefore, let`s speak about the apex five intellectual advantages of keeping fit.

Workout and Stress

That moment your physical body feels when you are under stress. Your face clearly depicts the situations what you‚Äôre going through. The stress doesn‚Äôt stop there; it creates insomnia, heartburn, diarrhea, or frequent urination. The worry and discomfort of all these physical symptoms can in turn lead to even more stress, creating a vicious cycle between your mind and body.

The best way to deal with all these uncanny symptoms is to do work out on a daily basis. Physical activity helps to relax the muscles and relieve tension in the body. The connection between the body and mind are so close, when your body feels better so, too, will your mind does.

Workout and Depression

Studies have shown that workout impacts on mind without any side effects, in terms of depression more effectively than anti-depression does. Recent research done by the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health has shown that walking for 15 minutes a day or for an hour reduces the risk of major depression. Moreover; letting go of depression symptoms working out on schedule can prevent you from deteriorating.

Exercise is a powerful depression fighter for several reasons. Most importantly, it promotes all kinds of changes in the brain, including neural growth, reduced inflammation, and new activity patterns that promote feelings of calm and well-being. It also releases endorphins, powerful chemicals in your brain that energize your spirits and make you feel good. Finally, exercise can also serve as a distraction, allowing you to find some quiet time to break out of the cycle of negative thoughts that feed depression.

Workout and Anxiety

The only viable way to tackle down anxiety is doing physical practice. It eases pressure and stress, helps physical and mental energy, and upgrades prosperity through the onset of endorphins. Whatever gets you going can help; however, you‚Äôll get a greater advantage if you pay attention instead of daydreaming.

Attempt to see the vibe of your feet hitting the ground, for instance, or the musicality of your breathing, or the sensation of the breeze on your skin. In addition to this attentiveness element; truly concentrating on your body and how it feels when you work out, you‚Äôll only not elevate your physical appearance faster, yet you may likewise have the option to interfere with the progression of steady concerns going through your mind.

Workout and ADHD

Practicing routinely is one of the least demanding and best ways of diminishing the side effects of ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) and further develops focus, inspiration, memory, and disposition. Actual work quickly supports the brain‚Äôs dopamine, norepinephrine (a substance that sends signals between nerve cells), and serotonin levels (the key hormone that stabilizes our mood, feelings of well-being, and happiness) ‚Äî all of which influence concentration and consideration. Thusly, practice works similarly to ADHD prescriptions like Ritalin and Adderall.

Workout and PTSD and Trauma

Proof proposes that by truly concentrating on your body and how it feels as you work out, you can really assist your nervous system with becoming ‚Äúreleased‚Äù and start to move out of the immobilization stress reaction that describes PTSD or injury. Rather than permitting your brain to meander, give close consideration to the actual sensations in your joints and muscles, even your inner parts as your body moves. Practices that include cross-development and that engage both arms and legs ‚Äî like strolling (particularly in sand), running, swimming, weight preparing, or moving ‚Äî are a portion of your most ideal decisions.

Open-air exercises like climbing, cruising, mountain trekking, rock ascending, whitewater boating, and skiing (downhill and cross-country) have likewise been displayed to lessen the manifestations of PTSD.

Conclusion

You don‚Äôt need to go through hours in a gym center or power yourself into long, repetitive workouts to encounter the many advantages of activity. These tips can assist you with observing exercises you appreciate and begin to feel good, look better, and get more out of life.

title: FlippED: DC Vs Marvel: Which Is The Better Universe: Our Bloggers Fight It Out
text:
FlippED is an ED Original style wherein two bloggers come together and share their opposing or orthogonal perspectives on an interesting subject.

For decades, comic book movies have kept people going to the theatres. Both Marvel fans and DC fans can agree on this fact. They have kept us entertained, excited and motivated.

While both have their own drawbacks and advantages, they started with a dream, an idea. And here we stand now. While most art is getting polluted with corporate interference, some are trying to keep the dream and the art alive.

The argument remains. Who is better- DC or Marvel? Someone has to be better than the other to make the comparison as undiplomatic as possible. Let‚Äôs get right into it!

‚ÄúDC is the layered labyrinth of a disturbed mind, which seeks liberation. Which screams freedom‚Äù - Blogger Debanjan Dasgupta‚Äôs

DC Comics, or known previously as Detective Comics Inc., originating in the year 1934, does not merely hold the record for being one of the oldest comic book producers, but also one which inspired many after it. Like, of course, Marvel. But being the oldest doesn‚Äôt mean being the best. It‚Äôs not wine. It‚Äôs a comic book company. Stories get old. What exactly does DC have, watching which isn‚Äôt necessarily supposed to entertain you like a theme park ride, like Marvel? DC is the layered labyrinth of a disturbed mind, which seeks liberation. Which screams freedom.

Let‚Äôs first talk Characters! Everyone knows the characters in DC. Superman, Batman, Wonder Woman. One might have said that these characters are from a child‚Äôs dream, arguably, if not for Christopher Nolan‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Knight Trilogy‚Äù. The Dark Knight Trilogy was not a part of the DCEU, but it was definitely a milestone in its own cinematic way. The first DCEU movie was Zack Snyder‚Äôs ‚ÄúMan of Steel‚Äù, and with a critical eye, Nolan‚Äôs influence is evident. It was not just the DCEU movies that got inspired by Nolan‚Äôs character development, but also Marvel.

Showing realistic political unrest brought down by interstellar forces, autocratic/dystopian systems, villains raised by the society and human-like characters, struggling with their own physical restraints is something every comic book movie does these days. So, the question that arises, in that case, is ‚ÄúWho Did It First?‚Äù

There was a movie based on a DC comic almost 15 years ago. It was called ‚ÄúV for Vendetta‚Äù. A lot of people believe that V for Vendetta is not originally DC‚Äôs, as the producers of the comic approached DC while the comic was halfway through. But anyway, the idea was carried forward. What the movie showed still remains with the mass.

Darling, all I know are sad songs

Let‚Äôs see what ruined the DCEU, now. Because, no matter how much we argue, the fact remains that the DCEU is ruined. It was corporate interference. Warner Bros wanted to compete with the Marvel Cinematic Universe, which was making it big by bringing all of their individual superhero movies together, creating this dream-like scenario that fans could only imagine before that. Of course, the MCU was earning billions upon billions with every single release because they are more business-minded, unlike the DC universe, who still believe in art.

Warner Bros thought they should do it as well without even creating proper character arcs because they might have thought that these characters have been going on for hundreds of years now. And that if they bring the characters together, they will create a huge thing!

Yes, showing Batman, Superman, Wonder Woman, Flash in one frame is something huge! But Warner Bros did not let DC do its job with building the character arcs first before jumping into bringing these together.

We know how miserably they failed. Zack Snyder‚Äôs cut of the Justice League movie was definitely better than the previous one, but it lacked what it lacked. We could not connect with the characters as much as we were supposed to. We could not feel the same emotional intensity like we did when Iron Man died.

Two years ago, Joker came out starring Joaquin Phoenix. The movie was no short of a masterpiece. If anyone did it after Heath Ledger, it was this guy, but sadly this movie was not by the DCEU either. But they should understand what works for them now.

Competing with Marvel is not going to work anymore because they must understand that they are different. If Marvel is a Bollywood action movie, DC is an art-house drama. While Marvel is targeting everyone, regardless of their age, class, ethnicity, DC cannot do that. Because both of them have created a brand for themselves, and they are different from one another.

DC is better with cinematic expressions, building characters, and it definitely awes those who have a taste for it. But not everyone is prepared to solve extreme puzzles after a hard week when they just want to be entertained! Cinematically, DC is better. Martin Scorsese was right, Marvel is a ride through the theme park.

‚ÄúIt is similar to Bollywood action movies, but the physics makes sense here!‚Äù - Blogger Charlotte Mondal

Marvel Comics is the brand name and primary imprint of Marvel Worldwide, Inc. formerly known as Marvel Publishing, Inc. It was started in 1939 as Timely Comics whereas the Marvel era began in 1961 when the company launched The Fantastic Four. Hence, the Marvel brand was solidified as the primary brand.

Marvel‚Äôs characters are as iconic and evergreen as the day they were created. They are the most well-known due to their simple nature and extremely entrancing storylines. Spiderman, Iron Man, Hawkeye, Thor, The Hulk and Black Widow are the most well-known ones among the general population.

Marvel has been winning the DC vs Marvel fight for quite a couple of decades now owing to its tendency of creating intricate universes that mesh with each other seamlessly.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe makes some of the most entertaining and detailed movies with the special added effects being their rock-solid wall of secrecy that is maintained with great efforts by everyone involved in the production.

Marvel while writing its stories keep certain things in mind. They try to create something that can be enjoyed by both children and grownups. The lack of complicacies in these movies provides the audience with what they want when they want to be entertained. It is similar to Bollywood action movies, but the physics makes sense here!

While the DCEU is still trying to figure out exactly how ‚Äúdark‚Äù they are going to make their stories, Marvel is achieving it all in the light. While DCEU is going on using the same ‚ÄúDark Knight Trilogy‚Äù formula, MCU is winning hearts. It won‚Äôt be an exaggeration to say that Marvel made the entire world shed some tears when Iron Man died.

Those of us who grew up watching these movies instantly remembered how tiny we were. Our legs would not reach the floor of the theatre. But we understood the movie!

The first Iron Man movie, where he‚Äôs building a suit for himself, flying around, fighting! We associate good times with these movies. Whereas those of us who have tried watching The Dark Knight as a kid because we heard that there was Batman in it, probably fell asleep 5 minutes into it.

Iron Man‚Äôs death was not the end of an era, but also a big push for everyone who was watching it, regardless of whether he or she was a fan. It was a realization that we were growing up.

The Times They Are a-Changin‚Äô

Of course, Marvel cannot and should not be compared with DC. Other than the fact that Marvel is better than DC, there‚Äôs also the fact that DC has fallen victim to the corporate drama. While the directors and writers know what they want, and probably what the audience wants, it‚Äôs the producers who are under the impression that DC fans want what Marvel is doing. That is not true.

Both are necessary in this world. Raw realism, showing the vulnerability even superheroes aren‚Äôt spared, and pure entertainment, bringing warmth and joy to billions of people watching it.

But we know who is better when it comes to making people feel more connected to a character. It‚Äôs Marvel. We know who is better when it comes to visually thrilling people with VFX. It‚Äôs Marvel! We know who is better at storytelling which is accessible to everyone. Marvel!

You Choose!

Again, both are good in their own way, and both are bad. But in the end of it‚Äôs up to us whom we are going to like, justify and defend.

Whom do you like?

title: ‚ÄòSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äô Becomes First Pandemic-Era Movie to Smash $1 Billion Milestone Globally.
text:
‚Äú Spider-Man: No Way Home ‚Äú unwrapped the best Christmas gift of all, becoming the first pandemic-era movie to cross $1 billion at the global box office.

Sony‚Äôs comic-book epic has eclipsed that milestone in a near-record 12 days, tying with 2015‚Äôs ‚ÄúStar Wars: The Force Awakens‚Äù as the third-fastest film to reach the billion-dollar benchmark. Only 2018‚Äôs ‚ÄúAvengers: Infinity War‚Äù and 2019‚Äôs ‚ÄúAvengers: Endgame‚Äù were quicker, smashing the coveted tally in 11 and five days, respectively.

It‚Äôs impressive that ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù managed to blow past $1 billion in ticket sales worldwide given the rapidly spreading omicron variant of COVID-19. But, so far, coronavirus concerns have done little to slow Peter Parker‚Äôs prowess; the film is still playing to many sold-out screenings nationwide. The achievement makes Tom Holland‚Äôs Marvel superhero adventure the only movie since 2019‚Äôs ‚ÄúStar Wars: The Rise of Skywalker‚Äù to surpass $1 billion globally. No other Hollywood film has come close to nearing those box office revenues in the last two years. Prior to Spidey‚Äôs reign, MGM‚Äôs James Bond sequel ‚ÄúNo Time to Die,‚Äù which grossed $774 million globally, came the closest and stood as the highest-grossing Hollywood film of 2021 (and the pandemic).

With $1 billion banked, ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù also took the earthly throne from another box-office behemoth, China‚Äôs local-language war film ‚ÄúThe Battle at Lake Changjin‚Äù ($902 million globally), officially cementing its place as the year‚Äôs highest-grossing film worldwide. It‚Äôs also notable that ‚ÄúNo Way Home‚Äù surpassed that high-watermark without playing in China, which is currently the world‚Äôs biggest moviegoing market.

At the domestic box office, ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù had another dominant weekend, soaring high above the competition during a crowded Christmas corridor. The newest ‚ÄúSpider-Man‚Äù adventure collected $81 million from 4,336 North American theaters over the weekend, down 69% from its jaw-dropping debut. To put its second-weekend figure in perspective, only select COVID-era releases have managed to generate that kind of coinage in their entire theatrical runs, much less in their sophomore outings. ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù also managed to do so at a time when several new movies ‚Äî ‚Äú The Matrix Resurrections,‚Äù ‚Äú Sing 2 ‚Äú and ‚ÄúThe King‚Äôs Man,‚Äù among others ‚Äî opened nationwide to decent (and not-so-decent) ticket sales.

It brings the film‚Äôs ten-day total to a mammoth $467 million at the domestic box office. That tally is more than double the year‚Äôs next highest-grossing movie, Disney and Marvel‚Äôs ‚ÄúShang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings,‚Äù which earned a mighty $224 million domestically. At the international box office, ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home‚Äù added $121.4 million over the weekend and has made $587 million to date, boosting its global revenues to $1.05 billion.

Universal and Illumination‚Äôs animated musical ‚ÄúSing 2‚Äù had the biggest start among new releases, debuting in second place with $23.7 million from 3,892 domestic theaters over the traditional weekend and $41 million since Wednesday. (That number is slightly inflated because it includes $1.6 million banked from advanced screenings over Thanksgiving weekend.) It‚Äôs a softer start than its predecessor, 2016‚Äôs ‚ÄúSing,‚Äù which had secured a three-day total of $35 million and five-day tally of $54.9 million. However, it‚Äôs not a bad result for a film targeted at parents with young kids at a time when family audiences have been especially wary about going to the movies.

‚ÄúThe industry has been saying family audiences haven‚Äôt been coming out, but we proved that wrong,‚Äù said Universal‚Äôs president of domestic distribution Jim Orr.

The jukebox sequel, directed by Garth Jennings and voiced by Matthew McConaughey, Reese Witherspoon, Scarlett Johansson, Nick Kroll and Bono, has been well-received by audiences, who awarded it a coveted ‚ÄúA+‚Äù CinemaScore. Unless the pandemic has something to say, ‚ÄúSing 2‚Äù should benefit from a long run on the big screen, especially since it doesn‚Äôt have much competition among family films. The original ‚ÄúSing,‚Äù centering on a bevy of animals with killer pipes, also bowed around Christmas and played in theaters well into the new year, ultimately grossing $270 million stateside and $634 million worldwide. At this rate, the sequel will have trouble replicating those results but it should remain the de facto choice for youngsters through the holiday season.

Other new nationwide releases struggled to pull ticket buyers away from ‚ÄúSpider-Man: No Way Home.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Matrix Resurrections,‚Äù Warner Bros. and Village Roadshow‚Äôs sci-fi sequel, landed with a thud in third place. The cerebral film arrived significantly behind expectations, scraping together $12 million from 3,552 cinemas over the weekend and $22.5 million since Wednesday. The fourth installment in the seminal series, like Warner Bros. entire 2021 slate, is available simultaneously on HBO Max, though the company didn‚Äôt provide digital viewership metrics.

Internationally, the latest ‚ÄúMatrix‚Äù entry has generated $47 million so far, which brings its global haul to $69.8 million.

Lana Wachowski returned to direct ‚ÄúThe Matrix Resurrections,‚Äù which stars Keanu Reeves as the sleek cybercriminal Neo and Carrie-Anne Moss as Trinity. The $190 million-budgeted tentpole has gotten mixed responses (it has a 67% on Rotten Tomatoes, as well as a ‚ÄúB-‚Äù CinemaScore), which may not move the needle for ticket sales while it‚Äôs playing simultaneously on a streaming service at no extra charge.

‚ÄúRight now, if you‚Äôre under 35 and going to the movies, your first choice is ‚ÄòSpider-Man,‚Äô and your second choice is seeing ‚ÄòSpider-Man‚Äô again,‚Äù says David A. Gross, who runs the movie consulting firm Franchise Entertainment Research. ‚ÄúYou can watch ‚ÄòThe Matrix‚Äô later with someone who has HBO. That‚Äôs how it is when a single movie is dominating the market the way ‚ÄòSpider-Man‚Äô is.‚Äù

Another newcomer, Disney and 20th Century‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe King‚Äôs Man‚Äù finished in fourth place, amassing a paltry $6.3 million from 3,180 screens over the weekend and $10 million since debuting on Wednesday. Overseas, the prequel in ‚ÄúThe Kingsman‚Äù action franchise didn‚Äôt make up much ground. The oft-delayed spy comedy, starring Ralph Fiennes, nabbed only $6.9 million from seven international markets for a global tally of $16.9 million.

At the domestic box office, ‚ÄúThe King‚Äôs Man‚Äù beat Lionsgate‚Äôs real-life sports drama ‚ÄúAmerican Underdog‚Äù by a hair. In fifth place, ‚ÄúAmerican Underdog‚Äù captured $6.2 million from 2,813 locations since opening on Christmas Day. The crowd-pleasing film about rags-to-riches quarterback Kurt Warner (played by Zachary Levi) has been embraced by moviegoers, who gave it an ‚ÄúA+‚Äù CinemaScore and 98% on Rotten Tomatoes. Unfortunately, the movie hasn‚Äôt been high on audience‚Äôs radars and could get sacked by competitors over the busy holiday stretch.

Strong reviews didn‚Äôt do much to boost Disney‚Äôs big-budget ‚ÄúWest Side Story‚Äù remake, which landed at ‚Ññ6 in its third weekend of release with $2.8 million from 2,810 venues. The Steven Spielberg-directed musical has generated $23.9 million domestically since launching earlier in December. The song-and-dance property has also had a slow go at it overseas, grossing only $12.7 million from 46 international territories so far. Globally, the $100 million-budgeted ‚ÄúWest Side Story‚Äù has earned just $36.6 million to date.

Even with the rousing success of Sony‚Äôs ‚ÄúSpider-Man‚Äù threequel, it wasn‚Äôt all good news on the movie studio‚Äôs lot. Sony‚Äôs latest new nationwide release, the tear-jerker ‚ÄúA Journal for Jordan,‚Äù barely managed to crack the top 10. Despite a high-wattage director and star in Denzel Washington and Michael B. Jordan, the film notched eighth place with a scant $2.2 million in receipts from 2,500 venues on Saturday and Sunday.

‚ÄúA Journal for Jordan‚Äù sold less tickets than director Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs coming-of-age comedic drama ‚ÄúLicorice Pizza,‚Äù which expanded to 786 North American theaters on Christmas Day after four weeks in limited release. The movie, starring Cooper Hoffman and Alana Haim, collected $2.32 million on Saturday and Sunday, enough for seventh place. To date, the MGM film and awards season hopeful has generated $3.6 million domestically.
