title: 10 Hard-Hitting, Not-So-Subtle New Year Thoughts for the Events Industry
text:
I‚Äôve read a few articles on predictions for the global events industry in 2022. Enjoyable reads from those associated with an industry hit hard by COVID. But, in my humble opinion, those articles stop short. They‚Äôre incomplete. Off target, at least from my point of view.

There are some chronic problems with events that never seem to get addressed. Others issues are just gaining traction. At events, large and small.

So I decided to offer 10 thoughts of my own, based on my experience as an event director, conference producer, corporate and product marketer, broadcast and streaming media professional, trade show booth set-up and tear-down guy, TV and film background actor, voiceover talent, exhibit hall presenter, CRM industry keynote speaker, writer, content creator, speaking coach, materials handler, frequent flyer‚Ä¶ you get the drift.

But they‚Äôre not predictions. I wanna be different. 10 thoughts.

I could offer so much more, but here are 10 thoughts, for starters:

1. Public Speakers Will Continue to be Ill-Prepared

Ok, allow me to clarify. The vast, vast, vast majority of public speakers won‚Äôt be prepared for their sessions. Not all, but most. This was a problem long before the pandemic, and it‚Äôs not changing anytime soon. The evidence is out there for all the world to see and hear as more and more companies decide to go online with event activities. It‚Äôs clear and obvious when corporate speakers don‚Äôt prep or rehearse. It‚Äôs clear when they don‚Äôt attempt to use their body language or their voices. While they read slides, waste your time, etc.

You know it 10‚Äì15 seconds into a session, and you have an hour to go‚Ä¶

2. Audiences Will Continue to Accept (and Pay for) Bad Presentations

Again, this is a problem that‚Äôs been around forever. Nobody checks on what an audience learns ‚Äî or doesn‚Äôt. I‚Äôve been a part of more terrible event, conference, and trade show sessions where the speaker loses an audience from the start, yet receives a polite round of applause from the crowd playing on phones and laptops. Add in the cost of travel, hotel, and food to the price of an event ticket and somebody, somewhere is flushing their money down the drain.

But it usually isn‚Äôt the attendee.

3. Panel Discussions Should be Regulated by the FDA

Because they‚Äôre putting people to sleep not just in the USA, but across the planet. We may have a new pharmaceutical on our hands.

Years have gone by and I‚Äôve yet to hear somebody say, ‚ÄúWOW! I was blown away by that panel discussion!‚Äù Check your next event schedule. Do you see a panel discussion?

Ugh.

I‚Äôm guilty of having panel discussions on my programs in the distant past. I‚Äôm not sure where the notion of having three to six (or more) people sit in comfy chairs on stage and drone on for an hour became engaging and entertaining. And I‚Äôm sure as hell unaware of how anybody can put the same number of people online and called that entertaining. Panel discussions look good an paper, and are very easy to do. It‚Äôs a way to accommodate high-paying sponsors and placate know-it-alls with a spot in front the crowd. It‚Äôs also a phenomenal way to phone in your next appearance.

Did I mention they‚Äôre easy, time fillers‚Ä¶ and you‚Äôre paying for that‚Ä¶

(In the United States of America, FDA stands for Food and Drug Adminstration.)

4. Investors, CEOs, and CMOs Continue to Struggle with Events

Having been in and around this business for decades, I know what costs what. Investors clearly pay the bill ‚Äî but they rarely ask questions about event outcomes. Or they wait until it‚Äôs too late.

CEOs may actually attend an event ‚Äî for a moment or two, but they‚Äôre rarely around for booth set-up or tear down. And CMOs will stroll into the convention hall with a cup of coffee while the booth is being set, finger point, and they‚Äôll leave just before this exhibit hall closes‚Ä¶with the false sense of knowing they did a great job, but without knowing all there is to know about the results from a just-completed event.

This event and conference stuff costs money.

And if more investors took an interest, and if more CEOs and CMOs had a handle on the totality of their events, expenditures, and outcomes, a different, more engaging and more productive event landscape may exist.

But it doesn‚Äôt.

How else can you explain why the business world is offered such outdated, cookie-cutter conventions and boring virtual activities while at the same time finding companies to pay the freight of the high-price tags to participate?

In 2022, some will start to pay attention. Finally.

5. Sales Enablement Continues to Enable‚Ä¶ Not Very Much

We‚Äôre now in a pandemic age of supporting sales across multiple channels. This includes events. But companies are more concerned with the usage of software platforms to deliver stale content then they are with genuine sales team readiness.

Meanwhile, more time is wasted and there are numbers to be hit.

External sales must be able to speak to content. Inside sales. Executives. Marketing. All front-line personnel, to start. Tech usage for learning is good, but if that‚Äôs the major concern, you‚Äôll be left standing on the one yard line.

Sales Readiness is essential for event success.

Example‚Ä¶ Think about the last demo you saw. I‚Äôll give you the benefit of the doubt. I‚Äôm sure there were award-winning graphics and sound. Scripted material. Innovative tech.

But how about the presenter? Storytelling skills‚Ä¶audience interaction‚Ä¶hybrid formats‚Ä¶endurance‚Ä¶ If the computer crashed, could the demo continue? Sales Enablement, indeed. You need team readiness for all event formats.

Try it without the tech to exercise personal communication skills.

6. Filler Language Expands its Footprint

Ummm, you know what I mean, uhhh‚Ä¶ right?

Filler words are the vocabulary of the unprepared public speaker. Or panelist. Or podcast host, and their guests. Filler words have now expanded into business podcasts. Into virtual and hybrid presentations. You‚Äôve heard them; maybe you use them.

What do I mean ‚Äòmaybe‚Äô?

Play a game with me. When watching or listening to a session (of any kind) you‚Äôll know within the first 15‚Äì30 seconds if a speaker is ready. The filler words will start to fly. Count them. Use your fingers and toes and a pen and paper to count the ummms, uhhhs, you knows, rights‚Ä¶odds are you‚Äôll run out of fingers and toes within a few minutes.

Maybe, ummm, quite possibly, sooner. Ya know?

That‚Äôs unfortunate. Filler words are so easy to eliminate.

7. On Podcasts‚Ä¶ The Astonishing Lack of Creativity Endures

I read somewhere that the average podcast lasts seven episodes. No surprise, because the average business podcast sounds like, acts like, looks like, and feels like every other podcast‚Ä¶ and they‚Äôre hard work to produce.

How about some generic music at the beginning?

How about some long-winded bio introductions?

Some poor quality audio, with phone lines or concrete walls?

Brought to you by your host, thrown to wolves on a microphone by those who think a good performance just happens, just because‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ and you expect me to listen for more than 60 seconds?

When the going gets tough and the podcast becomes a marketing pain, most take the path of least resistance. They stop doing them.

Podcasts can play a fun, creative, competitive part in any event activity. But they‚Äôre hard work. Good audio, is hard work. Speaker prep, is hard work. Creative usage at events doesn‚Äôt come easy. And for those who truly believe that you‚Äôre being creative just by having a podcast studio set-up in your booth, that‚Äôs old news. That‚Äôs been done for decades ‚Äî in various forms. The world won‚Äôt come running to your booth, just because. There are dozens of ways to use creative audio at events, anchored by exceptional podcasts. In-person, virtual, and hybrid.

Show your audience something other than the typical podcast painted-by-number.

8. Sales Kickoffs Need to Adjust

Beyond the safety blanket and the misguided notions behind sales enablement software and learning platforms being the immediate priorities, you‚Äôve got a sales or company kickoff scheduled for early 2022. Of course you do. And I challenge you to think and act differently before, during and after your next kickoff.

But what do you have planned, for this next round? Lemme guess‚Ä¶

Sessions with your CEO, CMO, and Product VPs given an hour each.

Maybe a customer or two and and an analyst, or a special guest, also with an hour each.

Some sales stories. A few case studies.

And a dash of product marketing‚Ä¶as in ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs Tony, at 9:30 Wednesday morning, to tell you everything you need to know about GTM strategy, messaging, positioning, content, alliances, and competitive intel, and how this will play out at events‚Ä¶ after his 30 minutes, we‚Äôll break at 10.‚Äù

Throw that away. For those who want an idea for 2022 sales kickoff, try the Product Marketing Gauntlet.

With Omicron at the outset of 2022, you need an agile, fully-prepared sales team to excel in any format of market interaction. Then again, you‚Äôve needed that all along and you still offered the same cookie-cutter sales kickoff format.

This year, get into the sales and team readiness game and try something else.

9. Alternatives to Trade Shows and Conventions Will Increase

As much as I can‚Äôt stand senior leadership‚Äôs obliviousness when it comes to events, there are some rumblings from some business people about long-in-the-tooth event formats, their effectiveness, and time and wallet-draining expenses.

in 2022, you don‚Äôt have to jump back into any single industry event and spend a boatload of your marketing money. I suggested 10 Alternatives, and your options are only increasing. And nobody is going to think you‚Äôre going out of business if you don‚Äôt have a 30‚Äô x 30‚Äô booth or spend six and seven figures at the next Vegas or Northern California event. There are newer, better, and more cost-efficient and effective ways to engage audiences vs. the tired exercise of fighting your way through a pandemic to Midtown Manhattan or the Chicago Lakefront for a week-long marathon.

Especially in explosive arena of B2B Tech Marketing.

10. Understanding Event Selection, Prep, Execution, and Measurement is Critical

Some want the Vegas boondoggle. Others want to play the role of big shot sponsor in Northern California. Still others just buy what some event producers are selling‚Ä¶just because.

Great, enjoy.

For those serious about their events, faced with choosing when and where to place their investments in 2022 and 2023, you must apply critical business perspectives to all event activities. That time is now.

You‚Äôre spending limited resources, and this affects how you choose events, how well your speakers are prepared, the depth of your content, how sales skills are strengthened, exhibit hall, branding, and booth activities, opportunity generation, on-line and in-person engagements, measurement and reporting‚Ä¶ and so much more.

As we enter 2022, possessing this business acumen around events has never been more important. For astute investors and executives, it‚Äôs all table stakes now.

‚Äî

Marketing, is under duress. CMOs have short windows of opportunities, and short tenures.

The process of how events are approached, executed, and measured plays a huge role in marketing and sales success. And event shortcomings have only been exposed and exasperated during the pandemic.

For those who wish to keep doing what you‚Äôre doing with events, I wrote about my experience here. All the best to you in 2022.

For those who understand the Event Gauntlet that will challenge you in 2022, welcome to a new business landscape like you‚Äôve never seen before.

I predict radically redesigned sales and marketing opportunities involving events will be endless.

Tony Compton holds two degrees from Loyola University Chicago: a 1987 B.A. in Communication and a 1995 MBA. He‚Äôs held a number of marketing and business leadership positions over the past three decades. And he knows a thing or two about events.

title: Life Changing Experience at NYC Public School
text:
So I had a pretty wild life experience last week. After reaching out to a bunch of NYC schools in hopes of performing a guest reading of The Nestomir ‚Äî a few schools responded enthusiastically to me! And last Tuesday I had the opportunity to perform a guest reading for The Urban Assembly Gateway School for Technology, a public high school in Manhattan, NY.

When the day came, I had no idea what I was going to say or do‚Ä¶what on Earth do you say to a group of skeptical, hard-to-impress teenagers? I decided it was not something I couldn‚Äôt easily plan for (I did have a few notes scribbled on a post-it taped to the front of my copy of the story), but I knew I would have to adapt to the situation in real time. And I was right.

(Presenting to the tenth graders of The Urban Assembly Gateway School for Technology)

When I showed up to the school‚Äôs main entrance, the security guard walked me up to the English classroom where I was scheduled to present. The teacher immediately greeted me‚Ä¶and to sum up what she told me: Good luck! These kids are a fidgety bunch, you‚Äôre going to have work really hard to get them to pay attention!

Great. Then the bell rang. The kids began to pour inside the room. What was quite comical: the kids could tell something was different about their class today‚Ä¶leading them to believe they had a pop quiz. To their relief, it was only a guest speaker.

The teacher gave me a brief intro, then I made my walk up to the front of the classroom. My only objective: do not let them fall asleep, no matter the cost.

What I Did:

I quickly intro‚Äôd myself, then I immediately asked the class if they wanted to perform a freestyle rap battle contest. This caught them off guard and perked their attention up‚Ä¶a few kids even selected classmates to compete‚Ä¶but I told them I would save this activity for next time I visit.

Next, I decided to put the book down. My gut told me to speak about my adventures learning to code. I spoke about learning key software engineering lessons from my first business partner. I got some engagement‚Ä¶but not enough.

The tide turned when I began to speak about my greatest life challenges, including when it came to performing in school. My greatest academic challenge came during my first semester of engineering school. I came into college with a high school work ethic, and that was a fail. I was used to doing everything last minute; I had no understanding of discipline or work ethic. That first college semester I had a big scare‚Ä¶but it ultimately led me to going from one of the world‚Äôs biggest procrastinators to someone who is obsessed with organization and being extremely disciplined when attacking new work and projects. The kids really took to this speaking segment‚Ä¶I got a lot of questions and heads perked up. And as a result, more kids paid attention to the short reading I performed.

I didn‚Äôt want to write too long of a post. But what I learned most: people, no matter if they are kids or adults, like to hear about struggle. It wasn‚Äôt until I spoke about the serious battles I faced in my life that I became credible and the kids paid me real attention. I hope to use these experiences talking to students to become a better mentor, educator, and author in the future.

ps: I will be presenting to a bunch of other NYC/Long Island public schools in January/February 2022! Stay tuned.

Have a great week!

Steven Reubenstone

Author, The Nestomir

Know any parents or educators who might be interested in The Nestomir newsletter? Get them to sign up here.

title: The Footsoldiers of the Next French Revolution
text:
Thinking myself relatively clued up on french style, it didn‚Äôt come as a shock when I arrived in Paris and saw that in fact very few French women wear berets ‚Äî what was much more surprising was that in the final throes of 2021, there are UGGs absolutely everywhere.

It may just be the circles I move in, or the galvanising echo-chamber effects of social media, but I was under the impression that the fashion world had left UGGs (definitely and determinedly) in the late noughties. Now, 10 years later, they appear to be back, in the fashion capital of the world of all places. Questions abound ‚Äî why? how? who? WHY? and I for one like to think that the answer lies in the reinvention of the elusive phenomenon that is the Parisienne.

Entire books ‚Äî many of them ‚Äî have been written on how to perfect the air of the archetypal Parisian woman (or perhaps, in true french style, implicitly reminding foreign readers of the impossibility of this task), whilst countless iterations of this red-lipped, trench-coated character have taken centre stage in all forms of media and art.

The pop-culture interpretation of French-girl chic is an image that I‚Äôve long aspired to. I‚Äôve completed the tousled bob, and painstakingly embraced the semi-undone ‚Äòdid my makeup in 15 seconds flat‚Äô aesthetic. ‚ÄòThe‚Äô Parisienne embodied the effortless elegance that my awkward and uncertain teenage self wished to exude, and that is what started me on the path to my current mode de vie, teaching English in a Parisian suburb. Now, despite having enthusiastically pursued this image for several years, I‚Äôm beginning to realise that I misunderstood it.

To start with, effortless beauty is a myth. Life is messy and unexpected and some days it is impossible to control anything, least of all your hair. More importantly however, we must ask ourselves who exactly this image is supposed to depict. In my time here so far, i‚Äôve not met a single person who could, practically speaking, fit into the mould that several decades of film and literature have cast. Perhaps part of the allure all along was the impossibility of the thing ‚Äî but a growing movement, which includes authors such as fashion journalist Alice Pfeiffer and culture writer Lindsey Tramuta, is highlighting the oversights of this particular trope.

The Parisienne is a sort of heroine immune to all biological, generational and social norms‚Ä¶ Generation after generation of Parisiennes share certain characteristics and answer to the same style criteria, which are implicit but omnipresent: social class, education, appearance, lineage, skin colour‚Ä¶ (‚ÄòJe ne suis pas parisienne‚Äô, Alice Pfeiffer ‚Äî my own translation)

Their argument is intertwined with a particularity of the French constitution, which, although perhaps well-intentioned, can be seen to propagate racial disparity ‚Äî ‚Äòla la√Øcit√©‚Äô. Similar to the notion of secularity, la√Øcit√© does not permit the french state to collect official data on race, ethnicity or religion, nor discuss these subjects in the public sphere. Although the goal is to treat citizens equally, this ‚Äòcolourblindness‚Äô can render minority groups invisible.

As Pfeiffer points out in the first chapter of her 2019 book ‚ÄòJe ne suis pas Parisienne‚Äô, there is no one image that can be associated with a Londoner, or the ladies of New York. They have many faces. In fact (for me at least), part of the draw of London is its melting-pot culture; so diverse are the identities of Londoners that diversity becomes the identity itself. This is not so in France, where, under the law, the one and only acceptable cultural identity is ‚ÄòFrench‚Äô.

Unfortunately for the french state, we live in an age where distinct cultural groups exist by default. There will always be a set of people in France who are of Asian origin, or who practise Islam, or who are first generation immigrants, regardless of whether or not they are permitted to openly express these aspects of their identity. Further, the divisions between these groups are exacerbated in times of social change. Although the juggernaut that is COVID has effected significant practical changes on all of our lives, the burden has landed disproportionately on certain strata of society; meanwhile, the resurgence of Black Lives Matter has woken us up to the importance of representation.

The french goal of repressing ‚Äòcommunautarisme‚Äô (the formation of these culture-based identity groups) cannot answer to either of these aspects of modern life, and nor can the invariably white, perfectly put together femme that we know as the Parisienne. Unable to make themselves heard or seen, members of minority communities can only watch as they are (mis)represented, time and time again, by an image whose singularity is a continuation of that which la√Øcit√© necessarily entails.

The traditional Parisienne is a caricature whose aesthetic I will continue to admire, but times are changing and UGGs may well be a step in the right direction. I maintain that the nickname ‚ÄòUGGlies‚Äô is not undeserved ‚Äî but that is exactly what makes this worth writing. Sporting such monstrously fluffy footwear constitutes a small act of rebellion against the trope of the Parisienne, whilst still managing to convey its one valuable message: not worrying too much about what you look like.

Come 2022, the Parisienne craves the same physical comfort and spiritual healing that many of us now seek more actively. This, for some, will mean striving to exist outside of the excruciatingly narrow definition of ‚Äòthe french woman‚Äô, and it is this cast who will model the new epitome of french-girl chic; coffee, cigarettes, and UGGs.

title: ‚ÄòThe Equality Education‚Äô: Inspiring Greatness in Kids in New York City
text:
‚ÄòThe Equality Education‚Äô: Inspiring Greatness in Kids in New York City

A New York City small business‚Äôs mission to help kids ‚Äúdiscover their greatness‚Äù through social-emotional learning.

Arianna Silver (left) and Soleil Laurent (right) stand within their Union Square Holiday Market vendor booth displaying their business‚Äôs empowering products on Monday, November 29, 2021. Equality Education, a business that began only last year, sits among over 160 others in the market in New York City, NY. (Photo courtesy of Equality Education).

As Soleil Laurent and Arianna Silver walked the mile from their neighborhood in Bushwick, Brooklyn to Blink Fitness ‚Äî a routine that began after they met by chance in spring 2019 and became friends‚Äî they discussed the usual: personal development, growth, and vulnerability.

After enduring physical and emotional bullying from grade five through high school, Laurent and Silver connected on their journeys growing from those and other negative experiences. Laurent, a musician and student of psychology and neuroscience, and Silver, a life coach who studied sociology, strode down Bushwick‚Äôs Knickerbocker Avenue, discussing their knowledge from their educations, a myriad of self-improvement books, and their commitment to understanding emotions.

‚ÄúAs we got deeper into these conversations, we realized that a lot of the stuff that we were talking about at this age in our lives were things that would have been totally transformational if we had learned them as kids,‚Äù said Silver. ‚ÄúBasically, if you had taught me in school how to deal with my emotions the same way you taught me math, I would be a totally different person.‚Äù

The ‚Äústuff‚Äù Silver mentioned is defined as social-emotional learning, or the process through which individuals ‚Äúacquire the knowledge, attitudes, and skills to: recognize and manage their emotions, set and achieve positive goals, demonstrate caring and concern for others, establish and maintain positive relationships, make responsible decisions, and handle interpersonal situations effectively,‚Äù according to the Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning, a nonprofit leader in social-emotional research. This sort of education is proven to be successful for children, with several studies of both short-term and long-term effects demonstrating improvements in interpersonal skills and feelings of personal growth while lowering emotional distress and conduct issues.

When the COVID-19 pandemic swept over the globe and a national reckoning with systemic racism came to the forefront of public consciousness in 2020, dealing with emotions and processing emotional distress could not have been more necessary for youth in the minds of Laurent and Silver. They began having conversations on Instagram Live in July 2020, reflecting on issues of the pandemic and racial injustices like the murder of George Floyd. The positive response to their conversations paired with their personal passion for social-emotional learning led to the beginning of Equality Education, a small-business with the goal of providing a 60-module social-emotional and diversity-centered curriculum as well as empowering merchandise to children and schools.

‚ÄúThe world shook,‚Äù said Laurent, ‚Äúand people, especially kids, need a better foundation within themselves. And that foundation can be built with the tools we create for them to access.‚Äù

Equality Education‚Äôs curriculum, which launches in mid-2022, is coming to fruition at a time when schools across New York City are implementing social-emotional learning practices. The city‚Äôs Bridge to School initiative, which received an almost two million dollar investment by the Department of Education and Fund for Public Schools, provides trauma-informed training to educators and social-emotional and mental health support for the city‚Äôs nearly 1.1 million students.

Chirlane McCray, First Lady of New York City, said in the 2021-2022 Bridge to School plan that ‚Äúpreparing our young people for success means helping them deal with the social, emotional, and academic challenges of their lives. It means teaching them ways to process their many emotions and showing them how to build healthy relationships and resolve conflicts in a constructive way. That is how we help them flourish into happy, healthy adults.‚Äù

Equality Education‚Äôs goal is to be a resource for schools, particularly ones in underfunded communities where research finds that funding differences are inequitable between schools with highest and lowest needs based on students living in poverty. According to the New York City Council, the schools in need of equitable funding and adequate resources ‚Äî including social-emotional pratices ‚Äî are in communities of color.

‚ÄúWe are looking to take funds from schools that can afford our almost $2,300 institutional membership to the curriculum and use that money to give the program to people and schools who might not have the funds to be able to access it themselves,‚Äù said Silver.

‚ÄúWe're big-hearted people that just want the best for others,‚Äù said Laurent, explaining their motivations. ‚ÄúLife is going to have a lot of challenges, but we want to provide resources and tools for kids to move forward and grow, especially kids who may be in tougher situations than others.‚Äù

At its core, Equality Education‚Äôs curriculum focuses on the ‚Äúdevelopment of human consciousness through mental health awareness, emotional intelligence, and perception of others,‚Äù according to its official website. The program covers topics from positive self-talk, gratitude, and decision-making to valuing individuality and diversity, communication techniques, and growth from failure. It contains animated teaching episodes, writing prompts, a neuro-linguistic programming series, child-parent exercises, and more, catering to any type of learner (whether visual, auditory, or kinesthetic). While the curriculum will be available for individuals to subscribe to for about $20 a month, its primary goal is to be bought and distributed within schools, which is why it is geared towards children ages 2 to 18.

The co-founders explained that as they develop the curriculum, the concepts will be the same across the spectrum, but the material will vary depending on the age group. ‚ÄúWith a kid who's being introduced to it as a two year old, it's a little different than something that we might teach 18 year old,‚Äù said Silver, explaining that younger age groups will have simpler activities that engage their attention like animated videos and coloring activities, while older kids will have more complex journaling activities or discussion prompts.

‚ÄúBeing human is human. That's really the basis of what we're teaching,‚Äù said Laurent, summarizing the curriculum.

Laurent and Silver invested a large amount of their own money to start the business, a number they cannot even begin to estimate. ‚ÄúWhen it comes to investing in Equality Education, it's almost automatic,‚Äù said Laurent. ‚ÄúWe essentially send $500, send $1000, send this, send that. And we've been doing that for a year, all because we have faith in this for children.‚Äù

As the curriculum awaits its launch, the business sells empowering merchandise like posters, art, clothing and accessories in order to fund the production of the 60-module program. The best-selling product is the ‚ÄúI AM‚Äù affirmations coloring book with hand-drawn images and affirmations ranging from ‚ÄúI am worthy, abundant and grateful,‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am in control of my emotions.‚Äù The hands-on resource represents the power of their coming curriculum. By coloring the pages and repeating the affirmations, kids and people of all ages begin to practice a sense of self confidence and believe in the words they say, explained Silver.

Equality Education‚Äôs ‚ÄúI AM‚Äù affirmations coloring book sits front and center at the vendor booth on Monday, November 29, 2021. It can be bought for oneself or donated to a local charity the small business partnered with this season called ‚ÄúSheltering Arms,‚Äù which helps foster social equity in New York City‚Äôs challenged communities. (Photo by Kasia O‚ÄôBrien).

Equality Education‚Äôs curriculum takes this concept of practicing self-empowerment and social-emotional awareness and expands it into multiple modalities.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so excited,‚Äù said Laurent loudly, reflecting on their passing $20,000 in sales and their curriculum‚Äôs quickly approaching launch. ‚ÄúMy whole body is in flames because it‚Äôs like, I wish I had this when I was a kid,‚Äù she continued, smiling from ear to ear.

Equality Education is currently undergoing a licensing process to become a Department of Education vendor with the ability to offer its curriculum to New York City schools. In the meantime, the business takes every opportunity to spread its message and products, from operating an Etsy shop and vending booths to conducting workshops.

This winter season, in a sea of over 160 vendors making up the tightly packed winding aisles of New York City‚Äôs Union Square Holiday Market, Laurent and Silver sit inside booth C34. Illuminated by suspended twinkling lights, the colorful bubble-lettered words on their products declaring that ‚Äúlove creates love,‚Äù and ‚Äúpowerful people empower other people,‚Äù jump out from the booth‚Äôs neutral walls. Holiday Market goers stop and flip through the coloring book. ‚ÄúNo age is too young for kids to get introduced to this,‚Äù says Silver to a few customers gathered around their booth, ‚Äúit‚Äôs never too young to learn unconditional love within ourselves and how to give it to others.‚Äù

title: Using Illustrations To Change The Face Of Business
text:
Using Illustrations To Change The Face Of Business

Illustration by issam laaziz

Have you ever had a professional photoshoot for your website or resume? Why, if you could just take some selfies? You choose professional photographers because good-looking, polished photos made in one style increase your reliability and status in the eyes of others: either a target audience or employers.

Similar principles apply to design, especially where illustration is used. Professional illustration has a number of benefits that, like a photoshoot made in a studio, cannot be substituted.

Let‚Äôs discover why and how often companies use IT outsourcing services to create illustrations, and take inspiration from some of the best practices among our case studies.

If design solves business problems and fine art predicts the future, then illustration is a medium between them.

‚Äî Sergiy Maidukov, The NY Times & The Washington Post illustrator

Why do companies outsource graphic design and illustration?

Graphic design implies creating visual content that communicates a certain message. Illustrations may be considered part of the former, but the major difference between graphic design and illustrations is where/how you use it. Graphic design projects have more commercial meaning. Meanwhile, illustrations are somewhere on the borderline between creating fine art and making profits.

Graphic design vs illustration by Vladanland

There are several reasons why companies pay someone to create visuals for them:

Saving money . Yep, paying for these services pays off in the future, and never mind the wordplay. In-house design team equals payroll costs, taxes, buying licensed software like Adobe After Effects, time to find the employees that get you. Design agencies charge only for the work done.

. Yep, paying for these services pays off in the future, and never mind the wordplay. In-house design team equals payroll costs, taxes, buying licensed software like Adobe After Effects, time to find the employees that get you. Design agencies charge only for the work done. Collective expertise and experience . Design agencies cooperate with companies of different profiles, so they have a broader knowledge of what‚Äôs good. They are also up to date with the latest trends in design and the market in general. If you would like to learn more about them, check out our article on top-2022 UI/UX design trends.

. Design agencies cooperate with companies of different profiles, so they have a broader knowledge of what‚Äôs good. They are also up to date with the latest trends in design and the market in general. If you would like to learn more about them, check out our article on top-2022 UI/UX design trends. Saving labor resources and outsourcing human resources. When a company doesn‚Äôt have in-house designers or expertise in a specific area, it doesn‚Äôt need to train its team. Especially if the project is not long-term or when the tasks are one-time. Also, an external team solves the problem of insufficient workload or overload of staff personnel.

When a company doesn‚Äôt have in-house designers or expertise in a specific area, it doesn‚Äôt need to train its team. Especially if the project is not long-term or when the tasks are one-time. Also, an external team solves the problem of insufficient workload or overload of staff personnel. Results without managing the working process. The company‚Äôs own design team needs guidance and management, and in a design agency, all processes are built by project managers, an art director, etc.

The company‚Äôs own design team needs guidance and management, and in a design agency, all processes are built by project managers, an art director, etc. Efficiency of core business. When a company chooses to outsource, it is not distracted from its strategic objectives and product development.

There‚Äôs no strong brand without competent design. The design, especially creative illustrations, requires a significant investment of money, time, and effort. But the good news is that illustrating is not usually a recurring process, but a one-time project. So companies hire professionals without pausing their strategic management.

How often do brands rely on professionals to create illustrations?

Illustration by Shakuro

The IT outsourcing services market is huge. Some time ago, Statista published research that shows that the IT-application outsourcing services market revenue in Poland is expected to reach $540 million by 2021. And that‚Äôs data for only one of the member states of the EU. The global IT outsourcing market amounted to $92.5 billion in 2019.

And what about graphic design and illustration services? $45.8 billion ‚Äî is the global graphic designers market size in 2021:

Graphic design market size according to IBIS

Where illustration is used? As of 2018, 73% of businesses invest in design to help their brand stand out against the competition. In the same research by Adobe, it was also reported that 71% of companies are now creating 10x the number of design assets than they did in previous years.

Excerpts from the research by Adobe

Most small businesses acknowledge that design is important to their success. Only 3% indicated the opposite. With this data, we can conclude that most of the companies choose to outsource their design to professional agencies like Shakuro.

How do illustrations change the face of business?

Creative illustration is a mediator between mass consumer and high art. Modern European trends come from 20th century art.

Soviet poster (constructivism) via creativebloq

Skyscrapers and Tunnels by Fortunato Depero via guggenheim.com (futurism)

Andy Warhol by Shakuro (pop art)

If design solves problems and art looks to the future, then illustration is a medium between them. An illustration is a layer of information between the meaning of a certain object and the way that viewers understand it for themselves. The illustration has no purpose in realistically conveying reality. It can be abstract and convey emotions.

Illustrations are a powerful tool for bonding with a target audience. There are several ways illustrations can change the face of business:

They show your story

How to convince others to invest resources in your brand? Sometimes it‚Äôs hard to find the words. Sometimes there are too many words and no one reads them. Show your purpose, values, processes with illustrations. Don‚Äôt tell. We talk more about this point in this article.

They create an emotional bond

How illustration shows emotions? They can be positive or negative. Some of us were legit horrified by Francisco Goya‚Äôs paintings when we were kids. But art can convey love and hope too. Custom illustrations will make other people feel: trust, warmth, even the ‚Äúuwus‚Äù. And feelings = bonding, important for all businesses alike. At Shakuro, we create illustrations for both B2C and B2B industries. People are more likely to associate themselves with cartoon characters than with the models in the photo. Looking at the staged photos, it is immediately clear that this is just a written script. Illustrations evoke the feeling of ‚Äúyeah, I feel the same‚Äù:

The coziness of Shakuro‚Äôs 2D illustration

They convey the mood and imprint on others‚Äô memories

All successful brands have one thing in common ‚Äî personality. You can design a brand to be friendly, broadminded, optimistic, memorable. Running a successful business already, but want to show its new side? Make your brand more human with illustrations, as Etsy did. But not with stock photos ‚Äî they are like Comic Sans nowadays. Leave the work to Shakuro‚Äôs professional artists.

With animations, they make a product to really stand out

Have you heard that awful joke about a snail? One man wanted his snail to be more aerodynamic and took off its shell, but it just made the snail more sluggish. What really could‚Äôve added dynamic to a poor creature, are animated illustrations. In the right doses, they can be a real eye-catcher.

Illustrations are a visual soundtrack to your brand

For our visual cortex neurons, custom illustration is like music to our ears. It can turn your existing website or application into a symphony, minimalistic ‚Äî or art-deco piece of art. Good design agencies make illustrations without disrupting the visual identity of a brand or company. They enhance things, and make art work.

Case study: creating a friendly environment

Craftverse is an aspiring crowdfunded platform for cosplay enthusiasts from around the world to share knowledge, seek advice, socialize, and explore job opportunities in this exciting creative industry.

They came to Shakuro seeking to create the site and the mobile application. You can learn more about the step-by-step process of our work with this case in our article. This cartoonish style of illustrated characters makes the overall look of the cosplay platform more open-minded and friendly. It creates an atmosphere of understanding and sincerity.

Craftverse website by Shakuro

Craftverse illustration by Shakuro

Case study: connecting a product with its audience through a mascot

A mascot is a character who embodies an idea, be it a company, a product, a team, or a brand. To put it simply, it‚Äôs a character you think of whenever a brand‚Äôs name pops up. Mascots are different, but in most cases they are animals. Anthropomorphic or not ‚Äî it‚Äôs up to a client to decide. Often you can see mascots as 2D animated characters.

Mascots unite people of different ages, professions, and nationalities. Look at the character that we created for Crizit:

Crizit mascot by Shakuro

Crizit mascot by Shakuro

Case study: adding meaningful details

Page 404

404 not found. Error 404. No one likes this message.

Competently designed, page 404 is able to keep visitors on the site, reduce bounce rates and increase traffic conversions.

404 Page Design by Shakuro

Food illustration

When it comes to food illustrations, the goal is often to celebrate, convey a sense of joy, and emphasize its ability in bringing people together. Color handles this perfectly.

Chinese food illustration by Shakuro

Sushi restaurant illustration by Shakuro

3D illustration

3D illustrations can fit perfectly into the concept of your web resource. They not only make the site more memorable, but also improve the user experience, allowing you to control the attention of the visitor. They also look more expensive, especially if the 3D characters creation is included. The main thing is not to overdo it: such elements should look appropriate, not complicate the interaction with the site and not slow down its loading.

3D illustration by Shakuro

Illustration by Shakuro

How to start outsourcing illustrations?

Illustration by Shakuro

If you decide to outsource, the next question is where to start? Posting your job on collaboration platforms is not enough, and even dangerous if you are on to something special about your product. Usually, clients turn to digital agencies to create visuals within a new web development project. But illustration, especially animated characters, can also improve an existing website or an app.

You can post your web development project that includes illustrations with just a brief statement of what you want and how you want it, and let agencies contact you.

You can research competition and see who does illustration for them.

You can formulate a list of requirements for your illustration and, eventually, you will narrow the circle to the outsourcing companies that fit best.

You can just write to a certain agency of your choice. This option is best for those who don‚Äôt really know how they want their illustrations to look like, except from competitors‚Äô examples, but don‚Äôt want to copy or create indistinguishable/stock pictures.

Finding the balance and the best-fitting expertise for your custom project is the main challenge. From our experience, people who are satisfied with our work willingly recommend us to their connections. You can learn more about how to outsource web development processes in our separate article.

Finding the balance and the best-fitting expertise for your custom project is the main challenge. From our experience, people who are satisfied with our work willingly recommend us to their connections. You can learn more about how to outsource web development in our separate article.

In conclusion

Graphic illustration is not just pretty pictures. They unite and enhance the entire user experience as a whole. Any business can be successful in design, whether it‚Äôs a product or a service. It all depends on a wise choice of outsourcing company. BTW, if you want to create an app, you might want to read our article on how to hire an outsourcing agency that gets you right.

Take a look at more examples of illustrations on our graphics page on Dribbble, in Behance, and read some stories in our portfolio where we tell more on how we used illustrations in commercial projects.

by Rita Kind-Envy, copywriter at Shakuro

title: Sqribble Ebook Creator REVIEWED!
text:
In this review, I‚Äôm going to be taking a closer look at Sqribble ‚Äî a brand new cloud-based tool that allows you to create eBooks, reports, whitepapers or other digital books on the fly, quickly and easily.

We‚Äôll cover what it does, who it‚Äôs for, how much it costs, what the upsells are, and the pros and cons of this new tool, so you can make a more informed decision about purchasing it‚Ä¶ and if it‚Äôs right for you.

Sqribble is a cloud based eBook creator tool. It allows you to create professional looking eBooks, based on templates inside the tool, with a few clicks, saving you a huge amount of time and money.

Unlike other eBook creators, Sqribble immediately caught my attention because it has some really useful features I haven‚Äôt seen anywhere else.

Automatic content ‚Äî yep, you can actually use Sqribble to fill your book with expert content, so you don‚Äôt have to write a word. This is content from around the web, based on the URL you provide. You can pull content from any URL, paste it directly, extract from a Word doc or from their own library of niche articles. Total game changer.

This is a HUGE time saver and a major plus for anyone who hates writing or doesn‚Äôt have time to do it.

Gorgeous eCovers ‚Äî a lot of eBook tools might save time, but they turn out terrible eCovers for your books. Sqribble is different here. The covers are seriously impressive. They wouldn‚Äôt look out of place on Kindle or Amazon, and they instantly look like you‚Äôre a professional who commands trust and authority.

Create Flipbooks ‚Äî this is one of my favorite things about Sqribble. You can turn your ‚Äúflat‚Äù books into interactive flipbooks. This makes your digital book look and feel much more like a real book ‚Äî with pages that turn (animated like a real book page turning) and make the book look like something you can reach out and grab.

Why does this matter?

It‚Äôs about standing out and grabbing attention. Plus, it‚Äôs a way to engage your readers better. If they enjoy the experience of reading your book (‚Äúflipping‚Äù the pages) they‚Äôre more likely to get value from your content and keep reading until the end where your pitch or call to action is! Another thing about flip books is that you can embed them on your website with a simple piece of code that Sqribble provides once you publish your book. Awesome!

What else can Sqribble do?

Sqribble is versatile tool, with tons more features I found useful. For example, here‚Äôs what else Sqribble can do:

‚Äî Automatic table of contents

‚Äî Automatic headers and footers

‚Äî Automatic pagination

‚Äî Drag and drop design

‚Äî Add or delete pages

‚Äî Add your own media

‚Äî 300+ Google Fonts

‚Äî 50 eBook templates (covering 15 different niches)

‚Äî 10 different eBook themes (1 click changes color scheme of book)

‚Äî Import content from a URL

‚Äî Manually add content

And that‚Äôs just the stuff I saw inside the dashboard!

There‚Äôs tons of features packed into this tool, making it one of the best eBook creators I‚Äôve seen, but there is one slight negative point which I‚Äôll cover down below.

Disclaimer: This post contains affiliate links. This means I may earn a commission should you chose to sign up for a program or make a purchase using my link. It‚Äôs okay ‚Äì I love all of these companies anyways, and you will too!

Sqribble is most suited for freelancers, independent internet marketers, small marketing agencies and small business owners who want to create lead magnets, publish Kindle books, create and sell eBooks, or publish whitepapers.

If you‚Äôre also looking to create an additional income you‚Äôll be pleased to know that also included is a commercial agency license to use Sqribble for client work, offering eBook creation services, with the ability to create unlimited eBooks which you can sell and keep all the profits!

They also give you a ready built agency website with pre-filled portfolio that you can upload to any domain for instant authority, so that you can show it off to any new potential clients to get work. (Professional websites like this would cost you at least $600 alone, so it‚Äôs really good value.)

Also included is an in-built ‚ÄúClient feedback tool‚Äù to collaborate with clients on eBook projects more easily (I love this feature).

What does it cost?

Normally $197, but the special launch price is a one-time $47.

Any upsells?

Yes, there are currently 4 upsells. You don‚Äôt really need all of them to use Sqribble, but they might come in useful depending on your situation and usage.

Upsell 1 ‚Äî Sqribble professional.

Unlock 150 more professional eBook templates (the best ones are in the professional version), graphics and even more ready ‚Äî made content for all kinds of niches. (Just so you know, single templates from stock websites would cost you up to $450‚Ä¶ for just ONE template!) Great for those that want more variety, content and heavy users.

Upsell 2 ‚Äî Sqribble Prime.

Get 15 premium ‚Äúlimited edition‚Äù new eBook templates added to your Sqribble dashboard every month. This will increase your library over time, and make you stand out from other users. It works out to less than two bucks for a template! (Much cheaper than stock sites.) Great for moderate users.

Upsell 3 ‚Äî Sqribble Fantasia 3D.

This includes 2-in-1 features.

1.) Unlocks a 3D cover creation tool inside your dashboard, allowing you to turn ‚Äúflat‚Äù covers into lifelike, 3d covers. Great for getting more attention and making your books look and feel more ‚Äúreal.‚Äù People do judge a book by its cover, so something to keep in mind.

2.) Create ‚ÄúFlipbooks‚Äù that turn your eBooks into interactive and animated pages that turn like in real life. They can be linked to from anywhere online, as well as embedded on web pages with a single piece of code. This is really cool.

Upsell 4 ‚Äî Auto Job Finder software.

If you‚Äôre going to be using Sqribble to create eBooks as a service to get paid, then Auto Job Finder is something that you need. It will automatically find you related jobs across various freelance websites and notify you so that you can fulfil them. A huge time saver and money earner.

The bad

‚Äî 3D cover is locked behind an upsell

The good

‚Äî Easy to use

‚Äî Glitch free

‚Äî Unlimited use (one-time payment)

The awesome

‚Äî Tons of beautiful templates

‚Äî Professional page layouts

‚Äî Automatic content (saves time)

‚Äî Flipbook creator (available through 3rd upsell)

There have been plenty of eBook creator tools in the past, but I haven‚Äôt seen any that make the entire process as smooth and quick as Sqribble. It‚Äôs surprisingly glitch free (most low-priced tools like this are buggy as hell) and it‚Äôs packed with some really cool features.

The templates are very nice looking, the layouts are professional and the fact you can automatically add content makes this a must have for anyone who‚Äôs tired of spending hours slaving over book design, writing content and screwing around with formatting.

The icing on the cake is the commercial license which is included. Normally vendors charge extra for this, so it‚Äôs a huge value added bonus. The additional provided done-for-you agency website is just over delivery.

Sqribble has been developed by Adeel Chowdhry, who is a well-known internet entrepreneur and best seller, with over ten years of experience and has previously created worldwide hits such as Pixel Studio FX which sold tens of thousands of units all around the world. He‚Äôs known for creating high quality professional solutions and I expect no less from Sqribble.

If you‚Äôre planning to create eBooks, reports or Kindle books in the near future, you owe it to yourself ‚Äî and your sanity ‚Äî to pick this up as it‚Äôs a tool that you‚Äôll definitely need in your business.

Disclaimer: This post contains affiliate links. This means I may earn a commission should you chose to sign up for a program or make a purchase using my link. It‚Äôs okay ‚Äì I love all of these companies anyways, and you will too!

title: Whatsapp needs to address the most important Usability Heuristic ‚Äî #1: Visibility of System Status
text:
In this story, I am going to illustrate a use case for Whatsapp mobile app and share an experience on how ‚ÄúVisibility of status‚Äù is very important for a product to be usable for ‚Äúall‚Äù users.

I really didn't feel good about what happened to one of my beloved family members while using this app and I spent some time reproducing and understanding the root cause for this use case.

The story of the person I am narrating is a 60-year-old retired government officer and a father of 2 daughters. He is not a tech-savvy person. He never uses the ‚ÄúWhatsapp status‚Äù feature. While he was on a FaceTime video call with his daughters, he wanted to forward a photo(confidential information) using Whatsapp on his iPhone. While attempting to forward this media, while on the Facetime Video call, he accidentally happened to select the ‚ÄúMy status‚Äù option. Due to this, the confidential information was uploaded as his status and unfortunately exposed to all his contacts.

What motivates the user to use ‚ÄúWhatsapp on mobile‚Äù?

To keep in touch with his daughters, who live overseas. To share memorable pictures and videos with his daughters. Stay in touch with family and friends.

Decode

Started to think about various options of how one can share any kind of media while they are simultaneously on a ‚ÄúFacetime Video‚Äù call. Refer ‚Äî Use other apps during a FaceTime call on iPhone

Steps to reproduce.

Call one of your friends using the Facetime video call.

Once the Facetime video call has been answered, open the WhatsApp application and let the Facetime‚Äôs video bubble stay to the top right.

Note ‚Äî one can use other apps during a FaceTime or Whatsapp Video call on iPhone.

Now, open one of your Whatsapp chats/conversations with your friend, lookup for any media that was shared with you.

Once we long press on the media, we see the menu that holds an option ‚ÄúForward‚Äù. Select ‚ÄúForward‚Äù and click on the ‚Äúforward icon‚Äù to the bottom left.

The user now is redirected to a screen to make a selection from a list of active contacts within the WhatsApp application. This list also includes the ‚ÄúWhatsapp Status‚Äù.

1. In the previous screen, there are 2 important things to notice that lack ‚ÄúVisibility of Status‚Äù to the user. The selection circle for the first 3 contacts is hidden behind the Facetime video bubble to the top right.

2. Before the user performs the primary action to ‚Äúforward‚Äù the user does not have visibility on the count of the selections made on the current screen.

Possible Solution(s)

How can we solve this use case to meet the usability heuristic ‚Äî Visibility of System Status?

I brainstormed a couple of ideas and came up with the below 2 possible design solutions to address the use case to make users‚Äô flow intuitive and not to leave them in a chaotic situation that they might never notice.

Design 1

title: Knowhere Creator: Democratizing NFT creation on Terra blockchain
text:
Introducing artist-friendly, no-code NFT minter on the Terra blockchain

Artist: apply for an invitation code here to list your NFT on Knowhere.art marketplace.

Welcome

Welcome to digital art‚Äôs last frontier, a dimension both near and far filled with wonder and awe ‚Äî a place called Knowhere

This Terra NFT marketplace has been transformed from an empty place in the vacuum of space into a bustling digital art hub ‚Äî filled with the colors of the cosmos & the stunning potential of man to create.

Introduction to Knowhere Creator (beta)

In order to attract more artists into the Terra blockchain, we wanted to lower the entry barrier for creators to the NFT space. We created Knowhere Creator, a customized NFT creator portal, designed with an artist-friendly and simple-to-use UI. Allowing anyone and everyone to mint their creative works without writing a single line of code.

Let‚Äôs dive into how it works.

Knowhere Creator (beta) Tutorial

You will be able to use the creator portal once you receive your Artist Invitation Code. Currently, Knowhere Creator is in beta, so we will slowly distribute the amount of creator code over time. You can get your invitation code by applying from this Google Form.

Navigate to https://creator.knowhere.art to input your code & connect your wallet.

Input the invitation code and connect your wallet

2. Before you create your individual NFT, you need to first create a Collection that NFT belongs to. Create a collection to start listing your NFTs.

Select Create Collection

3. Input your Collection Details, add a Profile and a Cover photo. The dimensions are as follows:

Collection Name: This is the name of your Collection

This is the name of your Collection Description : This is the description of the Collection (recommended to be < 140 characters)

: This is the description of the Collection (recommended to be < 140 characters) Profile/Logo of the collection : 400 x 400 square png/jpg image

: 400 x 400 square png/jpg image Cover photo: 1340 x 320 png/jpg image

Fill in your collection name, descriptions and upload logo and cover photo

4. Metadata and Rarity border: before you add individual NFTs, you can choose if you would like to add metadata or rarity

Rarity : If you choose to have a rarity system for your collection, there will be 6 different levels of rarities to choose from. You can toggle active your rarity in the Additional Setting section

: If you choose to have a rarity system for your collection, there will be 6 different levels of rarities to choose from. You can toggle active your rarity in the Additional Setting section Properties: To add additional metadata, you can toggle Properties. Here you can add all the available ‚Äòkeys‚Äô, such as headwear ‚Äî for pfp NFTs, weapons ‚Äî for spaceships, or backgrounds. For each ‚Äòkeys‚Äô, you will also need to add all the possible ‚Äòvalues‚Äô that any NFTs can have. You can create up to 20 metadata ‚Äòkeys‚Äô.

5. Collection has been created ‚Äî navigate to ‚ÄòCreate NFT‚Äô bottom right of the portal to create (multiple) NFTs of that collection.

Select Create NFT button on the bottom right

6. Upload the images you wanted to mint as NFTs via the Knowhere Creator Portal. A maximum of 30 images can be uploaded each time, with a maximum of 100 images per collection. You can create more NFTs under the same collection by repeating this step after submitting each bulk for review. Knowhere Creator currently supports Images and GIFs.

Upload your images to be used as an NFT

7. Metadata and rarity filling: Once images are uploaded, you will need to fill in the name and description of each NFT, as well as choose one of the values for each key listed in step 4. You can click save when you are ready to submit for review.

Fill in the metadata, select the values for each keys, and submit it for review

8. Submit to review: Once you save, the minting request will be submitted to the Knowhere team to review. You can check the status of the approval on the review page. Please note that, at this step, the NFT is not yet minted.

If you wish to create more NFTs for the same collection, you can simply create another set of NFTs under the same collection as per step 6.

9. Minting your NFTs: Once approved, in the ‚ÄòWaiting to mint‚Äô tab, you will be able to click create NFT contract, this will automatically create a contract for your NFT collection.

Click ‚ÄòCreate NFT contract‚Äô

Once the contract is created, when in the ‚ÄòWaiting to mint‚Äô tab, the ‚ÄòCreate NFT Contract‚Äô button will disappear. Please note that after NFT Contract is created, you will no longer be able to change the collection name, rarity, as well as keys and values list of metadata.

‚ÄòWaiting to mint‚Äô > ‚ÄòCreate NFT contract‚Äô button disappeared

You will then be able to select mint for your NFTs, and then Voila! Your NFT will be minted in your wallet. (Make sure that you have some UST for the gas for minting). You can select the ‚ÄòStart Selling‚Äô button to go directly to your ‚ÄòMy NFT‚Äô page on Knowhere.art.

Visit Knowhere.art > Connect your wallet > My Profile > My NFT

Or, you will be able to see your NFT on the Knowhere website, by connecting your Terra Station wallet, and selecting ‚ÄòMy Profile‚Äô > ‚ÄòMy NFT‚Äô. You can manage your NFT on this page, whether it's transferring them to another wallet, or listing them for sale on Knowhere.art

‚ÄòTransfer NFT‚Äô to other wallets, or ‚ÄòSell this NFT‚Äô to make them available for sale

10. Selling your NFT: You can list your NFT for sale under 2 different modes: ‚ÄòAuction‚Äô and ‚ÄòBuy it Now‚Äô. Note that you will need some UST in your wallet as the transaction gas cost.

Auctions : You will be able to set a minimum price for your NFT, the auction will start once anyone places a bid, and will last for 24 hours.

: You will be able to set a minimum price for your NFT, the auction will start once anyone places a bid, and will last for 24 hours. Buy it now: This is the fixed price option, anyone would be able to purchase this NFT at a fixed price that you‚Äôve specified. This option can be triggered if you select the check box when listing.

You can also choose to delist your NFT from the sale, provided that no one has placed any bids on your NFT yet.

Interested in Listing your Art on Knowhere?

We are always looking for new artists to join our community. Join the first NFT Marketplace on Terra Blockchain by using the Knowhere Creator and begin today.

Artists can apply for an invitation code to our Knowhere Creator by filling this Google Form.

DISCORD: https://discord.gg/QZpUznVftV

TWITTER: @knowhere_art

INSTAGRAM: @art.knowhere

TELEGRAM: https://t.me/Knowhereart

WEBSITE: https://knowhere.art/

FAQs

How do I request a creator code? please apply for a code by filling this Google Form.

Does Knowhere charge any fees to list? for the initial launch phase, this will be available free of charge with exception of the minting gas cost. The fee structure will be introduced at a later date, please follow us on Twitter for more information. There will be a default platform fee of 2% applied to all transactions on Knowhere.art.

Can I list multiple NFTs at a time using the Creator? Once a collection is created, you can bulk upload 30 images/gifs at a time for review. You can repeat the same process once submitted to up to 100 maximum NFTs per collection.

How to get a collection featured on the platform? Currently, the featured collection on Knowhere‚Äôs front page is selected manually. We may shift this towards a more decentralized process in the future.

Does Knowhere Creator work with candy machines / randomized minter? This is something we are working on and may be available in the near future.

Can I set up royalties for secondary sales for my collection? Yes, this process is currently still being done manually. Please contact the Knowhere team via Telegram, Twitter, or Discord.

title: 4 Best Practices I Recommend When Deciding On Which NFT Project To Invest In
text:
4 Best Practices I Recommend When Deciding On Which NFT Project To Invest In Mohammed Machraoui Dec 30, 2021¬∑3 min read

NFT Shopping 101

When deciding which NFT project is suitable for you, you should ask a lot of questions. This, like investing in cryptocurrency, is heavily dependent on your unique strategy. Today, we‚Äôll look at some best practices for NFT shopping.

Which Blockchain?

When deciding which NFT to purchase, one of the first things you should consider is the blockchain on which it is constructed. This year has seen a slew of blockchains emerge to compete with Ethereum.

When it comes to overall NFT volume, Ethereum is by far the clubhouse leader. The majority of new and existing A-List projects are hosted on ETH. During the peak of 2021 NFT hype, we saw a number of chains emerge to compete with ETH by offering lower gas/transaction costs.

Cardano, WAX, Solana, and Binance are other prominent chains. These are just a few examples of the numerous options available.

What Type of NFT?

The next step in purchasing your NFT is determining which type to purchase. That can be a little perplexing, but what I mean is what utility your new NFT will have.

NFTs were first as simple as a profile picture (PFP). CryptoPunks is a prime example of this, and they are among the most expensive NFT to acquire. It doesn‚Äôt hurt that they were among the earliest NFTs. Not to add, Visa purchased one in August.

When Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) released its soon-to-be blue-chip NFT, they changed up the utility element. When you bought your BAYC in April, you also got unique access to their Club. Fast forward eight months, and it has grown into a very elite Club to be a part of. The most intriguing aspect is that this ‚ÄúClub‚Äù includes some of the most different members. Steph Curry, Post Malone, Jimmy Fallon, Logan Paul, and others are among the members you may be familiar with.

Because time passes at warp speed in the NFT universe, the utility of contemporary NFTs is limitless. Virtual real estate inside The Sandbox, Decentraland, and other platforms appears to be popular right now. The same goes with play-to-earn games. As with most things in crypto, most of this is speculative, which is why having a strategy is essential.

You‚Äôll be much better prepared to go shopping once you‚Äôve decided on the chain and type of NFT you want. But now that you‚Äôve done all of that legwork, which NFT should you get?

Best Practices?

It‚Äôs never easy to predict whether NFT will be the next BAYC or your winning lottery ticket. However, there are certain general recommended practices to follow while investing.

The following are some common measures to take:

Community: As we frequently preach here, community is HUGE. Discord discussions and social media might provide insight into a potential investment‚Äôs community. Helpful community members are essential, particularly in the early phases of a project.

As we frequently preach here, community is HUGE. Discord discussions and social media might provide insight into a potential investment‚Äôs community. Helpful community members are essential, particularly in the early phases of a project. Leadership: Investigate who started the initiative and what their plan is. Is this a money grab for someone, or do they have a strategy that is similar to yours? Every hour, a new NFT project is launched, so the project‚Äôs leaders are crucial. Especially if you‚Äôre putting your own money into the endeavor.

Investigate who started the initiative and what their plan is. Is this a money grab for someone, or do they have a strategy that is similar to yours? Every hour, a new NFT project is launched, so the project‚Äôs leaders are crucial. Especially if you‚Äôre putting your own money into the endeavor. Roadmap: What is their plan when the initial FOMO subsides? It is normal for a project to start and then lose traction due to a lack of a defined plan for their community. A roadmap should outline the strategy and provide an overview of how they intend to carry out their main ideas. It‚Äôs always a fluid scenario, and things may change rapidly, which is why the project‚Äôs leadership is critical.

What is their plan when the initial FOMO subsides? It is normal for a project to start and then lose traction due to a lack of a defined plan for their community. A roadmap should outline the strategy and provide an overview of how they intend to carry out their main ideas. It‚Äôs always a fluid scenario, and things may change rapidly, which is why the project‚Äôs leadership is critical. Does It Make Sense: When considering an NFT investment, it‚Äôs essential that the project makes sense to YOU. Can you see the long-term goal coming to fruition, can you imagine additional people wanting to invest in this initiative, and so on? There is no correct or incorrect response, but the more information you have, the better.

Maybe this is the year you receive your first NFT?

title: How to Buy NFT on Rivernity
text:
The popularity of NFT as a digital asset has increased in recent years. NFT is one of the most popular digital art buying and selling trends in 2021. The total NFT sales from 2020 to 2021 have increased by 55 percent, from US$250 million to US$389 million. NFT collectors are even willing to spend millions of dollars on a range of collectibles that includes artwork, video clips, music, and so on in digital format.

Non-fungible tokens, or NFTs for short, are digital assets such as artwork, paintings, music, in-game items, and other types of work that can be collected and considered valuable. NFTs are like any other physical collector‚Äôs item. NFTs are traded online and use cryptocurrencies during the transaction process. The price of NFT that is traded is determined by the artist or content creator selling it.

How to Buy NFT on Rivernity?

If you intend to collect unique NFT assets for fun purposes or make a profit by selling them at a higher price, you can do it easily on Rivernity. Although relatively new, Rivernity has full features and lots of interesting offers. On Rivernity, NFT purchases can be made using Vex coin (VEX).

Here‚Äôs how to buy NFT on Rivernity that you can do easily.

1. Create a Vex Wallet

Before buying NFT, you must first have a Vex Wallet and connect it to Rivernity‚Äôs NFT marketplace platform.

2. Search NFT Collection

To view the available NFT collections, you can click the ‚ÄúMarket‚Äù menu to browse the images or objects offered at Rivernity.

3. Take Benefit of The Listing Menu

On Rivernity, there is also a menu listing available. With the ‚ÄúListing‚Äù feature, you can set options for selecting the object you want to search for. You can choose the latest artwork or based on the price category offered.

4. Buy NFT

Getting NFT on Rivernity is the same as on other NFT marketplaces. After you click the ‚ÄúBuy‚Äù button and follow the required steps, you will get NFT immediately after paying a certain amount of crypto for the asset. In addition, you can also click the ‚ÄúMake Offer‚Äù button if the NFT price is too high and you want to make an offer to the seller to sell the NFT at a lower price.

Suppose you have done the four steps above, congratulations! You have successfully obtained NFT. Not complicated, right? To view the NFT you have purchased, go to your profile menu and select the ‚ÄúIn Wallet‚Äù menu. Well, that‚Äôs how to buy and get NFT on Rivernity. So are you ready to have your first NFT?
