And I‚Äôve been working for almost 12 years to close that gap and I‚Äôm seeing good progress, but you know, this is going to take a long time because we‚Äôve had a century of people discounting native thinking, the left brain, which is the analytical brain acts that bully the other side of the brain. It‚Äôs smart enough to be a bully. Whereas creative people tend to not be bullied. They‚Äôre open they‚Äôre everything. They‚Äôre open to experience their brains. Don‚Äôt work that way. That‚Äôs another reason that creativity has been kind of blocked in a lot of companies, but now it‚Äôs quite different in companies are actively looking for creative people. And now we‚Äôve got to create real progress and business.

1. Differentiate

‚ÄçArek Dvornechuck:

Bending is the process of connecting good strategy with good creativity that brings to talking about those five disciplines of branding, right? So starting with discipline, number one, which is differentiate. So here you talk about three basic questions that we need to find compelling us to be in order to build a charismatic brand, right? So those three questions are, who are you? What do you do? And why does it matter? And as you say in your book, and I also have experienced that with my clients, that most companies have trouble us reading them, especially the second and the third one. So why does it matter? That could be a quite problematic question to us where, so can you talk to us a bit about this first discipline and perhaps give us some examples of sort of brands. The three

Marty Neumeier:

Questions are about three different aspects of a business. Who are you? What do you do as a matter, why are you is who are the founders of the group? Why are they doing it? What‚Äôs their passion, their passion do this. What‚Äôs the vision of this company. You know what, what‚Äôs the purpose of this company in a broader context, you know, beyond making money, what are they trying to do? People want to know that? So that‚Äôs really important. Second question is pretty easy. It‚Äôs what business are you in? In other words, what is the category that you‚Äôre selling? Oh, it‚Äôs a retail bank. Oh, well, we sell, you know, the software or, you know, whatever it is, you need to know where you‚Äôre playing, what you know, name, the playing field that you‚Äôre on. So that‚Äôs pretty easy. The last question is hard. Why does it matter? That‚Äôs really getting at the definition of a brand. Why does it matter to customer? Why should they care? Why should they choose you over a competitor? The answer to that one is usually rooted. Different customers have to see you as different in some important way that does something right, that they want. If you‚Äôre the only one, they have no choice, but to come to you and pay whatever you want to charge, if they can afford it, if they see that you‚Äôre the only one and they can‚Äôt afford it, you know, maybe someday they will, they‚Äôll go someplace else because they can‚Äôt afford the best, but they definitely have an idea of what‚Äôs the best. And that‚Äôs very valuable for a company to be seen as is the best at something. And typically the best isn‚Äôt about doing higher quality products or services that doing something different and being seen as the only in that industry for your customers. And then they‚Äôll do anything to have that, to choose that product service over the other ones. So you have to have that. So differentiation is the basis of any good brand without that you‚Äôre stuck. You‚Äôre not going to go anywhere.

Arek Dvornechuck:

‚ÄçRight. Also it‚Äôs about specialization here, right? It‚Äôs about being super focused and also, right. You should be number one in your car to go to any, if you cannot then, you know, define another category, right? So

Marty Neumeier:

If you‚Äôre, if you‚Äôre number one or number two, or maybe number three, if you‚Äôre number five or number seven in the ranking, in your customer‚Äôs mind, the only way you can win is by just suffering. You know, just getting lucky and making a few sales or lowering your price so that you can compete. That‚Äôs not a good thing to do. So if you‚Äôre lowering your price just to compete, that‚Äôs your branding. Uh, you should be different enough where you don‚Äôt have to lower your price. So if yourself below lowering your price, been a customer, then go back to where one you‚Äôre out, your differentiation be more different in some way, it was finding a niche, finding some space that you can own. It‚Äôs important to customers, enough customers to build a business on.

2. Collaborate

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right. Okay. So the second discipline, uh, we‚Äôre going to talk about is collaborate, right? So can you talk about how brands are built and why collaboration models and basically the premise of this, the second discipline is that it takes collaboration to build a brand. So it‚Äôs just not about executives and marketing people who manage the brand, but also are all sort of, you know, the, uh, specialists like strategy consultants, design, funerals, PR firms, advertising agencies, industrial designers, and so on. Branding requires a team of specialists. They‚Äôre sharing ideas and working together towards a common goal. So can you just talk to us a bit about this second discipline? Yeah. So

Marty Neumeier:

Collaboration requires people, right? Like with any, you don‚Äôt want everybody to have the same skill. Well, nobody‚Äôs going to have all the skills. You don‚Äôt want a football team, or every player is a kicker, right? Passers and whatever, or you‚Äôre blank. You want variety on your team and you want every player on the team to go really deep into something, to be really expert at something and probably not very expert at other things. So that means you need to collaborate. So, you know, so it‚Äôs those two things go together, specialize and collaborate. So you become a specialist and work with other people, uh, in the capacity that, you know, best. If you‚Äôre a graphic designer, you want to be the graphic designer on the team, right? If you‚Äôre a business consulting firm, you want to be the business consulting firm or that team. So everybody needs to specialize and then they can work together. So a good example is, uh, he would works on a collaborative model. So Hollywood is just a big industry where you have a lot of specialists. You have actors, you have directors, you have set designers, you have sound people. You have, you have artists who work on backgrounds and you, you know, just like hundreds of people, you you‚Äôve sat in a movie and watched all the credits and you go, how can so many people work together on one two-hour movie? I mean, it‚Äôs thousands of people. Well, because that‚Äôs what it takes. And this is the same with the brand. A big brand takes quite a bit of people somewhere on the inside of the company. Some are on the outside. And so what you do is you build a big team to make that movie. And when the movie is done, large park team, go back to their businesses and they go and do a movie for somebody else. They just, they go back into their, uh, their, their specialties and get another client. So that‚Äôs the sensor bill too. So someone has to orchestrate all that too. You know, I mean, that‚Äôs a lot of P two. And so you need new ways to do that. You need like brand Bree. You need someone to manage the whole project. You need team managers, you need a lot of coordination. And so if you don‚Äôt know how to that, or you‚Äôve never worked on a team successfully, probably not gonna get a chance to, because you know, you have to sort of work your way into this, this knowledge out of work with people. And when you, when people find out you‚Äôre a really good collaborator, they‚Äôll want you on their team in the, but it‚Äôs not something that‚Äôs taught in design school or in business school, how to collaborate. It‚Äôs just not. So that‚Äôs one of the teaching in our first course or brand or class masterclass one. So that‚Äôs the importance of that. No brands are built by one person.

3. Innovate

Arek Dvornechuck:

Okay. So, uh, and the next discipline is innovate. So here we talk about the importance of execution. So if you have good strategy, but poor execution is not going to work, as you mentioned at the beginning. So in this part, you talk about innovation that it requires creativity, which means thinking fresh ways, right? So can you just give us an overview of this third discipline and how you see that? Yeah.

Marty Neumeier:

‚ÄçIt‚Äôs really important not to do what everybody else is doing. And what‚Äôs hard about that is most of us, the way we learn is by imitating other people, right? We see somebody do something and then we go, I can do that. And we practice a bit and we get good at it. And we admire people‚Äôs skills. And so we want to have those skills too. And that‚Äôs great. That‚Äôs good for learning, craft, whatever you‚Äôre learning. You know, you have to learn by watching other people, but to succeed in a brand situation, you have to go further than that. And then you have to do something that‚Äôs never been done before. A lot. You have to do a lot of that. You have to always be thinking in fresh ways. You don‚Äôt have to be completely innovative, but you need to be at least fresh. You need to surprise people. Surprises is half the battle. And branding is surprising customers with what you create, what you say, all those kinds of things surprise them in a good way, because if there‚Äôs no surprise, they understand that there‚Äôs not anything new here. If there‚Äôs nothing new, there can‚Äôt be anything really valuable that they‚Äôll want to pay for here. If there‚Äôs nothing valuable, then you‚Äôre a, basically a commodity and you have to lower your price. So, um, being surprising in the right way is really important. So that‚Äôs what innovation does for branding. And it can do it at the product level. At the messaging level, at the business model level, innovation is super important. And yet it‚Äôs, again, not something that‚Äôs taught in school as a subject, and it should be because without it, you‚Äôre just not going to build an important company, right? You‚Äôre just not, you‚Äôre going to be a commoditized company where you‚Äôre selling your products on price. You have to do something different, but of course you can be different and not be good, right? There‚Äôs a lot of different things that are just bad. And that‚Äôs probably why they‚Äôre different. There has to be different and good. Those two things have to come together. When you can put those two things together, you‚Äôve got the basis of a very strong offering where you find that kind of thinking is in the creative arena, you don‚Äôt find it so much in business schools. You know, business schools teach you to mitigate risk, to play it safe, to protect the company, to keep it running smoothly, like, like piloting a ship between reefs. You gotta be really careful. Don‚Äôt wreck the ship. That‚Äôs a lot of what, uh, an MBA teaches you to do. Design school teaches you to go right for what customers love and create some experience for them. That‚Äôs magic. So that‚Äôs way different than what you learn in business school, but you need both to create a very strong brand. So that‚Äôs logic plus magic,

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right? And the, also in this part, in the book, just for you guys, really give us principles for coming up with a good brand name. What are the qualities of a good brand name? You talk also about icons, packaging, web designers, so on. So if you guys want to learn more, I invite you to check out the book.

Marty Neumeier:

‚ÄçSo my background is in design. That‚Äôs all I ever wanted to be when I was younger, just as a designer, I started moving into branding because I realized that design is not very powerful on its own. It‚Äôs only powerful when it connects with something that matters to businesses and branding is that area where design and business success overlap. So that‚Äôs why you want to be in branding and not just design. If you‚Äôre a designer, understanding how brands work will make your work so much more powerful and give you access to better projects, because you‚Äôre thinking in a way that matters to a business. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that all the other stuff you do, isn‚Äôt super important. All that craft stuff that you do, all that quality that you put into everything really important. And don‚Äôt ever cut back on that. There‚Äôs such a need for that, but it‚Äôs just, if you want the best projects and the most influence in the world, connect your design work to branding,

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right? So that‚Äôs for, for you guys go on to become strategist. And, and I can definitely relate to that because all I wanted to do when I started, when I was 16, I just wanted to design and I love designing. But as you already mentioned, design on its own, it doesn‚Äôt give you that much power. You actually need to get to know how business people think and to be able to explain some of your creative choices and work with them. So I really appreciate you and all the content you‚Äôre putting out to teach us as designers and open our minds and learn how actually branding works. You know how we should combine strategy with design, right? Not just,

Marty Neumeier:

If you want to be a strategist, you don‚Äôt have to be a strategist, have to be a designer who understands strategy. So you know how to contribute to the whole project in a way that really makes a difference. And also it allows you to get better work because you can talk about it, right? If you can talk about strategy and how your work is strategic, oh, it probably will double the value of your work. At least the perceived value with customers. And so that‚Äôs what a lot of designers never, they just want to do the work and they don‚Äôt understand why they never getting the best projects and other people are getting them that maybe those other people aren‚Äôt even very good designers. Well, they‚Äôre probably not, not, but they‚Äôre probably understanding something that you don‚Äôt about how business works, right? So you just don‚Äôt want to let them take the stage when you should be on the stage, you should be the one doing it. If you‚Äôre the better designer, you need to have those jobs, not those other people who don‚Äôt know how to design all they have is some information about business. So just don‚Äôt let that happen a lot about this so that you can elbow them offstage,

4. Validate

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right? So you don‚Äôt have to be a strategist, but you should be a strategic designer. Okay. So the discipline number four is to validate, right? So we need to violate our ideas and turn our, while the gases into more educated ones. So whether it is about new packaging or a brand name, you talk in this part about validating ideas and getting feedback, right? And there are different ways, you know, quantitative studies research and qualitative research. And I know that the premise of this part is that quantitative studies, they just lead to like analysis paralysis and small improvements, and at least have a lack of courage. And this is something we‚Äôve talked about earlier. So focus groups, they don‚Äôt bring best results. And you would actually advise us to do more of qualitative research quick and dirty and one-on-one interviews. And you also present us with different tools, select swap tests, test the concept, test the field test and so on. And so if you could just talk about some of those tools so we can understand the concept.

Marty Neumeier:

Well, I started learning about these because I was asked to way back in the late eighties, when I was doing a huge project for apple redesigning all their software packaging, they had their own software company because in the beginning there weren‚Äôt enough diverse apple had to start. They had to get the ball rolling by putting out their own, super into the company. It‚Äôs the make or break part of the company. And because I had decided to specialize that word again, right? I differentiated my company, specialized in software packaging for retail. I got the job. And part of it in the process of designing all this, I was asked by the president to test these designs because there was a difference of opinion on which designs were going to work the best, and they really needed these packages to sell. And so I course will have to figure out like, what are all these, oh, you know, what‚Äôs possible. And that led to a huge awakening for me to the power of testing, to better design, not to hold back to them, but to lead you into directions that you would never be able to go because you just didn‚Äôt have the insights or couldn‚Äôt convince the client or the bot to go along with your idea, because it was too bold, right? So bold ideas get shot down in the absence of proof. If you can‚Äôt prove your bold ideas going to work, then who‚Äôs going to take you up on that. That‚Äôd be crazy. So you have to be able to test your prototypes, prove that something is going to work, and then you get permission to do something amazing, but you have to prove it. So how do you do that? I‚Äôm just a designer or, you know, what do I know? Well, I found out I didn‚Äôt have to be a professional researcher to get this job done, to satisfy even a client as sophisticated as apple. I just had to have something. And so we started just testing packaging in a store in various stores and found out all kinds of things. People didn‚Äôt know about packaging software and all kinds of things. People didn‚Äôt know about design, even designers because designers never test their work. They just like, oh, I just thought it would be cool. So I did it well. Um, yeah, it can be cool, but you want to know whether it‚Äôs going to work or not in the marketplace before you spent and millions of dollars on it or hundreds or whatever, you know, whatever level you‚Äôre on. You want to, I don‚Äôt know if this is going to work or be a waste of money. So the testing is the answer to that. And focus groups is kind of like the common answer you say, oh, we‚Äôre going to test these designs. And people say, oh, focus groups. You know, they love to say focus groups, focus groups are easy to put on. You go to a firm and they got a room. You can stand behind the glass. And the people in the groups can see you and you can listen to all this stuff. And it‚Äôs just all a bunch of opinions, right? I mean, it‚Äôs its own focus groups were invented to focus research. So it‚Äôs a way to find out what‚Äôs important about a brand. I‚Äôm going to find out what people are thinking. Then we‚Äôll focus our research on that, that thing. It‚Äôs not a method of choosing the best design. You know, it‚Äôs not, it‚Äôs horrible for that. So what you have to do is create situations where customers can see whatever you‚Äôre doing in a realistic situation, as realistic as possible. And you have to ask the right questions. One-on-one not in a group for patterns, look for patterns in what they say. And if you do this as the creative person or a strategist, you‚Äôre going to go, oh, that‚Äôs what happening here. Okay. See how they‚Äôre thinking about it. And you‚Äôll learn things that you‚Äôve never would have guessed. And so you get insights from this, and then you go back to the drawing board and you do better work because now you know what people are thinking. And when you do that, your work can be two, three times as powerful as just winging it. The other thing it does, if you have a creative firm or you‚Äôre a freelancer or whatever that, you know, you‚Äôre running your own business, you can get work based on your ability to test your own work. Like if that‚Äôs built into it, it‚Äôs like I always test my own work. And that part of the price is that, yes, the price is higher. But when you work with me, you get a proven result. You feel confident about what we‚Äôre doing. So it‚Äôs not my opinion of what‚Äôs best. It‚Äôs not your opinion of what‚Äôs best. Neither of us has the answer. The answer lives with customers because, you know, they say it is right. It‚Äôs not what you say it is. It‚Äôs what they say it is. We need to find out how they‚Äôre receiving our work before we finalize it. Very simple. And nobody does it, but I‚Äôve been doing this for 30 years and there‚Äôs no way I do a significant project without testing various parts of it, because I really do want to be successful.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right. I think that what‚Äôs really interesting here is those different tests, right? Like swap tests and test the concept tests and so on. So for example, just for your guys here, listening here is here, for example, one of those tests, right? So we have the, the nationwide and Polaroid and I happened to ward on the rebrand of nationwide. So basically I worked with Jeremiah and Geismar as a designer. So if you can swap the name, any part of the logo. Right. And if it looks, yeah. If it works better for another company, can‚Äôt be as

Marty Neumeier:

Good as possible. Isn‚Äôt right. Because it‚Äôs better just by using somebody else‚Äôs symbol. Right. So you know that yours isn‚Äôt good. It should be perfect for that company. When you‚Äôre doing that, love, it should work for nobody else. Nobody else would be able to use that symbol or that

Arek Dvornechuck:

Name. Exactly. So does the swab test and another, for example, hand test where you basically, if you cover the logo and you can still recognize the brand by messaging, by tone of voice by, you know, all the visuals, that‚Äôs a good sign, but if you cannot, that‚Äôs a bad sign, right? You don‚Äôt

Marty Neumeier:

Want to have to depend on a logo to do all the work. Logos are super important. Probably the most, the logo and the name are the most important touch point of a brand, but they don‚Äôt carry all the way. There are elements, important elements, and they have to be right, but you shouldn‚Äôt expect them to do it everything. Right. That‚Äôs very old school. It‚Äôs like, let‚Äôs just get a good logo and a good name and be consistent with all the colors. And we‚Äôre done branding does that, maybe it was okay back in the fifties, but the definition of a brand has changed. The understanding of a brand has grown quite a bit. So we know that there are many other important touch points also.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Okay. Okay. So let‚Äôs talk about the last discipline, which is called Evert. So here you point out that our business is a process is a living. Organism is not an entity. So can you talk about consistency versus inconsistency or imperfection, which I think is really interesting. So can you just talk about this last discipline and what do you mean by consistency versus inconsistency and imperfection? Why we should strive for perfection? Always since

Marty Neumeier:

‚ÄçIt takes a lot of collaboration to build a brand, you really need to build your whole company around your brand. The company should be built and organized to support that brand. This is where a lot of companies fall down and they haven‚Äôt figured that out yet. Like the brand is the most important thing. And we need everybody to work on that brand. I don‚Äôt care what department they‚Äôre in. Finance included. You have to be very aware of the main asset of a company and for successful companies, that brand is more than half of the value of the company. This is really important, right? So you need to build the whole culture around it. So this is kind of like something that happens between the CEO and human relations, you know, somewhere in there and organization designers have to be in on all this stuff. The other point that you mentioned was that a brand doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect. It‚Äôs true. I mean, in fact, perfection is boring. Who wants that? What they want to see is a real life thing. They want to see some humanity in a brand. So that means you can make mistakes and maybe it‚Äôs okay to make mistakes. But what do you do when you have a mistake? You apologize, you admit your mistake, you apologize for it. And you fix it publicly. That doesn‚Äôt make you a weaker culture that makes you a stronger culture. Brewers will love you. If you have a problem or make a mistake and you apologize and fix it, then they start to see that you‚Äôre real. You‚Äôre relatable. It‚Äôs these companies that never admit mistakes. And everything‚Äôs perfect. It‚Äôs like, who wants to be involved with that? It‚Äôs like, it‚Äôs like, if you have, if you got a friend who acted like that, you wouldn‚Äôt feel very close to that friend. You would just say, this person is very private and impenetrable. I don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre thinking. It‚Äôs hard for me to relate to this person, consistency, which used to be how you built a brand is you‚Äôve got a logo and some callers and messaging and you always stay on brand. You never change. Right? You just like, you just pound on that thing through advertising and repetition. Well, that doesn‚Äôt really make sense anymore. If you‚Äôre trying to be a living thing, it‚Äôs okay. If your logo isn‚Äôt the same every time, or you have different ways of showing up, as long as it doesn‚Äôt confuse anybody, as long as they know it‚Äôs you, that only helps. Right? I mean, there are companies that change their logo lock have 15 different logos, but they‚Äôre all part of the set that they use and kind of a feeling that they have. And people love that. You know, it depends on what kind of company it is. I don‚Äôt expect IBM to be changing their logo for every particular use, but I don‚Äôt mind it for Nickelodeon. I don‚Äôt mind it for MailChimp. You know, they have the Chimp and the Chimp is different every time. It‚Äôs just great. It‚Äôs just better. Designers can relax about that. The main thing is that you‚Äôre creating a character, you‚Äôre building a character, building the company into a character and characters have flaws. They do some things well of the things they don‚Äôt do. Well, BMW is all about precision and kind of snobby approach to driving. You know, like we‚Äôre the best, the most sophisticated, but you don‚Äôt see the ultimate driving machine, but you don‚Äôt expect BMW to show a lot of empathy, you know, for people and neither do the drivers, right? At least in the U S are they drive faster than everyone? Well, the rules don‚Äôt apply to them. They‚Äôre arrogant in a sense, but that‚Äôs one of the flaws that you put up with, if you want to be that brand that, you know, that‚Äôs, that‚Äôs that character, the flaws, just make it more interesting. I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily try to be perfect. I would try to be something. I would try to be a definable character that everyone can understand and relate to and care about. They have to care about this company, like what happens to, to want the company to win right. For them if the company wins.

5. Cultivate

‚ÄçArek Dvornechuck:

So that‚Äôs what it means when you say our brand is a living organism. Okay. So as we are approaching the end of our interview, can you just let us know either for designers who want to learn more from, I know that you organize workshops and seminars. So maybe for designers who want to get certified brand strategists or for entrepreneurs and business owners who want to work with you, how can we get in touch with you?

Marty Neumeier:

Yes. Thing is to go on and buys one or more of my books. They‚Äôre easy to read there. They take to read a book and you‚Äôll be reading them probably for years and years, going back to them, that‚Äôs the way I have designed them. So that‚Äôs the first thing. And for people that already know my books and want to go further, they can get involved in the level C program, levelc.org. And it‚Äôs a five tier learning program for people who want to be expert in branding, right? So it‚Äôs about brand mastery. You have to work your way up from the bottom to the karate school. We‚Äôll be having other sorts of classes also besides the five main ones. But those are the ones that are going to take you to the level you want to go. And those that are available, I mean, we used to do these only in person like in London and Los Angeles and Philadelphia, places like that. But because of the pandemic, we started doing them online and they‚Äôre very popular online. So, um, it‚Äôs, it makes it easy for people to attend these things. You know, when the pandemic goes away, we‚Äôll be doing live and we‚Äôll always be doing the online ones too, because it‚Äôs a great experience. They like it lasts a week. It‚Äôs just two days and you, it tends to be a little evolving. So that‚Äôs, I would look at, see, you know, if you‚Äôre interested for masterclass one and see what‚Äôs where that takes you. So everything we talked about today is in masterclass one. So masterclass one based on The Brand Gap, masterclass two is advanced strategy. And that goes deeper into differentiation. This is for people that strategist at least have a strategy component to their work. And so, but you have to take masterclass one first. Right?

Arek Dvornechuck:

‚ÄçOkay. So I‚Äôm going to include those links to your website in the description. So thank you so much for taking the time to coming on the show. I really appreciate it. Thanks,

Marty Neumeier:

‚ÄçArek. My pleasure. Hope to see you soon.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Follow me on social media, for more tips on branding strategy and design. And I will see you in the next one.

title: An interview with Sean Adams (Video Podcast)
text:
Table of Contents

*PS. Below you will find an auto-generated transcript of this episode.

Please note: as an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases, at no extra cost to you.

Intro

Arek Dvornechuck:

What‚Äôs up branding expert? Arek here at Ebaqdesign and welcome to On Branding Podcast. And today my guest is Sean Adams and Sean is the Chair of Undergraduate and Graduate Graphic Design at Art Center College of Design. And Sean is also on on-screen instructor for LinkedIn Learning. And he‚Äôs the only two term AIGA national president in AIGA‚Äôs hundred-year history. So in addition to that, in 2014, Sean was awarded the AIGA medal. It is the highest honor in the profession. And previously Sean was a founding partner of AdamsMarioka and worked with clients with big brands like Adobe, GAP, Target, Disney among other big brands. So Sean is also the author of multiple best-selling books, including this one, How Design Makes Us Think. And this is the book we are going to talk about today. Hello, Sean, thanks for taking time to join us on our podcast.

Sean Adams:

Oh, it‚Äôs my pleasure. And like I said, this podcast is so amazing. You have such great guests and the content is truly what it‚Äôs, it‚Äôs one of my favorites.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Yeah. And, um, thank you so much for taking the time you are a great guest actually. So I‚Äôm happy that you were able to join us. So I wanted to talk to you about the content of this book. It‚Äôs a really great book. You‚Äôll give us a lot of examples to illustrate all of these chapters in the book. So basically the premise of the book is that as designers, we must be more purposeful and aware of the formal choices that we make. Right. Also think like,

Sean Adams:

I think that aim and on the opposite side for people that are civilians to read it and actually understand that the designers are making purposeful choices, that they‚Äôre not just arbitrarily saying, oh, I‚Äôll make it red, because I feel funny that day, you know, as designers, we‚Äôre logical, you know, smart people. And it‚Äôs important for, I think our clients to understand this, we‚Äôre not just wacky doodle artists that are toiling away at it in an attic and France.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right. And you talk about that in the book is some of it is intuition, but for the most part, there are some reasons for why we make those choices, right. So, you know, can you dive into those reasons, sociological, psychological historical reasons and asking yourself the question, what visual and conceptual cues resonate with us and why? So, as you said, you know, it could be for creative school, do it more intuitively, and now try to understand perhaps the science behind it, or to be able to articulate better their designs to, to their clients. For example, all just, you know, regular people, as you said to have them understand why we make those choices as designers, right? So basically you divide your book into 13 chapters, right? So what I wanted to do, you know, if time allows, I wanted to spend a couple of minutes just giving out lists and that‚Äôs an overview of each. Uh, so starting with the first ones, the action, right? So how do you seduce the viewer? How we can use design to, you know, invite people to become more intimate with our message.

1. Seduction

Sean Adams:

I mean, you know, seduction is it‚Äôs, it seemed to me that, that I started with that chapter because it was the entry point to almost anything that, you know, our job as designers is the first thing they have to do is actually get someone‚Äôs attention and make them want to get engaged. And there‚Äôs ways to do that. And clearly, you know, a lot of those are basic biological reasons that we‚Äôre going to respond to brighter colors because they typically meant good things. That‚Äôs a good barrier to eat. That‚Äôs like a fresh fruit as opposed to, okay, that‚Äôs a murky color, perhaps that rotting needs not so tasty. So I think those basic sort of biological reasons that people are attracted things, plus, you know, the reasons intellectually, like why someone might see something and want to want to engage is really critical that, you know, you‚Äôre asking the viewer to ask questions, to look at something and say, gee, I don‚Äôt under, I need to know more. And that‚Äôs sort of what we‚Äôre always trying to do as designers. And I have this argument, every one saw with someone and they‚Äôll say, well, I don‚Äôt think work has to be attractive. I don‚Äôt think it has to be attractive either. But I do think he had asked to reduce the viewer. I think something has to engage the viewer in a way that makes them want to dig deeper.

Arek Dvornechuck:

Right so you talked about color, as you said, primary colors and associate them with some positive feelings, right? Like you said, fruits, flowers. And we talk also about forum in this chapter, that there are shapes that, you know, with naturally find attractive and here you talk a lot about, you know, go the proportions golden rectangle and Bonacci sequence and so on. And you‚Äôll give us actually a lot of examples here. So just for our listeners to, you know, we just want it to show us what‚Äôs the content of the book too. So there is a lot of examples illustrations.

Sean Adams:

Yeah. I mean, I love that just by her blue ball on, the arrows magazine, which is, um, that was an erotic magazine, right? Like that‚Äôs the, you know, and, and it‚Äôs amazing that new balance took it and redefined it from sort of the girlymag that was typically out there at the time and used, you know, for the cover of that one bright yellow and a big amount of negative space and, and all of these things that would first get your attention, but then very quickly tell the reader or the viewer, this is not your typical erotic magazine. This is for someone who appreciates good design or understands the negative space. All of those kinds of little cues get thrown in there. So that the, so that if I‚Äôm just looking for some like really revolting pornography, that‚Äôs not the place to go. You know, that I‚Äôm going to know, oh no, I‚Äôm going to go there. And there‚Äôs going to be probably smart content, something interesting. And LouDelan was a genius to that. This sort of tapping into the, the things that we value in terms of emotional resonance and utilizing those, um, in, in such a great way. I mean, I think it‚Äôs fine with arrows too, that we look at it. You can look at it now and it‚Äôs so tame. I mean, it‚Äôs so like just polite intellectual sort of discussions, but the commentary that they would get back then, like you were going to hell for doing this magazine. It‚Äôs just, it‚Äôs amazing how times change. Right.

Arek Dvornechuck:

The next one efficiency. So in the next chapter we talk about efficiency. So my question is, so w why efficiency is so important when it comes to design and how we can use it as designers to tower.

2. Efficiency

Sean Adams:

I mean, I think the first thing with efficiency to consider that I had not actually considered until I started working on the book was the fact that efficiency is a modern concept that obviously we‚Äôre going to like something that works better than something that doesn‚Äôt, I‚Äôm going to like a round wheel because of the actually functions as opposed to the square wheel, right. That‚Äôs just sort of, you know, a given, but this idea of valuing efficiency as an attribute that we, we should really adhere to, I think is a very 20th century sort of Bauhaus concept that, you know, making something with the least resources to actually succeed is what makes it efficient. title: How To Start Your Own Logo Design Business
text:
A creative design logo represents that‚Äôs own company. An image of product and services of the company can be seen inside a logo actually. All businesses owner, product developers, non-profit organisations and small consumer brands use custom business logo as their brand identity to reach customers.

Demand of logo designer or logo maker in the market is an endless process just because each single newly registered company needs this. If you have a creative mind and skills, so logo business can be a great choice with handsome earning.

In this business article we will discuss golden rules of logo design and all related things such what equipment do you need to start graphic design, how to start a freelance graphic design business and how to start a graphic design business with no money.

Let‚Äôs begin..

Here are the most important steps to designing a logo: ‚Äî

Understand why you need a logo. Define your brand identity. Find inspiration for your design. Check out the competition. Choose your design style. Find the right type of logo. Pay attention to color. Pick the right typography.

How much money does a logo designer make?

While ZipRecruiter was seeing annual salaries as high as $107,000 and as low as $19,000, the majority of LOGO Designer salaries in current range is between $31,500 (25th percentile) to $87,500 (75th percentile) with top earners (90th percentile) making $101,000 annually across the United States.

Do logo designers make good money?

A LOGO Design in your area makes on average $60,950per year, or $1,681 (4%) more than the national average annual salary of $59,271. California city ranks number 11 out of 50 states nationwide for LOGO Design salaries. ‚Ä¶ Find your next high paying job as a LOGO Design on ZipRecruiter today fast.

How do you become a logo designer?

Step-by-Step Secrets to Designing Great Logos

Master the use of Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator for effective logo design job. Explore the function of logos and why some work better than others. Discover the fundamental design principles behind great logos. Learn how to land clients and understand what they want from a design.

Necessary steps to building a successful & profitable logo design business

What is logo design business

Logo designing job comes under graphic designing. Logo design, brand strategy,web design, social media design and poster design etc.. are few graphic design services to explore. That‚Äôs why there is high demand and scope for custom logo designers. After starting new business every business owner look for professional custom logo designers. According to the report of many studies the logo designing and branding contributes 20 percent of graphic design market. Usually logo maker prove their loge designing services online which is known as logo online service as well.

Need to understand market

Before starting and making logo design business this is very important to understand the market. However, today there are many free logo maker software are available online, but you can not compare them to professional logos. Give your time to market research and understand the market and all your competitors what types of services they are providing to their customers in what price. After knowing all these basic facts related logo design business now you will be able to make a successful business plan.
