title: How Much Does It Cost To Operate An Autonomous Vehicle?
text:
Almost nothing. Self-driving cars are insanely cheaper to operate than a normal car

The Origin, a self-driving car with no steering wheels or pedals, designed by GM-owned Cruise

This is the first in a series of stories in which I will show you just how HUGE the impact of AVs will be in our lives.

We‚Äôll begin by looking at how much it would cost for a self-driving car to take you from Downtown San Francisco to Ocean Beach, on the city‚Äôs western end ‚Äî and how this compares to the costs that an Uber or Lyft driver would face on the same trip.

Before we start, let‚Äôs agree on how to calculate these costs

First, we‚Äôll only include variable costs, that is, those that occur directly as a result of the ride. We‚Äôll ignore fixed expenses like software development, because they are not causally linked to the trip.

Second, we‚Äôll include the following variable costs: electricity, depreciation, insurance, cleaning, maintenance, and driver cost. We won‚Äôt include customer service cost, as these are harder to estimate, and usually low.

Third, we‚Äôll choose the Cruise Origin as our benchmark for AVs. The Origin has no steering wheel or pedals, and is expected to be released in 2023 by Cruise, a General Motors-owned company. Even if you wanted to, you couldn‚Äôt drive it, so it‚Äôs the quintessential autonomous vehicle.

Fourth, our non-AV benchmark will be an Uber driver riding a Chevy Bolt. The Bolt is electric, and choosing an electric car allows for a fairer comparison, as the Origin is battery-powered too.

Fifth, we will focus on cost, and not on price. Cost is a measure of the resources that are consumed when making the drive, and is straightforward to calculate. Price is how much the service provider (Uber or Cruise) will charge you for the ride, and is more complex to determine.

Sixth: We‚Äôll assume that both cars have a 60% utilization, which is approximately what we see in New York City. They‚Äôll be driving with a passenger 60% of the time, while the other 40% will be ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles in which the cars will be driving to pick up a new passenger or waiting for a new call. We‚Äôll assume that the 40% is all driving, and that there is no ‚Äúparking‚Äù involved.

Finally, we‚Äôll use estimates and common sense when we cannot find reliable data for any given cost component.

Alright, now that we have set the ground rules, let‚Äôs dive into the costs.

San Francisco, California, and our simulated ride, from the Civic Center to the Dutch Windmill at Ocean Beach

COST BREAKDOWN

Electricity

Our trip from Downtown to the Beach is 5.7 miles long (or 8.5 miles including the ‚Äúempty‚Äù distance driven to the next passenger).

The Origin will probably need around 29 kwh / 100 miles (similar to the Bolt), so that‚Äôs 1.65 kwh for the trip. We‚Äôre only missing the electricity cost, which in San Francisco is about $0.25 per kwh. That gets us to $0.41 for the trip, and adding the ‚Äúempty‚Äù distance to the next rider, 3.8 miles, we get to $0.62.

That‚Äôs pretty cheap. If you drove this same route with a Chevy Malibu, which does about 24 mpg, it would cost you about 1.41 cents at the current California gas price of $4.5 / gallon.

But remember: our Uber driver has an electric Chevy Bolt and gets the same 62 cents. So the AV cost advantage is not really related to the electricity cost.

Tie between Uber and Cruise at 62 cents

2. Depreciation

This is where the Origin starts pulling ahead. According to Cruise, the Origin will cost about $50,000 and last about one million miles before it needs to be retired. That‚Äôs a lot more than the useful life of the Bolt, which is 400,000 miles.

Quick math shows that the depreciation cost per mile is 5 cents per mile ($50,000 / 1,000,000) and that the depreciation cost for our trip to the beach is then 5.7 * 5 = 29 cents, or 44 cents with 60% utilization.

If we drove the Bolt, which costs the driver $33,000, the cost would be 71 cents. Advantage Origin.

Cruise beats Uber, 44 cents vs. 71 cents

The San Francisco Civic Center, our starting point

3. Insurance

This is another cost line where AVs will crush competition, if we make one simple assumption: that self-driving vehicles will never be at fault for a traffic accident.

Wait, what? That‚Äôs kinda hard to believe, right? Well, it‚Äôs closer to the truth than you may think. Data from Waymo ‚Äî Cruise‚Äôs Google-owned competitor ‚Äî can help us.

Waymo‚Äôs cars drove 6.2 million miles autonomously around Phoenix, Arizona, from January 2019 to September 2020. During this time, the firm‚Äôs cars were involved in 47 collisions and, according to the company, nearly all of those were not Waymo‚Äôs fault. How many does ‚Äúnearly all‚Äù mean? Waymo doesn‚Äôt specify, but I‚Äôm guessing no more than 2 or 3. Which would basically mean 4‚Äì6% of all accidents. That‚Äôs very close to ZERO, and, to simplify, we‚Äôll call it zero.

What type of insurance do app drivers and Cruise need?

With this controversial but credible assumption, we can move on to understand the two insurance policies we might need:

Liability coverage for app drivers: California requires Uber drivers to carry $1 million in liability insurance to cover the passengers and property involved in an accident. This covers accidents where the insured Uber driver is to blame for the accident, so the Origin doesn‚Äôt need it.

California requires Uber drivers to carry $1 million in liability insurance to cover the passengers and property involved in an accident. This covers accidents where the insured Uber driver is to blame for the accident, so the Origin doesn‚Äôt need it. Uninsured /underinsured driver: When someone other than the app driver is responsible for the accident, the coverage above does not apply. But maybe the other party at fault doesn‚Äôt have insurance, and can‚Äôt pay for the damages of the crash. To guard their users against such risk, Uber offers this ‚Äúuninsured driver coverage‚Äù, even though this is not required by law. Cruise should too, because as long as there are bad drivers sharing the road with the Origin, this risk still exists.

How much does all of this cost? According to Allstate, which offers insurance to app drivers in California:

Liability coverage adds up to $1,248 per year for 50,000 miles, or 14 cents for our 5.7-mile trip, 21 cents with the ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles. Again, Cruise doesn‚Äôt have to pay for this, but Uber drivers do.

Uninsured / underinsured coverage costs $360 a year for 50,000 miles ‚Üí 4 cents for our trip, or 6 cents including the ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles. Both Cruise and our Uber driver need to pay for this.

Cruise beats Uber, 6 cents vs. 27 cents

Ocean Beach, our destination, on the city‚Äôs Western End

4. Maintenance

The Origin and the Bolt need to be maintained from time to time so they can safely tranport passengers. There is no data available on how much it will cost to maintain the Origin‚Ä¶but we do have a good estimate for the Bolt. That comes from Edmunds, a well-known car-review portal.

We also know that, as a rule of thumb, the more it costs to build a car, the more it costs to maintain it. And we know the Origin‚Äôs and the Bolt‚Äôs production cost: $50,000 and $29,000, respectively. (You‚Äôll pay $33,000 for a new Bolt because GM and the dealer need to make a profit, but $29,000 is what it costs to make it).

Now for the actual cost: Edmunds expects you to spend $3,021 on maintenance for every 75,000 miles driven on your Bolt, or 23 cents for our trip, 35 cents with the ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles. The Origin costs 72% more to produce, so we‚Äôll just assume that the maintenance costs are 72% higher ‚Üí 60 cents including the ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles.

Uber wins, with 35 cents, vs. 60 cents for the Origin

5. Cleaning

From time to time, Uber drivers need to vacuum and wipe the vehicle‚Äôs floor and seats to keep it looking and smelling fresh. Less often, they will wash the outside too, to give the vehicle that shiny new car look.

How often do they do it? The Uber sub-reddit seems to indicate once a day for the interior, and a once a week for the exterior. The same would apply for Cruise, as their passengers will still demand a spotless vehicle.

For the costs, let‚Äôs assume that a car drives about 150 miles per day:

Interior cleaning: 15 minutes per day + $1 of cleaning products per day. With a cleaner costing about $20 / hour, that comes to $6 / day, 4 cents a mile ‚Üí 35 cents per trip with ‚Äúempty‚Äù miles

Exterior: A standard cash wash is about $30, or 3 cents per mile ‚Üí 25 cents per trip

The total adds up to 40 cents per trip, which is a lot! More than insurance, and almost the same as electricity.

If I were to be super rigorous, I‚Äôd say that the Origin has a small disadvantage over the Bolt: its exterior sensors, like LIDARs, cameras and radars, need constant cleaning, because it relies on them to ‚Äúsee‚Äù the road and drive safely. How often is this required? Maybe once a week? Maybe never because they have some ‚Äúauto-cleaning‚Äù function? Not sure.

But we know that the Origin is already going to be cleaned once a day, so the marginal cost of cleaning the sensors would be very small. It‚Äôs just a matter of spending an extra 2‚Äì3 minutes wiping them. We‚Äôll call it not relevant for our calculations.

Uber and Cruise tie at 60 cents per trip

Waymo‚Äôs vehicles like this adapted Jaguar have been roaming the streets of San Francisco for a while. Notice the driver inside, who can still take over if needed. This won‚Äôt be possible ‚Äî or hopefully needed ‚Äî in the Origin

6. Driver cost

You guessed it: it‚Äôs zero for Cruise. The company is spending a lot of money on developing its self-driving software, but this is a fixed cost. Once the program is installed in the car, it doesn‚Äôt cost anything more to take passengers from one point to another.

For an Uber driver, it‚Äôs a different story: Everytime they ride, they expect to earn a wage. It‚Äôs how they make a living, afterall. So there is a cost here. We‚Äôll calculate it based on the trip length, utilization rate, and on the wage that a driver would demand. Let‚Äôs dive into the math:

The trip would take 31 minutes at the SF downtown average speed of 11 mph‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶but the drivers expect to be paid for more than just these 31 minutes. They are only carrying a passenger 60% of the time they are working, but also want money for the other 40% of the time. If we didn‚Äôt factor this time in, we‚Äôd get a much lower pay, one at which drivers would prefer to work somewhere else. Factoring in the 40%, the actual duration of the trip is 52 minutes.

At $16.32 per hour, which is the San Francisco minimum wage, these 52 minutes cost $14.06, vs. ZERO for Cruise. That‚Äôs an insane advantage. Let‚Äôs discuss it below.

Cruise beats Uber, $0 to $14.06

COST SUMMARY, PRICING AND IMPLICATIONS

Cost summary

Adding up everything, the total cost for an Uber driver to move you from the Civic Center to Ocean Beach comes to $16.60. Out of this total, $2.54 comes from non-driver costs, and $14.06 from the driver.

Summary of all trip-related costs. The ‚ÄòDriver‚Äô line is the main difference between the two alternatives

For a self-driving vehicle, the cost for the same trip is $2.31, all from non-driver costs. That is 86% lower than the Uber driver.

86% is A LOT. Like really a lot. It‚Äôs all the more significant because transportation is a very significant expense to all of us. The average American family spends $9,600 on transportation a year, the second highest budget category behind housing. Imagine if I told you that in 10 years, all houses would cost 86% less. You‚Äôd call me crazy, for sure.

Pricing

But let‚Äôs remember that it‚Äôs one thing to calculate the variable cost of the ride, and another one to calculate how much Cruise or Waymo will charge us for it. They are companies and want to maximize their profits, so we can expect to pay more than $2.31.

Exactly how much? This will be the subject of my next post. To calculate the price, I will borrow concepts from microeconomics like demand curve, marginal revenue and profit maximization. Another key aspect of price calculation is the variable cost of the ride ‚Äî and this is the reason why this text focuses on variable costs.

But while we are still not sure about the final price, one thing is certain: it will be much cheaper. This brings powerful implications to the transportation world as we know it.

What does this lower cost even mean? Implications

At the very least, lower prices will drive a lot more people to use AV ride-hailing services vs. other alternatives like buses, the subway, or even walking or cycling.

More demand means more cars on the streets, and potentially more traffic jams. But it‚Äôs not all bad: it also means less public space reserved to parking, as AVs will either be parked in their company‚Äôs garage when they are charging or undergoing maintenance work, or not parked at all.

To understand exactly how much more traffic, or how much less parking space is needed, we‚Äôll first need to understand how many people will use AVs. And this number depends on how much Cruise or Waymo will charge for their services.

So see you on our next post about pricing!

title: Types of fashion: understanding styles right now
text:
Intro

Do you think men and women both are crazy about fashion? We are going to discuss about types of fashion. Read the article till the end to get insight in to the concept of fashion. Fashion meaning is to adopt a specific style in clothing and personal grooming. It makes people distinguished from other people. These days celebrities and designers are very serious about fashion. Hairstyle, footwear, wristwatches, bracelets, lockets, and clothes are included in fashion.

Types of Fashion

Limited time edition

This type of product is for those people who want something unique or exclusive. These are not costly products but are produced in limited quantity and sold.

Designer wear

Many designers around the globe produce products for special industries or occasions. These products are mostly costly. Examples include the film industry and wedding occasions.

Timeless

These products are cheap to very costly but never go out of fashion and people can use them even after a decade. Some examples are casual shoes, nightclothes, etc.

Street

These are the cheapest products. Every second person uses these products. People having low incomes mostly use these products.

Diffusion

These are outdated products having high costs sold at low cost so that people having low income can use them.

Conclusion

title: December 21 Commentary
text:
Commentary:

Perhaps we were all expecting a different end of the year, with some fitting fireworks. The market, however, after the welcomed Christmas rally, has delivered the harsh truth with a correction on the 27th that brought us back to the lowest prices since the September lows. Low liquidity seems to blame, however looking closely at the price performance of Bitcoin over the year, and comparing it with the S&P500, as displayed in Figure 2, we observe that twice this year we had periods of inverse correlation in the performance trend. After the Summer correction, the two time-series began to diverge again around mid-November, when crypto markets initiated their downward trajectory, while the equity market, despite some short-lived correction, has kept pushing to new highs. Whether this continued behaviour hides more significance than just end of the year lack of liquidity shall be seen over the coming weeks when institutional players are expected to deploy more capital in the crypto markets.

Figure 2: Comparison of the yearly price performance of Bitcoin and S&P500. It can be noticed without the aid of correlation measures, how we had two instances of diametrically opposite behaviour. First in the Summer, with the May crash, then the current period, after the December crash. Historically such a difference in behaviour has been resolved in a few months. Source: Trading View

Looking closely at the chart in Figure 2, it can be noticed that most of the divergence in performance is due to the market crash on December 3rd, ultimately a reaction to the FED tapering plans and the spreading of the Omicron variant. Both caused continued downward pressure throughout the month and should be expected to produce headwinds into the new year.

In the meantime, Derivative markets paid the price with an Open Interest (OI) wash-out in the region of 20%-30% triggered by the liquidations on the 3rd of December, as well as the unwinding of directional longs and cash-and-carry shorts, set to profit from the demand for leverage products that characterises neutral and in particular bullish market regimes. As displayed in Figure 3, the OI of Bitcoin products crashed for both linear and inverse contracts, however, while the former has found new footing and recovered the interest of buyers and sellers, the latter, crypto-native products, struggled to recover. A theme that has characterised the last couple of years, with every crash providing an opportunity for linear derivatives to gain market share. Lower OI and a lack of demand in the past few weeks has not only characterised Future products but also Option Markets, with a monster expiry on December 31st that has halved the size of the market overnight. As displayed in Figure 4, the uncertainty has caused traders to be cautious with only a small percentage of the OI being rolled into farther maturities. The low demand, as well as the increasing influence of DeFi on the markets, has pushed Implied Volatility (IV) below the levels to be historically considered normal. With the increasing popularity of yield generation via passive option-selling strategies by decentralised protocols, we can expect the IV to remain compressed on the shorter maturities, as well as pinning the whole curve down.

Figure 3: Open interest time series for Bitcoin contracts, both linear (BTC denominated ‚Äî green) and inverse (USD denominated ‚Äî purple) since late November. It can be easily identified the drop due to the liquidations and position unwinding on December 3rd. Since then, linear instruments Open Interest has recovered the pre-crash levels (partially thanks to the price appreciation), while inverse instruments struggle to recover their popularity Source: Coinalyze

Figure 4: Monster Option expiry on December 31st has halved the size of the market overnight, with only a timid recovery due to rolling into the next available maturity. Market participants seem to be taking an approach of wait and see, as liquidity slowly comes back from the Winter Holidays. Source: Deribit

Rates across the curve for Futures products have also been compressed, as discussed earlier, with Perpetual contracts (Figure 5) and Fix Maturity contracts (Figure 6) demonstrating a lack of demand with low rates and a flat behaviour during the second half of the month, after the initial volatility post-crash dissipated. After a few weeks of discounts on the Perpetual contracts, following the crash at the beginning of December, funding rates seems to have stabilised, with all contracts exhibiting neutral premia, the first sign that traders‚Äô confidence in the market is increasing and sentiment improving.

Figure 5: Average Funding Rates for linear and inverse BTC contracts, grouped by collateralisation currency (USD ‚Äî green, USDT ‚Äî blue, BTC ‚Äî red). It can be noticed how the rates have remained subdued during the second half of November and the majority of December, with a slow and painful recovery from the depths caused by the crash on December 3rd. Source: Trading View

Figure 6: Annualised premia of March Future contracts over the last two months. Notice how the volatile trend, albeit downward, has died down in December, with rates barely moving from their baseline return of 8%-10%. Source: Trading View

Looking away from the short-term price performance of the majors, a thriving ecosystem can be found in microcap coins and projects oriented towards the creator economy, gamified DeFi, p2e games (play to earn) and similar. In Figure 1 we show an assortment of ‚ÄúFlippenings‚Äù that happened in the few prior weeks and, albeit their scope is limited, they offer some insight into the transformational trends that we are experiencing. NFTs are more popular than Ethereum itself, Metaverse is more clicked than Cryptocurrency, the most expensive art piece from a living artist is now a digital image minted as NFT, Bored Apes are more expensive than CryptoPunks (read as ‚Äúa vibrant community takes over the establishment‚Äù).

The old guard should watch its back, the incumbents are being displaced and a new reality is taking shape. Despite this warning, in Figure 7 we show the ranking over time in the app store of a number of retail crypto platforms. It can be observed how the sentiment has actually cooled down during December, with Coinbase and Crypto.com apps tumbling down the rankings below the 100th and the 50th place respectively.

The headwind for most crypto assets is partially due to the tightening in financial conditions that are expected over the coming months, as the FED slows down its bond purchase program and increases the rates, on the back of rising inflation and normalisation of economic conditions. As Crypto was born from the ashes of the 2008 Financial Crisis it has historically been focused on payments and financial disintermediation, tying the fortunes of the market with the ebbs and flows of the overarching financial system, a system from which the crypto community wants to break apart. Enters Web3, NFTs and social tokens that offer a compelling use case beyond finance, onboarding millions of people to the Blockchain ecosystem, and reaching a crowd that had no interest in trading and speculative investments.

Figure 7: Popularity of retail-oriented Crypto apps in the US Google play store. Representative of the sentiment over the last few weeks, we observe the popularity of those that used to be top-ranking apps at the beginning of November crashing down to sub 50th and sub 100th ranking (Coinbase and Crypto.com respectively). Source: The Block

Despite the increasing institutionalisation of DeFi and the growing interests of the traditional financial industry towards decentralised investments products (loans, swaps and derivatives) as well as improved settlement channels, the sector has lagged the market over the last few months, with infrastructure plays, Web3 and games decisively outperforming as they enter the spotlight for the first time (the latter two in particular). With major fashion brands (Dolce and Gabbana, Burberry, Hermes), sports brands (Adidas, Nike), tech companies (Facebook), artists (Kings of Leon, Eminem, Jay-Z, Snoop Dog, Ice Cube) and many other businesses and celebrities betting on the space, the industry can thrive during times of adverse macroeconomic conditions.

In Figure 8 we show the historic active developer count over the last 8 years, highlighting the positive trend and the increasing participation resulting from the newly found interest in the Metaverse and, more generally, non-financial applications of decentralised protocols. Expect network effects to transform the landscape in the years to come, with the most talented software engineers, researchers and designers joining the space and fuelling exponential growth in user adoption with improved interfaces and compelling use-cases.

title: 5 Major Industries enefiting From Augmented Reality Technology
text:
e

Augmented Reality (AR) is one of the technologies that nowadays has experienced a boom in its expansion and that is showing to have an impact not only in industrial fields but in people‚Äôs lives in many ways. This technology aims to enhance one‚Äôs experience by involving overlaying visual, auditory, or other sensory information onto the world. Based on a report by ResearchAndMarkets.com‚Äôs the AR market was valued at USD 14.7 billion in 2020 and is projected to reach USD 88.4 billion by 2026. Here we can add that the key factors driving the growth of the AR market include surging demand for AR devices and applications in healthcare, growing demand for AR in retail and e-commerce sectors due to COVID-19, rising investments in the AR market, increasing demand for AR devices and technology in the global automotive industry, and many other industries as well. As AR technology finds new applications day by day, saves costs, and helps to keep the business continuity, demand and investment in AR will continue to grow. AR application is diverse, so let‚Äôs see below some of its existing applications in emerging market industries:

1. Automotive

Many businesses operating in the automotive industry have successfully embraced new technologies such as AR, as a need to change the way of operations and to build a bridge of collaboration between experts and field workers. Nowadays with the help of AR-based remote support integrated into smart glasses experts are able to make live annotations that overlay into real-world during work, field workers can work hands-free without distractions while receiving instructions on how to assemble a specific machine. With this AR-based remote collaboration, the accuracy of field workers can go up to 96% and they are able to work 30% faster. In addition, AR remote support has demonstrated great potential for fieldworkers' training. Connected in real-time with an experienced expert, field workers from different locations all around the world, are trained for different assembly tasks before they start performing their work. Training field workers to perform their job correctly have productive results in fewer operator errors that eventually cause slowdowns and downtime.

2. Manufacturing

Given all the many benefits that remote support offers, the manufacturing industry is utilizing AR technology in order to stay relevant, innovative, and competitive. AR-remote support is one of the main tools that help operating businesses in the manufacturing industry to achieve functional goals such as reducing costs, improving efficiency, increasing safety, and expanding production capacity. In manufacturing businesses, production downtime due to machine breakdowns is a serious threat and it could cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Machinery malfunctions need to be prevented to minimize manufacturing downtime. But with the help of AR remote support, the field workers from received instructions on their smart devices can quickly visually identify the problem and resolve it or even prevent the downtime from ever occurring. Businesses of the manufacturing industry through implementing AR remote support monitor, inspect, update, and repair their machinery, by this, are able to create the right atmosphere for meeting goals to help to eliminate machinery downtime.

Trending AR VR Articles:

3. Logistics and Transportation

Innovative technologies such as AR enable logistics and transportation businesses to optimize efficiency by automating and standardizing the workflows. Using AR can enhance warehouses‚Äô maintenance, improve packaging and order picking processes, and reduce the time spent on transportation and delivery. To lower the error rates and ease the workers‚Äô decision-making process in logistics, it is necessary to use technologies like AR and simplify tasks. It will also clarify most of the logistic business steps like assembly, storage, sorting, inventory, order picking, transportation, and more.

4. Oil and Gas

AR applications are already enabling oil and gas companies to transform their operational processes by reducing expenditures, enhancing remote collaboration, and helping to stay competitive in the market. Considering all the features and benefits, the implementation of AR in oil and gas operations is proving to be really efficient and indeed can transform the sector. Due to the harmful environment in which field workers are exposed, they are prone to health damage that can lead to loss of life. Through expert guidance field, workers perform their tasks in safe environments.

5. Healthcare

The tremendous growth of AR is being experienced especially in the healthcare sector, creating business opportunities for companies with AR expertise. In the healthcare field, the potential of AR is manifested in the ability that enable the presentation of 3D medical models in real-time at remote locations. The AR-based remote support can help doctors diagnose and treat patients accurately. With access to real-time patient data, they can perform functions better than before. In addition, by ignoring distance and boundaries AR brings the most specialized surgeons to the same operating room alongside the specialists who will perform the operation. Furthermore, doctors can record video and audio while examining a patient and can use them at a later time to train their students across the globe.

AR knows no boundaries but plays an important role in the operation of businesses despite the many and quite difficult challenges. This technology can be seen as an innovative solution to be adopted and that provides many benefits for businesses operating in different industrial fields. The power of AR connects experts with field workers around the world with real-time data, guidance, and the power of remote support. The impact of this technology is an excellent example of how the operational process of different industry types has been transformed and how the quality and productivity of work have increased.

Don‚Äôt forget to give us your üëè !

title: Is Netflix destined to be doomed?
text:
Is Netflix destined to be doomed?

Netflix has exceptional organizational culture, leadership style, and innovational practices which lead to the world‚Äôs first video streaming service that has 214 million paid subscribers. On my journey to understanding Netflix deeper, I am sad and disheartened to see that Netflix might fail in this decade due to the following reasons.

Limited Options: Netflix only streams TV shows, movies, and documentaries. Competitors are providing additional services like live TV, sports streaming, music, and games included in the same subscription plan. Decentralized streaming: With the advent of technology innovation, decentralized video streaming services are ready to go mainstream. The service is as good as any paid subscription but offered at a much lower price. Customers are being rewarded with community and crypto tokens for using, hosting, and maintaining these services. Alternate cable TV: Recently, IPTV has disrupted the cable TV industry by providing personalized TV viewership options. IPTV is taking 14% of the OTT industry, and YouTube TV is yet to roll out globally. This will directly affect Netflix viewership.

As an aspiring strategy & innovation consultant, I propose the following solutions:

Enemy of my enemy is my Friend: Team up with companies facing the same global competitors (Apple, Google, Amazon) in a different industry like Spotify for music, Gameloft for games. Make deals and establish partnerships where all the companies can benefit mutually. Improve the merchandise business: The Netflix shop does not have good designs to convert into sales. You can change that by starting a fashion division within Netflix. Enable an interactive option to purchase clothes and accessories that are worn by actors on-screen while watching the shows. Tap into NFT Market: Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) i.e., Digital collectibles are the next big thing for companies in the entertainment industry. Recently, an artist Michael Joseph Winkelmann sold a video clip for $67,000 as an NFT, later re-sold for 6.6 million dollars. People have spent more than 230$ million dollars buying and selling NFTs of NBA highlights. Netflix can create and sell NFTs of iconic moments, short clips from Netflix Originals.

Frameworks and methods used for market analysis.

Proter‚Äôs five forces

Competition in the industry: The success of Netflix has attracted global giants like Amazon, Apple, Disney. Every regional production house or broadcast network is having a digital transformation and entering the streaming space. As Netflix offers a library of films and TV series through distribution deals, most of the content on the platform will disappear as contracts expire. Global competitors like Amazon, Apple, Disney have deep pockets and support from their umbrella companies that lets them offer services at a discounted price. Regional production & broadcast companies have advantages of content they have been producing for 50+ years and the customer royalty that comes along. Threats of new entrants: Regional production companies are emerging in the market by leveraging their age-old content and targeting their niche customer groups. As they already hold the broadcast licenses or the original movie rights, these production houses and broadcast networks don‚Äôt spend much on acquiring content. For example, India‚Äôs video streaming market is growing to $5 Billion from $500 million in the next 2 years, primarily because of new players entering the streaming industry. Threats of Substitutes: YouTube is launching its own live stream platform (YouTube TV) in the U.S and worldwide by 2026. IPTV (Internet protocol television) is a new way of watching old-school TV channels. It uses the internet to search any kind of video content and streams directly on your TV or smartphone allowing customers to view, pause & record live tv, sports, regional movies, and tv shows throughout the world. Currently, IPTV is offering a service to start your own OTT platform with inbuilt IT infrastructure. It already gained a 17.8% market share of the entertainment industry and is experiencing accelerated growth. Power of Customers: Customers can choose from a lot of options and with Gen-Z being more tech-savvy, people are finding ways to download free content from the internet. Power of Suppliers: The market is in a unique growth phase where artists are getting an opportunity to produce video content that can be streamed globally on every platform. The cost of production and acquiring new content keeps increasing with artists, production houses starting their own streaming services.

Customer Value Map

Proposed Strategy Roadmap to avoid the disaster

What strategies would you propose to help Netflix grow? Let me know in the comments below‚Ä¶

title: ML Optimisation for Portfolio Allocation
text:
Authors: Darius Oh (Tech Lead), Mayve Chua, Luke Lau, Sng Hao Jun, Jamais Ang, Kexin Wang, Jacob Pang

Introduction

Portfolio Optimisation is the process of selecting the best portfolio, or rather the best set of possible weights for a basket of assets, given some sort of objective function. Common objective functions include maximising returns, minimising risk, maximising return-risk ratio or minimising tail risk.

The aim of our study is to understand deeper into how Machine Learning can be used to tackle such a complex asset allocation problem, and potentially devise a quantitative strategy that exceeds traditional methods.

The most common strategy that comes to mind when we talk about Portfolio Optimisation would be Markowitz‚Äôs Mean-Variance Optimisation. It aims to maximise portfolio returns while minimising portfolio risk, or rather the portfolio‚Äôs volatility. For example, investing in two separate negatively correlated stocks instead of a single stock is likely to reduce the risk, or in this case the volatility, of the portfolio. Such an action can also potentially generate greater returns even with the reduced risk. However, Markowitz‚Äôs model requires the forecasted portfolio return and volatility as an input to the model. Instead of a simple moving average forecast, we see an opportunity to use Machine Learning to gather a more accurate forecast of the future expected portfolio returns and volatility. With the assumption that the underlying theory of Mean-Variance Optimisation works, we would then be able to come up with an optimal portfolio. This strategy would, hence, combine more advanced Machine Learning techniques with traditional financial theory.

On top of this, we also wanted to explore a second approach to Portfolio Optimization through a pure Machine Learning strategy. This would allow us to come up with a new strategy that is independent of the reliance of traditional financial theory. Recently, much focus has been placed on Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Portfolio Optimisation, as it is able to handle the complex sequential decision-making process. Hence, we wish to explore building our own Reinforcement Learning model to handle the dynamic optimization process and maximise portfolio returns.

Dataset Used

Our models will be trained purely with historical OHLC (Open-High-Low-Close) price data. This means that it would not account for changes in the macroeconomic environment such as Interest Rates or Inflation. We collected the historical price data from the year of 2001 until the year of 2019 using yfinance Python API. We excluded earlier time periods as we believe that the price signals in the market performed much more differently as compared to more recent times.

Our stock universe would be the constituent stocks under the Dow Jones Industrial Average Index (DJI) as of 29 August 2021, excluding stocks listed after 2001 due to the lack of data. We chose DJI as it would provide us with a small enough stock universe that can cover a diverse array of industries. In addition, we would also be able to benchmark our portfolio performance against the performance of the index over time. This eventually left us with 27 stocks in our stock universe, coming from various fields of industry.

Approach 1: Mean-Variance Optimization

Asset Returns Forecast Model

Motivation

To support Markowitz‚Äôs model for portfolio optimization, we aim to explore using machine learning models to forecast the returns for each of the 27 chosen stocks. In which, our team has narrowed down to three more popular stock predictive machine learning models namely Decision Tree, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) to kickstart our exploration. Our team has chosen to explore LSTM and ARIMA as it has proven to support time-series prediction well. On the other hand, we have also chosen a decision tree as our team is interested in exploring the performance of a regression tree in the context of price prediction.

Model Exploration

All three models will predict for the target variable, log returns (generated using the adjusted close prices) of each stock ticker and the performance of each model will be compared and evaluated using mean square error (MSE) and root mean square error (RMSE). Adjusted close price is used for determining the log returns as it is more comprehensive and takes into account dividends, stock splits and factors that happen after the market closes.

For the Decision tree model, our team used Adjusted Close Price and Volume as input variables to predict for the log returns of each ticker. Meanwhile for LSTM and ARIMA, for every 50 time steps in the historical log returns dataset of each ticker, our team will utilize the log returns in these time steps as training data to predict for the next time step (testing data). Relative Strength Index (RSI) was also included. After training our model, we evaluated the performance of the model, and the results are shown in the result table below.

Table 1: RMSE and MSE of models

From the results, it can be seen that the decision tree model performed the best as it has the lowest RMSE and MSE. However, this is because the training data contain Adjusted Close Prices which is used to calculate the target variable, log returns and hence the model trained can be said to be biased and the results are overfitted. This is undesirable as the model may not be able to perform as well when fitted with unseen data. However, our team could not fit the training data of LSTM and ARIMA to the decision tree as the decision tree is unable to support the ratio of having many of the same input variables to 1 target variable (1: n) like that of LSTM and ARIMA. Hence, it can be concluded that the decision could only support 1:1 training data making it unable to support the context of our project. As such, despite the decision tree performing the best, our team has decided not to move forward with this model.

On the other hand, it can be seen that the ARIMA model performed the worst. Theoretically speaking, this could be due to the fact that ARIMA is powered by linear regression and hence it assumes that the time series training data being fed is stationary. This means that ARIMA assumes that the training data has no seasonality and has a constant mean, variance and covariance over time. This would thus not support the prediction well as the training data used in this project are long-term (at least 15 years) and contain seasonality in the data itself. As such, it can be said that the ARIMA model is more suited for prediction of short-term time-series data where there is no seasonality as compared to long-term dataset where there exists seasonality. With that, our team has also decided not to move forward with this model.

Therefore, we have decided to move forward with the LSTM model as it is able to handle seasonality in data which the ARIMA model cannot handle as well as handle 1: n training data which the decision tree model cannot handle.

Hyperparameter tuning for LSTM

To further improve on our chosen model, our team has decided to perform hyperparameter tuning to our LSTM model by tuning the learning rate, number of dropout layers and the number of neurons in the first layer. Tuning the learning model will allow the model to be more efficient as it controls how quickly the model can converge to a local minima. On the other hand, tuning the number of dropout layers and the number of neurons in the first layer will improve the performance of the model as it prevents the model from being under or overfitted. To do so, Keras in-built hyper tuner was used to tune the learning rate and number of neurons.

Evaluation Results for LSTM (Apple Ticker)

With that, our team has used the LSTM model to predict for the log returns of each ticker and the actual vs predicted result of the model when predicting Apple stock can be seen in the figure below.

Figure 1: Actual vs Predicted Result of Apple Ticker using LSTM model

Limitations and Further improvements

Due to the limitation of time, our team kept our maximum epochs to 10 to reduce training time which could compromise the performance of our model. This is because the number of epochs is related to the number of rounds of optimization that are applied during training and hence with more epochs, the error on training data will reduce which will in turn improve performance of the model. Thus, it can be said that by limiting the maximum number of epochs to 10 can result in a non-optimal number of rounds of optimization and thus a less optimal performance LSTM model being trained. Having said that, a room for improvement would be to tune the number of epochs when training the model so as to further improve the performance of our model. Furthermore, we can look into using a bi-directional LSTM which has been shown to be able to capture additional features from the data which is not able to be captured by a unidirectional LSTM.

Considering the scope of our project, a more in-depth time series analysis could be completed to further improve the final performance of our model. By analysing and accounting for possible seasonality present in the various time series of the stock prices, it would be easier for the neutral network to learn and hence potentially achieve better performance and more accurate results. For example, to get the model to learn the seasonality of the data, we can use the difference (P(t +1) -P(t)) as the input feature instead, this would allow the generation of a leading model and at the same time prevent the model from having to solely reference yesterday‚Äôs price, effectively mitigating the problem of a lagging model.

Going beyond the scope of our project, future work could look into including qualitative data to improve the robustness of our overall model. Sentiment analysis done on diverse data sources such as tweets, news articles, company reports and financial statements could also be included and combined into the deep learning model using feature engineering techniques. By doing so, there is a high potential to develop a more comprehensive prediction system that considers both quantitative and qualitative data.

Asset Covariance Forecast Model

Motivation

The covariance matrix is the other essential input for portfolio optimisation. In order to formulate a predicted rolling covariance matrix, we had to explore how to develop a predicted rolling volatility and rolling correlation matrix. Since a rolling correlation matrix is easily generated, the difficulty here was mainly exploring a logical way to predict rolling volatility.

Harry Markowitz in Portfolio Selection paper (1952) introduces the concept of volatility. Volatility of a portfolio is the standard deviation of the returns of this portfolio. This concept continues to be used in financial markets to define uncertainty/risk. However, most allocation and option pricing models assume that volatilities are constant through time. This assumption is flawed in that volatility clustering is observable in practice: periods of low volatility tend to be followed by periods of low volatility and periods of high volatility tend to be followed by periods of high volatility.

Volatility clustering represents a challenge being an example of heteroskedasticity. In order to alleviate this, Engle (1982) proposed the Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (ARCH model). Then, Bollerslev (1986) built upon Engle‚Äôs model and published his General Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (GARCH model).

Thus, we decided to train a GARCH model to predict future volatility as this would address volatility clustering. We create a methodology that enables the estimation of a GARCH model while using the most robust parameters.

Model Exploration

Bollerslev (1986) proposes an extension of the previous model, in which he adds an MA (moving average) part to the equation:

Such a process is written GARCH (p, q). Œ≤ is a new vector of weights deriving from the underlying MA process, we now have Œ≥ + ‚àëŒ± +‚àëŒ≤ = 1. For example, a GARCH(1,1) process has p = 1 and q = 1. It can be written as:

In order to estimate œâ, Œ± and Œ≤, we usually use the maximum likelihood estimation method. In this case, it consists of maximizing:

In our exercise, we tested GARCH models with parameters p=1 to 5 and q=1 to 5, resulting in 25 possible combinations of p‚Äôs and q‚Äôs on each of the assets. In order to not overfit the GARCH model, we selected the model that is able to do well in the scoring metrics across all assets.

Evaluation Results

In order to select the set of hyperparameters that are optimized for the smallest extent of errors, we first chose 3 common error metrics ‚Äî Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) in our GARCH modelling analyses performed on each of the 30 assets in our portfolio.

Figure 2: Results of GARCH Modelling using MSE, RMSE and MAE

As the GARCH modelling may possibly yield differing sets of hyperparameters p and q for each asset in the portfolio, we explored a na√Øve way of taking the mean of the values of p and q across all 30 assets in the portfolio for each error metric. As seen in the figure above, all 3 error metrics return the same set of mean hyperparameters (p = 3, q = 5).

Following this, we used p = 3 and q = 5 as inputs for our hyperparameters in the GARCH modelling to obtain the predicted volatility values which would then allow us to derive the rolling volatility values.

Figure 3: Covariance Matrix of our Portfolio (showing only 10/30 assets)

Together with the rolling correlation values, the covariance matrix can then be calculated.

Limitations & Further improvements

Na√Øve Mean method

The method of taking the average of the hyperparameters across all the assets of the portfolio may bring about inaccuracies in the GARCH modelling as the hyperparameters p and q represent the extent of which the past values have an influence on the current value. Taking the average of p and q across assets is essentially implying that ‚Äî if I have a portfolio of 2 assets where it is optimal to take the past x and y values to derive their current respective values, I can proceed to take the past (average of x and y) values to derive the current values for both assets in the portfolio. This is a na√Øve method as it banks on the assumption that the extent of errors that result from each asset is the same for all assets in the portfolio, which is not necessarily true in reality.

An alternative way that can be explored in future to obtain values p and q might involve running the GARCH modelling on the portfolio returns instead of on individual assets. For example, we can first aggregate across all 30 assets in the portfolio to obtain portfolio returns values at each timepoint. Thereafter, we can run the GARCH modelling on the portfolio to observe what sets of values of p and q are returned with the lowest error values using the same 3 error metrics as illustrated above. This set of values of p and q may arguably represent more accurately the extent of which past values have an influence on the current value.

Optimization

Model Implementation

Having obtained the forecasted daily asset returns from the LSTM model as well as the forecasted daily asset covariance from the GARCH model, we are now able to use these data as input for mean-variance optimisation. We make use of the PyPortfolioOpt Python Library which helps us to perform such optimisations efficiently.

Figure 4: Efficient Frontier Plot using 20000 randomly generated weights

The efficient frontier line is the set of optimal portfolios that offer the highest expected return for a defined level of risk or the lowest risk for a given level of expected return. Portfolios above the line are unattainable regardless of the asset allocation, while portfolios below the line are attainable but are less optimal. In order to decide on which optimal portfolio on the efficient frontier to choose, we have to fix an objective function for the optimisation. This could be maximising return-risk ratio, minimising volatility, maximising return with a risk constraint or minimising volatility with a returns target.

For each trading day, we will generate the Efficient Frontier using the current day‚Äôs forecasted returns and forecasted covariance. Based on the objective function that we set, we will obtain an optimal portfolio allocation that optimizes for the objective function. This would then give us the weights to hold for each asset for the day. This implies that there will be a rebalancing of the portfolio at the start of each trading day.

In this study, we will be exploring maximising return-risk ratio as well as maximising return with a given risk constraint. This will be further discussed in the Performance Comparison section.

Limitations

The key limitation of the mean-variance optimization strategy is its assumption that returns follow a normal distribution. However, this may not be applicable to some assets which display skewness in the returns data. Since the variability below and above is no longer the same (i.e. downside variance could be much greater than upside variance), it would now make more sense for an investor to work towards minimising downside variance rather than the portfolio variance as a whole. A research paper by Andrea Rigamonti discusses this more elaborately, and pushes for a new strategy known as mean-semivariance strategy. Semivariance is similar to variance, but it only accounts for observations below the mean. This potentially makes it a more useful measure of portfolio risk, especially when returns are not normally distributed.

Another key limitation of our optimisation strategy is that it is not extendable to other assets outside of our stock universe. As we are training the machine learning forecast models specific to only the 27 assets of interest, we would not be able to use the same models to forecast the data for other assets which can exhibit very different behaviours.

Approach 2: Reinforcement Learning

Brief Overview

Reinforcement Learning is an area in machine learning where we train an agent to perceive and interpret its environment, take actions and learn through trial and error. Given a specific situation or environment, the agent would be able to make the best possible decision to take that can result in the maximum reward attained. In the context of our problem statement, our agent would be making decisions on what stocks our portfolio should hold on each trading day in order to maximise the final cumulative portfolio returns.

Environment

For every step in each episode, the Environment supplies an observation to the Agent, accepts the corresponding action,

which represents the portfolio weights to adopt prior to open, and executes the interactions between the internal portfolio state and the changes in the financial market. Transaction costs of 0.2% were applied on the transition of weights from the prior close, wt-1 to, at to simulate actual trading. Using the vector of assets‚Äô returns rt, the relative portfolio weights at close is then given by

The effective portfolio return (with respect to the prior close) for the step is equivalent to

. Since the rewards are additively accumulated across the episodes, applying logarithm enables geometric returns to be captured in the rewards. For the purposes of setting a common basis for comparison across episodes starting from different dates, the return relative to a benchmark return rate, bt is used as a measurement for the reward ut. S&P 500 was used as the benchmark for this project.

The observations were comprised of the following features, separated into components:

a. Asset prices, returns, expected returns for the previous 20 days.

b. Asset covariance based on the previous 180 days, naive markowitz tangent portfolio weights, and the prior close portfolio weights.

Agent

In order to work with the continuous space of the action required (portfolio weights), Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) was used for the RL agent. A custom actor network was used, consisting of a convolutional asset scoring network and secondary dense network. The first component of the observations is fed into the asset scoring network, on an individual asset basis, to obtain an asset score. The asset scores, along with the second component of the observations are then fed into the secondary network to obtain the action. This design prevents the network from overfitting on underlying asset-specific trends which therefore trades some performance for ability to generalize outside the sample.

Actor Network Architecture

Evaluation Results

The results for the k-fold validation are as shown for the model after 50 episodes of training and 100 episodes of training. With the exception of 2020, the model with 100 episodes of training performs better as compared to the model with 50 episodes of training. The models generally outperform the benchmark during stable periods, but underperform during the recovery periods post-shocks.

Limitations

As deep RL requires extensive training and computation, time and investment into the project poses as the primary limitation, which is constrained further by applying k-fold validation. As each action influences the environment state, a permutation of sequences of actions over the same episode provides different training to the agent. In the context of the portfolio optimization problem, where the initial state already varies based on the starting date, it is improbable for an agent trained on 50 or 100 episodes to have covered sufficient exposure. We expect that given sufficient time, the RL model can perform better.

Performance Comparison

Portfolio Performance Results

Our portfolios are generated via three methods ‚Äî

‚óè Baseline: Mean-Variance Optimisation using rolling average of past returns as forecast

‚óè ML: Mean-Variance Optimisation using forecasts from LSTM and GARCH

‚óè RL: Reinforcement Learning

We include the Baseline portfolio as a comparison to observe the advantages that Machine Learning can bring as compared to a much simpler strategy. In addition, both the Baseline & ML are optimized to maximise return-risk ratio.

Additionally, we decided to filter away the portfolio performance past 2020 for this analysis because our Machine Learning Models have not been able to provide reliable forecasts during periods of unforeseen market shock.

Figure 5: Cumulative Returns of portfolios

Table 2: Summary Statistics of portfolios

From the table above, we can first see that our RL portfolio performs significantly worse than the other two portfolios. It has the lowest annualized returns as well as the lowest return/risk ratio as well. The potential reason for this poor performance has been discussed under Limitations in the previous section.

When comparing the Baseline portfolio against the ML portfolio, we can see that the ML portfolio has a much higher return/risk ratio. While it does have a slightly lower annualized return, it has a significantly lower annualized volatility in comparison to the baseline portfolio. This means that while both portfolios can attain a similar yield, the ML portfolio is able to provide us with a less risky option as compared to the Baseline portfolio. We also wish to explore the flip side where we fix a risk constraint for both portfolios and aim to maximise returns given the same set of constraints.

Figure 6: Cumulative Returns of portfolios

Table 3: Summary Statistics of portfolios

From the table above, we can now see that in order to adhere to the risk constraints, the Baseline Portfolio has a reduced Annualized Volatility together with a reduced Annualized Returns. In contrast, our ML Portfolio is able to take up slightly more risk but has resulted in a significant increase in Annualized Returns. With this objective function, our ML Portfolio achieves a significant higher yield for a similar risk level as compared to the Baseline Portfolio.

Further Discussions

It is useful to note that when we changed our objective function from maximising return/risk ratio to maximising returns, it actually resulted in an increase in the return/risk ratio of the portfolio. This is very unexpected as it means that the ML portfolio generated when maximising return/risk ratio is still not optimal. The reason for this is because we optimize for the objective function using forecasted data. However, due to our forecasts not being able to follow closely enough to the actual numbers, our ‚Äúforecasted optimal‚Äù portfolio will not be able to match the ‚Äúactual optimal‚Äù portfolio.

However, we can see that for the optimisation of the two different objective functions, using the forecasts from our Machine Learning models has proved to achieve better portfolio performance as compared to using a naive method.

Conclusion

From this study, we can observe the potential advantages of using more advanced Machine Learning techniques to make investment decisions. While there has been much skepticism and distrust due to the black-box nature of these techniques, it is without a doubt that many investors and institutions are moving towards such strategies due to the upsides that it brings. Whether it is to complement an existing traditional strategy or to devise an entirely new strategy, Machine Learning is definitely the area that the quantitative finance industry is moving towards and increasingly placing emphasis on.

Sources:

https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3465717

https://towardsdatascience.com/free-stock-data-for-python-using-yahoo-finance-api-9dafd96cad2e

https://pyportfolioopt.readthedocs.io/en/latest/MeanVariance.html

https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/why-you-should-not-use-arima-to-forecast-demand-196cc8b8df3d

https://arxiv.org/pdf/1911.09512.pdf

https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/analysis-of-stock-price-predictions-using-lstm-models-f993faa524c4

title: 2022 Market Outlook
text:
Key takeaways:

Illiquid supply in Bitcoin Ethereum.

DXY and the S&P, how this has an effect on the crypto space.

Macro market, how US policy might affect outcomes. Money printing, Covid, War and regulation.

Media coverage preparing retail to reenter.

(Retail has essentially been sidelined since May 2021)

(Retail has essentially been sidelined since May 2021) DeFi and stablecoins. Regulation means you should move into decentralised stables. i.e UST, Frax, MIM.

Bull market, blow off top, bear market. What will happen and how to prepare.

Some notes: These are observations connecting the unfolding of recent and future events and how to best prepare for the next year. NFA



Even though I am long term very bullish for the Crypto & Web3 space as a whole, it is important to remember that all markets enter cycles ‚Äî especially young markets. For those reasons, I believe there may be more volatility this year (yes, more volatile than normal for crypto).

Up until now, we have had relatively clear market cycles. With the introduction of ‚Äòbig money‚Äô, these patterns are changing. This means there are more things to watch out for moving forward.

Illiquid supply in Bitcoin and some On-chain Analysis.



Many people have called this year a bull market. This is not incorrect as we have seen some intense growth in many crypto assets, however, the On-chain data shows a different story ‚Äî a story of accumulation and price consolidation. Let‚Äôs look at the illiquid supply chart and see how this chart has been on a pretty aggressive downtrend. It‚Äôs getting to the point where close to 78% of Bitcoin is currently out of circulation, leaving less Bitcoin to be traded. This lack of liquidity can make for volatile movements as only close to 22% of the supply is actually being traded. This means it takes less money to move the price in either direction.

Here we can see how illiquid supply has grown for the past 2 years. Even with the price action we‚Äôve had.

There is a direct relation with how illiquid supply tends to be a precursor to some form of bullish rally. You can find more information on why Illiquid supply matters here.

Here we can see how illiquid supply has grown for the past 2 years. Even with the price action we‚Äôve had.

Moving on, let‚Äôs quickly see who has been selling recently and if the market will continue downward. Looking at ‚Äòdormancy‚Äô, we can see the average age of the coins that are being spent. In this recent downtrend, most of the coins spent have been young coins. Usually this means whales and ‚Äòsmart money‚Äô aren‚Äôt spending, rather, recent local top sellers are capitulating.

Furthermore, looking at the Entity-adjusted Dormancy Flow we can see that we have almost reset to the summer lows and are essentially forming another bottom.

Entity-adjusted Dormancy Flow is the ratio of the current market capitalisation and the annualised dormancy value (measured in USD). Entity-adjusted Dormancy Flow can be used to time market lows and assess whether the bull market remains in relatively normal conditions



If we have a look at the full Bitcoin history for the Entity-adjusted Dormancy Flow, we can see that we have only touched this zone in market bottoms.

Furthermore, Supply on Exchanges has been moving off into storage that historically is less willing to sell. This would indicate aggressive accumulation, especially since March 2020. Even though we have seen some moments of profit raking, the overall actions have been of accumulation and supply leaving exchanges.

Ethereum tells a similar story. It has actually had more aggressive withdrawals in the past two years and recently has started to see inflows on exchanges. Typically this would mean intense selling, but given that only about 12% of Ethereum was actually on exchanges, it looks more like the start of a run for it.

We can see that since the March crash, Ethereum has been leaving exchanges ‚Äî reaching a low of 11.2%. As money flows back, it will historically move into the hands of new adopters who do not understand the value of owning your own keys and will typically leave their new bought Eth (or any crypto) on the exchange.

DXY and the S&P: How this has an effect on the crypto space



Historically when the dollar has struggled, but the stock market has rallied, it has created a perfect combination for Bitcoin to flourish.

If the dollar starts to show weakness here, we could see a short but sweet rally of the investment assets as people look for ways to conserve their wealth and purchasing power. Inflation reached its highest point in 40 years and shows now signs of slowing. That is unless they raise interest rates and find a reason to justify printing money, war‚Ä¶ more on that later‚Ä¶

With the S&P marching on and the Dollar not looking pretty, money will flow into assets that have proven to protect purchasing power. Sorry Peter, gold has not kept up with inflation in the past 10 years‚Ä¶.

Macro market, how US policy might affect outcomes.

Money printing, Covid, War and regulation.



‚ÄúThe United States printed more money in June than in the first two centuries after its founding. Last month the U.S. budget deficit ‚Äî $864 billion ‚Äî was larger than the total debt incurred from 1776 through the end of 1979.‚Äù- Pantera Capital

Jul 29, 2020

This is only recently catching up to the US as inflation intensifies and the people in charge scapegoat with supply shortage excuses. Or even worse ‚Äî boogymen greedy corporate owners hiking up prices out of hate of the general public‚Ä¶ Oh Elly‚Ä¶

All of this while still being in the middle of an ongoing pandemic. Yes, the one we have been in for two years now, and for some reason, the COVID case count is at ATH now. I won‚Äôt get into that but let‚Äôs just say lots of things don‚Äôt add up. I‚Äôll mention some of these things: lack of prevention care, excessive use of vaccines (4 doses seems like something didn‚Äôt work the first time), arbitrary numbers/counting, oh and the 38 billion in profits from big pharma (a successful new product launch is 1 billion in a year). I won‚Äôt add wood to the fire, but more COVID cases tends to mean more justification for government spending.



Note: I feel for all the deaths and am sorry. I deeply thank all first responders.



Pair this with a country that is showing intense divide with each side becoming more extremist, the great hate of democrats and republicans. Historically there has been solved one way: war. Now the US is too woke to enter into a direct war with anyone. However, the United States is set to spend $768 billion next year on the military. This is much more than the year before, but this year the US has already exited Afghanistan and isn‚Äôt active in any public conflict.



Up for ‚Äúdemocratisation‚Äù and country reshaping are Ukraine and Taiwan. Most likely, the US would enter into a proxy war with China and Russia through these 2 fronts. Also ‚Äúprotecting‚Äù the South China Sea and its allies in the region. Nothing unites a country more than war and threat of foreign fighters‚Ä¶

More on military spending: Politico Opinion (ignore the crying about not getting what dems want, look at numbers for military). Aljazeera article

I don‚Äôt pick sides and am not American. But know the effect that the world‚Äôs biggest economy has on the rest of the world. For now.

Finally, interest rate hikes. Most central banks around the world announced no hikes for Q1 of this year fearing it would hamper recovery, and blaming the supply shortage for inflation even though inflation has happened everywhere in the world and debt is reaching pretty extreme levels. Most central banks did mention intentions to start hiking interest rates later in the year.



Once this happens, it can spark a quick selling of on-risk assets as well as a general deleveraging in the market. Big players don‚Äôt want to hold onto loans as it isn‚Äôt cheap anymore to have outstanding debt. Yes the whole economy runs on debt, but it is all about who ends up holding that bag of debt. As interest rates begin to pick up, the hot potato will begin moving around until the last person gets stuck holding the bag.

Media coverage preparing retail to reenter

A lot has happened this year in Crypto as it has slowly grown, however, most of the retail buyers left after the May crash. Since then, big companies have been spending big amounts of money on ads and branding. I‚Äôll mention a few of the most important ones:

Remember that retail moves slowly. Most of what has been happening this past year will start to take effect this year as retail sees the ads in more spaces. As crypto prices pick up, so will interest.



As much as this can sound bullish, I think it‚Äôs more of an exit strategy (pump and dump but in rich people words) before the impending doom of the year ahead.



In a tale as old as time, big money exits on risk assets and purchases war and consumer stocks (stock that will perform regardless of market conditions. i.e food, water, McDonalds, etc.) as a safe heaven ‚Äî not growth stock. Bye bye Tesla.

DeFi and stablecoins.

Regulation means you should move into decentralised stables. i.e UST, Frax, MIM



Stablecoins have been one of the most debated topics in US policy. I‚Äôll keep it short. US wants control and to make sure the USD stays as the world reserve currency. Good luck. But even then, crypto native users do look for some form of stability in order to sidestep the markets in volatile times. We have seen this year how USDT and USDC can easily be frozen, and because of policy, will most likely require KYC to use in the future (it‚Äôs all about control).



In the spirit of Cypher Punks and a free, decentralised economy, I support other solutions.

UST is on the top of my list as it has grown the most this year. I believe this growth will continue and adoption of a decentralised stablecoin in DeFi is only natural.

MIM is another solution. Similar to DAI, MIM is a crypto collateralised stablecoin, however, unlike DAI, MIM uses yield bearing collateral and allows anyone to mint MIM (when it is available).



Lastly, Frax. Frax is the first fractional-algorithmic stablecoin protocol. Frax is open-source, permissionless, and entirely on-chain. Unlike UST, Frax has some backing and is not completely algorithmic. However, Frax has not yet grown as much and in my opinion has the most growth ahead for the year. Keep an eye out for FXS (Frax share token).



This year will most likely be the migration from USDT/USDC to decentralised alternatives. Decentralised finance needs decentralised money.

Bull market, blow off top, bear market. What will happen and how to prepare.



With all that has been explained until this point, this is what it predict (I hate predictions) for the year 2022.



I expect Q1 and possibly Q2 to be part of a blow off top mania phase, mostly due to big money looking to exit pump before interest rate hikes and the impending war.



Events to watch for tops:

‚Äî Bitcoin backed ETF announcement is set for February to likely launch in March.

‚Äî Interest rate hikes. This is said to be re-evaluated quarterly but most likely will begin in the second half of the year Q3.

‚Äî War. This only will be harder to see a clear start, but Russia acting on Ukraine or China getting violent will be clear enough.



Lastly, it is important to monitor exchange inflows to see when big money is starting to move out. Smart money sells into strength ‚Äî not on the other end as price starts to move down.



We must look for dormancy to start to pick up ‚Äî this would mean old money is preparing for a move. Next blow off tops tend to have 2‚Äì6 weeks of exchange inflows as price continues to rally. So when your aunt asks you how to buy some of those ‚ÄúCrypto coins‚Äù, tell her how to but that it‚Äôs all NFA and then subsequently exit all positions.



My primary objectives and moves for Q1 will be to deleverage and repay all of my DeFi loans, consolidate my portfolio into stablecoin farming strategies, identify potential out performers for the year and work on short time frames, and focusing on the 4H chart and Daily chart in a paranoid way for the next 2‚Äì5 months (this, or forgetting about my holdings for 2‚Äì5 years).



Be well.



Xulian.

@kingjulianIam on twitter

title: Cannabis for Diabetes: You get High, but Your Sugar get Low
text:
Cannabis for Diabetes: You get High, but Your Sugar get Low

Cannabis Sativa green leaves

The medicinal properties of marijuana have been known to men for over 10,000 years. But since the 1930s, this plant has been kept underground in the US. Because cannabis became illegal, fear, crime, and ignorance were associated with cannabis. But of course, as we all know, this is rapidly changing.

California, Massachusetts, Maine, and Nevada all passed measures in November legalizing recreational marijuana. California‚Äôs Prop. 64 action allows adults 21 and older to possess up to one ounce of marijuana and grow up to six plants in their homes.

Finally, marijuana is getting the scientific community‚Äôs attention as many seek medical alternatives. As a result, new studies are appearing in all areas of disease prevention and treatment, such as cancer, seizures, and diabetes, to name a few.

Marijuana appears to have a beneficial influence in controlling blood sugar levels and preventing diabetes.

The relationship between pot and hunger and appetite have been widely known. Commonly known as the ‚Äúthe munchies‚Äù

The endocannabinoid system is a group of neuromodulatory lipids and their receptors in the brain, involved in various physiological processes including appetite, pain-sensation, mood, and memory; it mediates the psychoactive effects of cannabis inside our body. If pot increases appetite, how can that be good for diabetes? Even though pot is associated with an increase caloric intake it is also associated with a lower body mass index (BMI), lower obesity and diabetes, but why? New studies are beginning to investigate this.

Recent studies

The first study investigates the benefits of Tetrahydrocannabivarin (THCV) a neutral CB1 in obese rodents. The administration of THCV in obese mice and the subsequent improvement in metabolic functions in these rodents. THCV were found to improve fasting plasma glucose and glucose tolerance when given twice daily, improving insulin sensitivity.

An increased energy expenditure were also noted in obese mouse. THCV was also found to reduce liver triglyceride levels. In another study the use of Rimonabant or CB1 was tested in humans. For one year under the CB1 therapy was reported a 4.7 Kg or greater mean weight loss then the placebo mice group. The treatment also showed beneficial action on metabolic risk factors with an increase in HDL cholesterol (the good one) and a decrease in triglycerides (fat in the blood).

In yet another study seeking to determine the association between diabetes mellitus and marijuana use had a total sample of 10,896 adults including groups of non-marijuana users; past marijuana users; light users and heavy current users.

The results indicated that marijuana users had a lower age-adjusted prevalence of DM compared to non-marijuana users. The prevalence of elevated C reactive protein was significantly higher in non marijuana users (C reactive protein is involved with inflammation therefore having that around is not a good thing). This discovery pointed to the anti-inflammatory properties of marijuana. The study also found that there could be a relationship between early exposure to marijuana and deterrence in the development of diabetes. This study also review other studies performed in rodents where significant benefits against diabetic complications and atherosclerosis were noted in addition to the anti-inflammatory properties. It was also found that CB‚Äôs (the non-psychoactive cannabidiol was also found to attenuate the progression of DM type I in rodents.

The limitation of this study (the first one mentioned) were its cross-sectional nature. Persons attending the study may not have represented the larger sample of the population overall. Other limitations were the self-report format which is subject to bias and not always possible to be confirmed.

So what should you do?

So with so much evidence on the benefits of marijuana should you fire up that bowl yet? Not so fast, Even though the medicinal properties of marijuana have been known for a long time we are just discovering how they works. Many are reporting successes of marijuana therapy in various front lines of disease fighting but there are still many questions answered and methodology have not been yet refined.

Marijuana potency have been increasing as growers develop new planting techniques and dosages vary widely and the properties of certain plants are now being studied. We may know the proven benefits in laboratory studies but nothing have been yet tested on populations during a long time period. Unfortunately the therapies available are still being developed and because of the its illegal status in most of the world marijuana have been kept out of the hands of health care systems and professionals capable of delivering safe and effective care except for a few brave ones who goes against the grain in order to find new cures.

Image credit: Pixabay
